The contrast Internal > External probes internal attributions (self-responsibility) during social scenarios involving friends; this is a social cognition task and directly measures social processing (self vs other causal attributions).
Stimuli are friendship-related social events (e.g., a friend bought you a present), engaging affiliation/attachment processes; the contrast assesses attribution in the context of interpersonal bonds.

The task requires interpreting socially relevant interpersonal information (friend interactions) and making attributional decisions, which falls under social communication processing of socially relevant information.
Internal > External isolates self-responsibility attributions (judgments about oneself as causal agent), directly measuring perception/understanding of self (agency/self-judgment).

This contrast highlights greater activation for self-responsibility (internal attributions) rather than processing or understanding of others; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
The External > Internal contrast assesses external (other or situational) attributions during friend-related social scenarios, clearly a social processing measure focusing on others' responsibility.
Stimuli involve friend interactions and judgments about others' responsibility, engaging affiliation/attachment related social evaluations.
Participants interpret socially relevant statements about friends and decide causal attributions, which constitutes social communication processing of interpersonal information.
This contrast emphasizes external/other attributions (others/situational responsibility) and thus does not primarily index perception/understanding of the self.

External > Internal isolates processing when others (or situations) are judged responsible; the authors report STS activation for external attributions, consistent with perception/understanding of others (intentionality/action perception).
Self-serving bias contrast combines internal attributions of positive events and external attributions of negative events in interpersonal (friend) scenarios, a canonical social cognition measure.

The scenarios concern friends and positive/negative interpersonal outcomes; the self-serving attributional pattern relates to affiliation/attachment processing (self-enhancing in social relationships).
Evaluating causal attributions for friend-related events requires processing and interpreting socially relevant information, fitting social communication criteria.
Self-serving attributions involve attributing positive events internally (self-responsibility) and thus directly measure self-perception/agency and self-evaluative judgments.

The self-serving bias contrast also includes external attribution of negative events (attributing blame to others/situations), engaging perception and understanding of others' responsibility and intentions.
Non-self-serving bias contrast (internal negative, external positive) involves interpersonal attributions in friend scenarios and thus is a social processing measure.
Scenarios concern friends and attributions that affect social bonds; the contrast examines affiliation-relevant attributional patterns (credit/blame in relationships).
Participants interpret social statements about friends and make attributional decisions, engaging social communication processes (reception/interpretation of interpersonal information).
Non-self-serving attributions include internal attribution of negative events (self-blame), directly indexing perception/understanding of the self (agency, self-evaluation).
The contrast also includes external attribution of positive events (crediting others), engaging perception and understanding of others' roles and intentions in social outcomes.

Contrast compares affective (cooperators and defectors) vs neutral faces from a social learning task (Prisoner’s Dilemma). This directly measures social processing (perception and evaluation of socially learned moral status).
Task involves cooperation/defection (cooperators vs defectors) and formation of social bonds/attitudes (likeability, memory), so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.
The contrast involves perception of faces with socially relevant learned information (reception of facial communication and social information conveyed by faces), fitting Social Communication.

The contrast targets perception and evaluation of other persons (faces) learned through interaction rather than processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure Perception/Understanding of Self.

Contrast assesses representations and evaluations of others’ moral/social status (cooperators/defectors) learned via interaction—directly measures Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/intentionality and trait judgments).
Cooperator vs neutral faces contrast from an interactive cooperation learning paradigm probes social processing (evaluation of socially learned positive moral status).
Contrast isolates responses to cooperators (positive social bonds, rewarding social interaction), directly indexing affiliation/attachment processes (cooperation).
Measures reception of facial/social information (faces associated with cooperative behavior) and implicit social evaluation—fits Social Communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast focuses on representations of other people (cooperators) rather than self-related processing (agency or self-knowledge), so Perception/Self is not measured.
Directly assesses perception and evaluation of others’ social/moral status (cooperators) learned through interaction, engaging understanding of others’ traits and intentions.
Defector vs neutral faces contrast examines neural responses to socially learned negative moral status (cheaters) and thus probes social processing.
Defection is the converse of cooperation and directly pertains to affiliation/attachment (violation of cooperative bonds); contrast measures responses related to social affiliation/its breakdown.
Contrast involves perception of faces carrying socially relevant information (defection) and implicit evaluation—fits Social Communication (receptive facial/social information).
Contrast targets perception/evaluation of other agents (defectors) rather than self-reflection or self-related judgment; it does not measure Perception/Understanding of Self.
Directly assesses representations and evaluative knowledge about others (defectors), including moral/intentional attributes—measures Perception and Understanding of Others.
This contrast (intentional vs nonintentional cooperators) manipulates attribution of intentionality in a social cooperation context, probing high-level social processing and social cognition.
Comparing cooperators introduced as intentional versus nonintentional agents examines social bonding and reward related to perceived intentional cooperation—clearly affiliation/attachment relevant.
Manipulates perceived agency/intentionality associated with faces learned in cooperative interactions, affecting reception of socially communicative cues—fits Social Communication.
The contrast concerns attributions about other agents (intentionality of cooperators) rather than self-related judgments or agency of the subject; it does not index Perception/Self.

Directly probes understanding of others’ mental states/intentionality and social value (cooperators), measuring Perception and Understanding of Others (mental-state attribution, animacy/agency perception).

The contrast compares relational (two-person social interaction) versus alone segments and versus rest; it directly measures processing of social relationships and broader social cognition. Activations reported (dorsomedial PFC, precuneus, STS, IFG, fusiform) are canonical social-processing regions, so the analysis measures Social Processing.

Relational segments include Communal Sharing clips (affiliation) and Authority Ranking clips; the pooled relational vs alone contrast tests processing of affiliation/attachment-related social relations (especially communal sharing). Behavioral pretesting and stimulus design target affiliation-type relations, so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment processes.

Stimuli contain faces, biological motion, and speech in many clips; reported activations in STS, IFG, and fusiform gyrus reflect reception/processing of social communicative signals. The relational vs alone contrast therefore captures social communication (receptive) processes.

The task is passive observation of others’ interactions and does not require self-referential judgments or explicit self-processing. Although the Discussion speculates about self-related/default activity, the experimental contrast does not directly measure Perception/Understanding of Self.

The contrast explicitly compares observing interactions between others (relational) versus observing an individual alone; the task requires perceiving and interpreting others’ actions, intentions, and social roles. Reported activations (STS, IFG, dorsomedial PFC) are consistent with perception/understanding of others, so the analysis measures this construct.

Contrast (Cooperation vs Independent) directly manipulates a social interaction (cooperation) and measures neural responses to social processing (monitoring partner, joint goal), satisfying Social Processing inclusion criteria.
Cooperation trials explicitly index affiliative/attachment-related behavior (working together toward a common goal); the contrast isolates affiliation-related neural activity.
The cooperative task requires exchange of socially relevant information (coordination, monitoring partner actions); cooperation/competition are listed as example tasks for this annotation.
The contrast involves self-monitoring and sense of agency when coordinating moves with another (study discusses agency and self–other monitoring), meeting the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Cooperation requires representing and predicting the partner's actions/intentions (understanding others), so this contrast measures Perception/Understanding of Others.

Contrast (Competition vs Independent) manipulates a social interaction (competition) and measures neural responses to social cognition (monitoring opponent, differing goals), satisfying Social Processing inclusion criteria.

Although competitive rather than affiliative, the annotation guidance lists competition/cooperation as example tasks; the contrast measures social relationship dynamics relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Competition trials require exchanging/processing socially relevant information about the opponent's moves and intentions; cooperation/competition are example tasks for this annotation.
Competition emphasizes self–other distinction and agency (study reports inferior parietal/agency and medial prefrontal involvement), so the contrast taps Perception of Self processes.
Competition requires representing and predicting the opponent's intentions (mentalizing); the contrast measures Perception/Understanding of Others.
Direct comparison (Cooperation vs Competition) isolates different social mental sets and thus measures social processing broadly (distinct neural correlates of two social interaction modes).
This contrast directly compares affiliative (cooperation) versus competitive contexts, so it targets Affiliation/Attachment-related neural differences as per inclusion examples.
Cooperation vs Competition contrast examines differences in social information exchange and coordination demands, matching the Social Communication construct examples.

The contrast highlights processes related to self–other merging versus distinction and sense of agency (study reports orbitofrontal for cooperation, inferior parietal for self–other distinction), meeting Perception/Self inclusion.
The comparison probes differential mentalizing and representation of others (greater medial PFC for competition), directly addressing Perception/Understanding of Others.
Contrast (Competition vs Cooperation) isolates the social-cognitive processes specific to competition versus cooperation, thus measuring Social Processing.
The contrast emphasizes non-affiliative (competitive) versus affiliative (cooperative) processing; cooperation/competition are example tasks for this annotation, so include.
Competition vs Cooperation examines differences in social communication demands (e.g., predicting opponent vs coordinating), consistent with Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Competition-specific activations relate to self–other distinction and agency (right inferior parietal, medial PFC), so the contrast measures Perception/Understanding of Self.
Competition vs Cooperation highlights differential mentalizing about others (medial PFC increases during competition), directly measuring Perception/Understanding of Others.

Task involves evaluative judgments of moral/social emotions (guilt, embarrassment) and the authors interpret activations in MPFC and STS as reflecting Theory of Mind and social cognition. This directly measures broad social processing.

The paradigm presents short sentences eliciting guilt/embarrassment and asks evaluative judgments; it does not probe affiliation, attachment, close relationships, cooperation, or kinship-related processes.

Although stimuli are social in content, the task does not probe social communicative exchange (facial or non-facial communication reception/production) or explicit communicative behavior; it targets evaluative social emotion processes rather than communication per se.

Participants make judgments about self-conscious emotions (guilt and embarrassment) described in first-person sentences; this requires self-evaluation/self-monitoring processes and maps onto perception/understanding of self.

Authors emphasize Theory of Mind and representing others' mental states to evaluate self-conscious emotions; contrasts and reported activations (MPFC, STS) reflect processing of others’ perspectives, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.

Task explicitly contrasts perception of self-face vs a highly familiar other and examines neural responses related to self–other discrimination and social-cognitive networks; this is a social-related task and the contrast measures social processing.

The control stimulus is a personally familiar other (a close friend/colleague encountered daily), which taps affiliation/attachment-related representations; the contrast involves comparing self to a socially bonded familiar other.
The paradigm requires reception of facial information (face identification) and discrimination of self vs other, fitting the reception-of-facial-communication subconstruct of social communication.
The contrast directly tests perception and recognition of one’s own face (self as object), indexing self-related perceptual and agency-related processes.
The analysis contrasts self with a familiar other and therefore probes representations and perception of another person (familiar other), engaging processes of perceiving others.
This contrast (other > self) probes differential responses to a familiar social other versus self and examines social-cognitive/default-network engagement; thus it measures social processing.
The ‘other’ stimulus is a personally familiar individual (friend/colleague); the contrast highlights responses to a socially affiliated person, implicating affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Viewing and discriminating a familiar face involves reception of facial social information; the contrast captures social-communication-related perceptual processing of faces.
Although this contrast emphasizes ‘other’>‘self’, it still directly involves self-perception by comparison (self trials used as baseline/contrast), so it indexes self-related perceptual processing.
The contrast isolates activity greater for a familiar other and thus directly measures perception and representation of another person (social other), consistent with perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast (Person-impression > other trial types) explicitly isolates social-cognitive processing involved in forming impressions of other people versus objects and sequencing. This directly measures social processing (understanding others’ psychological characteristics).

The task involves impression formation about strangers and inanimate objects, not measures of affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation, or close-relationship contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger); thus it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.

Although faces are shown, the contrast targets impression formation/mental-state inference rather than exchange or production/reception of communicative signals (gaze, facial expressions as communication). The task does not operationalize social communication per the definition.
The analyses concern impressions of others (people vs objects) and do not involve self-referential judgments, self-awareness, or self-knowledge; therefore they do not meet Perception/Self criteria.

The contrast measures perception and understanding of others (forming impressions about people, inferring psychological characteristics and mental states). This directly matches the Perception/Others construct (including Understanding Mental States and Animacy Perception).

The contrast (Impression formation > Sequencing for person trials) isolates processes engaged when forming impressions of people (social-cognitive processing) compared with a nonsocial orienting task, so it measures social processing.

The contrast compares impression formation versus sequencing for persons but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/relationship measures); therefore it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

This contrast targets mental-state inference/impression formation rather than communicative exchanges or explicit receptive/expressive communication measures, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The task contrasts impression formation about others versus sequencing and contains no self-referential judgments or measures of self-perception; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Impression formation for person trials directly involves representing and reasoning about others’ traits/mental states (Understanding Mental States), matching the Perception/Others construct.

The contrast (Impression formation > Sequencing, all trials) identifies regions engaged by impression formation generally; significant effects reflect social-cognitive processing particularly for person trials and thus index social processing.

Although this contrast pools person and object trials, it still operationalizes impression formation versus sequencing, not affiliation/attachment measures (no cooperation, bonding, or relationship-specific contrasts).

The contrast contrasts orienting tasks (impression vs sequencing) and does not specifically measure communicative reception/production (gaze, expression exchange) or communication-focused tasks, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
No self-referential processing is involved in these contrasts; they concern impressions of others/objects and sequencing, so Perception/Self is not measured.

Impression formation contrasts, particularly where effects are driven by person trials, involve representing others’ traits and mental states. This matches Perception/Others (Understanding Mental States, Animacy Perception).

Although this analysis entry lacks a descriptive table name, it is part of the set of contrasts in the study that probe impression formation versus sequencing and person versus object targets. The study’s primary focus is social-cognitive processing, so in absence of contrary specification this analysis is treated as measuring social processing.
No information indicates this analysis measures affiliation/attachment (cooperation, bonding, loved one vs stranger); therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.

No evidence this analysis targets communicative exchange or reception/production of facial/non-facial communication; the study focuses on impression formation and mental-state inference rather than social communication.
No indication this analysis assesses self-perception or self-referential judgments; the study contrasts impressions about others and objects, so Perception/Self is not measured.

Given the study’s emphasis on forming impressions of people and the consistent mPFC effects for person-impression trials, this analysis is most plausibly related to perception/understanding of others (mental-state inference) and is therefore annotated as such.

Contrast involves unknown distracter faces vs scrambled baseline and does not target affiliation or attachment (no familiar/loved person comparison).
The task requires reception of facial information (face recognition) and thus fits Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
Contrast does not involve self-related stimuli or judgments and therefore does not measure perception/understanding of self.
Contrast isolates neural responses to viewing other (unknown) faces versus baseline, which indexes perception/processing of others' faces.
Contrast compares personally familiar face to unknown faces — a social task probing processing of social familiarity and recognition.
Familiar (fraternity brother) vs unknown contrast directly probes personal familiarity/attachment and uses explicit familiarity ratings, meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.
Contrast involves reception and recognition of facial identity (familiar vs unfamiliar) — a canonical social communication (receptive facial) task.
This contrast compares familiar other to unknown others and does not target self-related perception or judgments.
Contrast isolates processing of another person (familiar) versus other persons (unknown), directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Contrast compares self-face to unknown distracter faces — a clear social-related task probing self/other face recognition.
Although the contrast includes others as distracters, the primary focus is self versus unknown; it does not directly assess affiliation/attachment to a familiar person.
Task requires reception/recognition of facial identity (including self) and thus falls within social communication (receptive facial) processes.
Contrast isolates self-face processing relative to unknown faces and directly measures perception/understanding of self (self-recognition).
The contrast emphasizes self > others; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
Contrast compares familiar (personally known) face to self-face — a social task probing interpersonal recognition and social cognition.

Familiar (fraternity brother) vs self contrast highlights processing of a personally familiar/affiliative other and leverages measured familiarity/likability/trust — consistent with affiliation/attachment.
Contrast involves reception and discrimination of facial identity between self and a familiar other — fits social communication (receptive facial) constructs.
Although self is part of the contrast, the effect reported is greater activation for the familiar other versus self; the contrast does not primarily index self-perception processes.
This contrast specifically highlights neural responses to a familiar other (versus self), indexing perception/understanding of others.

Although a familiar (affiliative) face is used as the contrast, the comparison isolates self-specific processing (self > familiar) and does not directly assess affiliation/attachment as the primary construct.
Contrast involves reception/discrimination of facial identity (self vs familiar), fitting social communication (receptive facial) processes.
This contrast isolates neural activity associated with self-face recognition relative to a familiar other and directly measures perception/understanding of self (self-recognition).
The contrast emphasizes self > familiar, so it isolates self-related processing rather than primarily indexing perception/understanding of others.

Contrast compares angry vs neutral prosody in voices (AN+NA vs NN). This measures perception and appraisal of emotional social cues in voices—a core social processing task.
Contrast assesses emotional prosody (anger) in voices, not affiliation/attachment behaviors or relationships (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or similar measures).
Angry vs neutral prosody is a canonical social-communication stimulus (non-facial vocal affect recognition). The contrast measures reception of non-facial communication.
Task and contrast probe perception of others' vocal emotion, not self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency.
Contrast directly measures representations of others' emotional states (anger in voices), i.e., perception and understanding of others' affect.
Contrast isolates responses to angry prosody when it is attended (social/emotional voice processing under attention). This taps social processing of vocal emotion.
Contrast does not involve affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, etc.).
Attended angry prosody pertains to reception of non-facial social communication (vocal affect), so this contrast measures social communication processing.
The contrast examines processing of others' vocal emotion during an attended task, not self-related processing.
Contrast measures neural responses to others' emotional vocalizations (anger) when attended—directly indexing perception/understanding of others' emotional states.
Contrast examines responses to angry prosody when it is to-be-ignored (implicit processing of vocal emotion)—still social processing of voices.
No measures of affiliation/attachment are present; contrast focuses on detection of anger in voices, not bonding or related constructs.
Implicit/unattended processing of angry prosody concerns reception of non-facial social communication (vocal affect recognition).
Contrast indexes processing of external social vocal signals, not self-related cognition or judgments.
Even when ignored, angry prosody evokes representations of others' affect; the contrast probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states.
This contrast tests attention-dependent modulation of responses to angry voices (to-be-attended vs to-be-ignored) — a social-emotional processing comparison.
Contrast probes attentional modulation of vocal anger processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast directly addresses how reception of vocal social signals (angry prosody) is affected by attention, fitting social communication construct (reception of non-facial communication).
Analysis concerns perception of others' emotional vocalizations and attentional state, not self-perception processes.
Contrast measures how perception/processing of others' emotional states (angry voices) changes with attention, directly indexing perception_others.
Inverse of the previous contrast (to-be-ignored vs to-be-attended) still probes social-emotional processing (angry vs neutral voice under attention manipulations).
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or tasks.
Examines reception/processing of vocal affect under differing attentional states—falls within social communication (reception of non-facial cues).
Contrast pertains to others' vocal emotional signals and attention, not self-related perception or judgments.
Contrast probes perception of others' emotional states when unattended vs attended, directly assessing perception_others.

Spatial attention right vs left in this study is embedded within a vocal gender-decision task using socially relevant voice stimuli; although primarily attention-related, it still involves processing of social auditory stimuli and task context.
Contrast tests spatial attention (right vs left) and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.

Although the contrast is spatial-attention-focused, it modulates processing of voice stimuli (gender decision on voices) — reception of non-facial social communication is integral to the task context.
The contrast concerns attentional orientation within a voice-processing task, not self-related perception or judgments.
Right vs left attention affects how participants process voices (others' vocal signals); the contrast therefore relates to perception/processing of others' vocal information.

Left vs right spatial attention contrast is conducted in the context of a vocal gender-decision task with emotional prosody; it implicates processing of social auditory stimuli and therefore general social processing.
This contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs or tasks.
Contrast influences processing of voices (social communication) as participants selectively attend to left vs right auditory channels; reception of non-facial communication is relevant here.
Contrast addresses attentional orientation in a voice-based task, not self-related processing.
Selective attention to left vs right ear modulates how others' vocal signals (including emotional prosody) are perceived, aligning with perception_others.

Contrast isolates Theory-of-Mind processing (inferring intentions), a core social cognition task involving perceiving and reasoning about others — thus measures broad social processing.
Task requires inferring intentions but does not operationalize affiliation or attachment (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition paradigms).
Participants decode social information (non-verbal cartoon narratives) to infer intentions — equivalent to reception of non-facial social communication.
Contrast focuses on attributing mental states to others, not on self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
This contrast directly targets understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind), matching the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct.
Empathy contrast engages social cognition (attribution of emotion, understanding others' emotional states), thus broad social processing is measured.

Although empathy involves emotional responses to others, the task does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, loved-one vs stranger, or attachment styles).
Empathy blocks require interpreting social narratives and emotional states from visual cues (reception of non-facial communication), meeting social communication criteria.
Task instructions and contrasts focus on others' emotions, not self-judgments or self-referential processing.
Empathy contrast explicitly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (Understanding Mental States), matching this annotation.
Conjunction identifies areas common to ToM and empathy — both are social processes; thus broad social processing is clearly involved.
Conjunction shows overlap of ToM and empathy networks but does not isolate affiliation/attachment-specific processes (no attachment paradigms).
Overlap reflects regions engaged in decoding social narratives and emotional/intentional cues from visual stimuli, consistent with social communication (receptive non-facial communication).
Conjunction reflects processing of others (mental states/emotions) rather than self-related judgments or agency.
Conjunction highlights shared neural substrates for understanding others' mental and emotional states — directly fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others'.
This interaction contrast isolates regions more engaged by ToM than Empathy — both are social processes, so it still probes social processing.
Contrast identifies differential ToM-related activations but does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or tasks (no bonding/cooperation manipulations).
Differential activation for inferring intentions (ToM) versus empathic processing involves decoding of social narrative cues (reception of non-facial communication), relevant to social communication.
Contrast compares two other-focused processes (ToM vs Empathy); it does not examine self-perception or self-referential judgments.
The interaction isolates processes specifically tied to reasoning about others' intentions (a core 'Understanding Mental States' operation), so this annotation applies.
This interaction isolates Empathy>ToM activations, which reflect social cognitive processing of others' emotions — thus broad social processing.
Although empathy-related activations (e.g., amygdala, cingulate) relate to emotional processing, the experiment does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs specifically.
Empathy>ToM activations arise from interpreting emotional social information in the cartoons (reception of non-facial communication), fitting social communication.
Contrast focuses on perceiving others' emotions rather than self-related processes or judgments.
This contrast highlights neural systems engaged in understanding others' emotional states (perception and understanding of others), matching the annotation.

Contrast SOC>ARB isolates perception of socially relevant facial expressions vs arbitrary movements; this directly measures social processing (understanding/interpretation of social cues).
Contrast addresses perception of social signals but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or close-relationship comparisons).
SOC>ARB contrasts socially meaningful facial expressions (reception of facial communication) against arbitrary movements, directly indexing social communicative reception.
SOC>ARB pools across ME and OTHER and does not specifically measure self-related perception or self-knowledge processes.
Contrast concerns perceptual/interpretive processing of others' facial signals (understanding others' social cues), meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
ARB>SOC isolates processing of arbitrary (non-social) facial movements; this contrast indexes low-level perceptual/visual motion and face-processing rather than social processing per se.
ARB>SOC does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding, cooperation, or relationship comparisons).
ARB>SOC contrasts arbitrary movements that lack social communicative content, so it does not measure social communication (reception/production) per the construct definition.
ARB>SOC does not probe self-related perception or self-knowledge.
ARB>SOC emphasizes non-social visual motion and face-processing rather than representing or reasoning about others' mental states or actions.
ME>OTHER isolates self-involvement (being directly gazed at) vs observing others; this contrast indexes social processing related to interpersonal engagement and self-relevance.
Although ME>OTHER taps interpersonal engagement, it does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, attachment styles, cooperation, or loved-one comparisons).
ME>OTHER captures the communicative relevance of gaze (eye contact) and the reception of socially directed signals, which falls under social communication (receptive facial/gaze communication).
ME>OTHER explicitly contrasts self-directed versus other-directed stimuli, indexing self-related perception and processing (self-involvement, agency/self-reference).
The primary focus of ME>OTHER is on self-involvement; it does not specifically measure representations or reasoning about others’ mental states (the contrast emphasizes self-relevance).

OTHER>ME contrasts observing interactions directed to others vs being involved oneself; this reflects social processing related to third-person perspective and scene reconstruction in social contexts.
OTHER>ME does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding or relationship-related judgments.
This contrast involves perceiving facial expressions/gaze between agents (reception of social signals about others), fitting the social communication construct.
OTHER>ME specifically emphasizes other-directed events and third-person perspective-taking rather than self-related perception or self-knowledge.
OTHER>ME measures processing of others’ interactions and spatial/mental state reconstruction about others, aligning with perception and understanding of others.
SOC×ME interaction probes social signals when the observer is personally involved (combines social content and self-involvement), clearly a social processing effect.
The interaction reflects social engagement and self-relevance but does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/attachment measures).
SOC×ME isolates reception/processing of socially communicative facial expressions specifically when directed at the self, meeting the social communication criteria.
This interaction specifically examines how social cues are processed when self-involved, indexing self-related perception and processing.

Although focused on self-involvement, the interaction entails processing others' communicative signals (decoding others' expressions) in relation to the self, thus involving perception/understanding of others as well.
SOC×OTHER probes social signals directed to others (social content combined with third-person perspective), representing social processing.
The SOC×OTHER interaction addresses social perception for others but does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.

SOC×OTHER isolates processing of socially communicative facial expressions when they are directed to someone else, fitting the social communication construct (reception of facial communication about others).
SOC×OTHER focuses on others-directed social signals and third-person perspective-taking rather than self-related perception.
This interaction specifically targets understanding and reconstructing others' interactions and perspectives, aligning with perception/understanding of others.

The task requires participants to judge whether visual cursor movement is feedback from their own movement versus another’s movement; the abstract frames this as important for social interaction (self vs other detection). This constitutes social-related processing (self/other distinction) so meets I1.

The task does not assess affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation, or related measures; it is a perceptual/agency judgment rather than a measure of social bonds or attachment, so it does not meet I1.

The task does not involve exchange of social information, communication, or recognition/production of communicative signals (faces, gestures, speech). It is an agency/perception task rather than social communication, so it does not meet I1.

The contrast isolates neural responses to synchronous vs asynchronous feedback and directly tests participants' perception of whether a stimulus is feedback from their own movement (agency/self-recognition). This directly matches Perception and Understanding of Self (agency) and meets I1.

Because the task requires distinguishing self-generated from externally generated (other) movement, it involves perceiving and representing others' actions (action perception subconstruct). Thus it taps Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception) and meets I1.

As above: the passive-condition contrast examines judgments about whether visual motion is feedback from the subject or an external agent (self vs other), which is a social-related self/other processing question; meets I1.
The passive movement task does not measure affiliation, attachment, or social bonding; it is not an affiliation/attachment task and therefore does not meet I1.
The passive movement contrast does not involve communicative signal reception/production or social exchange; it is a perceptual/agency task and does not meet I1.

The Pa–Ps contrast (passive asynchronous vs synchronous) tests perception of whether visual feedback corresponds to the subject's own movement (ownership/agency), fitting Perception and Understanding of Self (agency); meets I1.

By contrasting passive asynchronous vs synchronous feedback, subjects judge whether the visual stimulus is externally generated (other) versus self; this engages action perception/awareness of others’ movements and thus fits Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception); meets I1.

The contrast compares faces associated with prior behavioral information versus novel faces in a one-back task; it probes spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge and neural systems for social cognition (APC, STS). This is clearly a social-related task measuring social processing.

The task/contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation, or bonding); it examines trait inference and affective person knowledge, not attachment processes.

The analysis involves reception of facial information and affective/person-related signals (face categorization, emotion-related responses such as disgust); it targets receptive aspects of social communication.

The contrast does not measure self-perception or self-referential judgments; although APC activity can relate to self-processing, the experimental manipulation concerns perception of others, not self-related processes.
The contrast measures representations and retrieval of knowledge about others’ traits and affective states (spontaneous trait inferences), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

This contrast (disgusting > aggressive) probes social-affective knowledge retrieved during face perception and engages social-cognitive and emotion systems (anterior insula, STS), so it measures social processing.

The contrast differentiates types of negative behaviors (disgust vs aggression) but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding, kinship, cooperation), so it does not meet affiliation criteria.
The contrast examines reception of facially-indexed social information and implicit affective responses (disgust-related signaling in faces), fitting the receptive component of social communication.
The contrast targets perception of others’ affective/person knowledge rather than self-related processing; it does not measure self-perception or self-knowledge.

The contrast differentiates inferred affective traits of other people (disgust vs aggression) and shows activation in regions representing others’ emotional states—directly relevant to perception/understanding of others.

The aggressive > disgusting contrast remains within the same domain of social cognition and face-based trait inference; it probes social processing by comparing different person-knowledge associations.
This contrast does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of relationship bonding or cooperation), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Even when reversed, the contrast concerns reception of socially relevant facial information and distinctions in affective/person-related signaling, meeting the social communication inclusion criterion.
The analysis concerns perception and inferred traits of other people rather than self-related processing; it does not measure perception or understanding of the self.

The contrast examines differences in how faces associated with different negative traits are perceived and represented, directly addressing perception and understanding of others’ traits and emotions.

The 'receiving aversive stimuli; parametric modulation' condition is embedded in a competitive social interaction paradigm: subjects observe an opponent adjusting the intensity of a stimulus that will be applied to them. This is clearly a social task measuring perception and response to socially relevant cues (anticipation of punishment from another person) and thus indexes broad social processing.

The task involves competition with an opponent (cooperation/competition construct), a core context for affiliation/attachment processes in social scenarios; the analysis measures responses during a competitive social interaction (opponent-adjusted aversive stimulus), so it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Subjects view dynamic social cues (an opponent’s adjustment of stimulus intensity and associated videos) and brain regions involved in processing social signals (e.g., STS, amygdala, insula) are reported. The contrast measures reception of socially communicative signals (facial/behavioral cues), satisfying social communication criteria.

The condition involves anticipation of personally-relevant punishment and is accompanied by measures of autonomic and self-reported responses; subjects’ internal states (anticipatory arousal, decision-related monitoring) are central to the contrast, indicating perception/understanding of self processes.

Subjects observe an opponent’s actions (adjusting stimulus intensity) and the analysis reports activations in areas linked to perceiving others’ states (insula, amygdala, STS), indicating representation and assessment of another person’s intentions/emotions.

The 'retaliation; parametric modulation' condition requires deciding how strongly to punish an opponent within a social interactive (competitive) context. This directly probes social decision-making and interaction processes and thus measures broad social processing.

Retaliation occurs in a cooperation/competition framework (competitive reaction time task, tit-for-tat behavior). The analysis measures behavior and neural responses during competitive interaction, satisfying the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

During retaliation subjects use communicative social signals (choice of stimulus intensity that is later conveyed via video of opponent suffering) and recruit regions (STS, temporal pole) tied to processing social communicative cues. The contrast therefore taps social communication processes.

Choosing retaliation intensity requires self-referential processing, conflict monitoring and evaluating one’s own intentions and feelings; dorsal mPFC activity correlating with chosen intensity supports involvement of self-related decision processes, meeting perception_self criteria.

Retaliation involves representing the opponent’s likely experience and integrating their potential suffering into decision-making; reported activations in regions associated with others’ representations (STS, amygdala, mPFC) indicate perception/understanding of others.

The conjunction of 'retaliation' and 'watching the opponent' identifies common activations (dorsal mPFC, STS, precuneus, inferior frontal gyrus) engaged across interactive social behaviors. This conjunction assesses core social processing involved in both active and observational interaction phases.

The conjunction captures neural responses across competitive interaction and observation of the opponent—both central to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition/cooperation contexts); thus it measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.

Common activations across both conditions include areas (STS, IFG) implicated in processing social communicative signals (facial/gesture information and action understanding), indicating that the conjunction measures social communication.

The conjunction includes dorsal mPFC/paracingulate activation—a region implicated in self-monitoring, conflict resolution, and mentalizing about action choices—consistent with perception/self processes engaged during both retaliation and observation phases.

The conjunction highlights regions (STS, precuneus, left amygdala) involved in understanding others’ actions and emotions across both conditions, directly indexing perception and understanding of others’ mental states and suffering.

Task is explicit emotion recognition of facial expressions, which is a core social process; the contrast measures social processing of emotions. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing.
Task assesses emotion recognition and age discrimination, not affiliation, bonding, or attachment-related behavior. Does not meet inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.
Explicit emotion recognition is reception of facial communication (affect recognition), directly measuring social communication. Meets inclusion criteria.
Tasks require judging others' emotions/age, not self-related judgments, so they do not measure perception or understanding of the self.
Emotion recognition involves assessing others' emotional states and traits, directly fitting perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria.
Implicit (age) task still involves processing faces with emotional expressions and measures social processing of facial information. Meets inclusion criteria.
Age discrimination does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or related comparisons). Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Although implicit, the task requires perception of facial cues and thus involves reception of facial communication; it measures social communication processes.
Task is about judging others (age), not self-related perception or judgments, so it does not measure perception of the self.
Participants evaluate faces and implicitly process emotional expressions, assessing others' characteristics/emotional states; fits perception and understanding of others.
The EMO-AGE contrast directly tests differences in social processing (explicit vs implicit emotion processing), so it measures social processing overall.
The contrast compares emotion vs age discrimination and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs or related contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The contrast isolates explicit reception/processing of facial emotional communication versus implicit processing, directly relevant to social communication (reception of facial cues). Meets inclusion criteria.
Contrast reflects differences in processing others' faces/emotions, not self-related perception or judgments; does not meet perception_self criteria.
The contrast examines differential representation of others' emotional states under explicit vs implicit attention, fitting perception and understanding of others.

The communication task (communication vs control) is explicitly a social task involving speaking to another (actor); it measures social processing broadly (understanding context, interaction).

This contrast (communication vs control) does not manipulate affiliation/familiarity (it combines familiar and unfamiliar), so it does not measure attachment/affiliation (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
The contrast isolates production of communicative speech (talking to actor) versus a control naming task, directly measuring social communication production.
The contrast does not probe self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency; it focuses on interacting with/communicating to another person.
Communicating to an actor requires perceiving and reasoning about the other’s intentions and social context; the contrast captures processes related to understanding others.
The description task involves viewing an actor and verbally describing actions — a social-related task involving perception/interpretation of social information.
Description vs control does not manipulate affiliation/familiarity (no loved vs stranger contrast), so it does not measure attachment/affiliation.

The description task is not social communication directed to the actor (it is descriptive, not communicative exchange); therefore this contrast does not measure social communication production per se.
The contrast does not target self-related processing or self-knowledge; it concerns perceiving/describing another’s action.
Describing another’s action requires perceiving and interpreting others’ actions/intentions, so the contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
Communication vs description isolates behavioral aspects of communicative speech — a social processing contrast by design.
This contrast averages familiar and unfamiliar conditions and contrasts communicative vs descriptive tasks; it does not specifically index affiliation/attachment (loved vs stranger).
The contrast directly targets production of communicative speech (communication task) versus non-communicative description, meeting criteria for social communication.
The contrast probes communicative behavior and understanding of social context, not self-related judgments or agency.
The contrast taps regions involved in understanding others’ intentions and social context (theory-of-mind related), so it measures perception/understanding of others.
Familiar vs unfamiliar communication is explicitly social, examining effects of biographical/familiarity information on communicative interactions — broad social processing.

This contrast (familiar communication − unfamiliar communication) directly compares a familiar (close friend) versus an unfamiliar actor, matching the affiliation/attachment criterion (loved one vs stranger type contrast).
This analysis examines how social-communication production is modulated by familiarity; it directly pertains to social communication and meets both task and contrast criteria.
The contrast contrasts familiarity of the communication partner and access to biographical information about others, not self-perception or self-judgment.

Comparing familiar vs unfamiliar actors probes representations and reasoning about others’ traits/biographical information and mental states (understanding others), satisfying perception_of_others criteria.

The analysis tests a social interaction simulation (peers/friends vs celebrities; approach/avoid/neutral) and reports neural responses to social stimuli and interactions (including contrasts for friends vs others). This directly measures broad social processing. Both inclusion criteria apply: the task is social (I1) and the contrast measures social processing (I2).

The key contrast isolates positive peers (operationalized as friends) versus other conditions, probing bonds/affiliation and positive social attachment; behavioral approach measures further index affiliative responding. Thus the task and contrast measure affiliation/attachment. Inclusion criteria I1 and I2 apply.

Stimuli are personally familiar faces and participants make social responses (approach/avoid) to them; analyses contrast loved/familiar individuals vs others and report regions involved in face/person knowledge and social cognition, consistent with social communication (reception of facial/social cues). Inclusion criteria I1 and I2 apply.

Participants perform a first-person social interaction simulation (move a figure representing themselves) and results include medial prefrontal/anterior midline activations linked to self-related processing. The task therefore engages perception/understanding of self in the social context; inclusion criteria I1 and I2 apply.

The analysis focuses on perceiving and evaluating others (peers, friends, celebrities), contrasts friends vs others, and reports activations in regions tied to person knowledge, theory of mind, and understanding others (e.g., temporal and medial regions). Thus it measures perception/understanding of others. Inclusion criteria I1 and I2 apply.

Table entry summarizes self vs. intimately known other (mother) studies—these are social tasks assessing social cognition; meets inclusion I1 (social-related task).
Studies summarized use intimately known others (close relationships/kin), which map onto affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).

These studies focus on self/other trait judgments and memory (self-reference effect), not on communicative exchange or facial/non-facial communication per se, so do not meet social_communication criteria.
Analyses concern self-referential processing (self-trait judgments), directly measuring perception/understanding of self (I1).
Analyses involve judgments about intimates/others (mother or other targets) and thus assess perception/understanding of others (I1).
This analysis (listed in the summary table) involves self vs. other social-reference tasks, hence is social processing (I1).
The study contrasts self with an intimately known other, implicating affiliation/attachment processes (I1).

Contains self-referential judgments; directly measures perception/understanding of self (I1).

Self-referential judgments are core to the analysis (I1).
Other-referential judgments about close others are included, indicating perception/understanding of others (I1).

Analyses include other-referential judgments (close others), tapping perception/understanding of others (I1).

Contrasts involve intimate others, implicating affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).

Conjunction of Self vs. Letter and Mother vs. Letter identifies common network for self- and mother-referential processing—clearly social processing (I1).
Mother condition is an intimately known other; conjunction captures processing about an attachment figure versus self (I1).
Contrast probes trait-based referential processing, not communicative reception or production; does not meet social_communication criteria.
Includes Self vs. Letter contrast and thus measures self-perception and self-referential judgments (I1).
Includes Mother vs. Letter contrast and thus measures perception/understanding of another person (intimate other) (I1).
Self vs. Mother contrast is a direct social comparison and addresses social processing (I1).
Contrast directly pits self against a close other (mother), assessing affiliation/attachment-related processing (I1).

Contrast includes self-referential processing and differences in self-related activation (I1).
Contrast also isolates mother-related processing (other perception); thus measures perception of others (I1).
Mother > Self contrast reflects social processing about an intimate other (I1).
Greater activation for mother implicates processing of an attachment figure (I1).
This contrast reflects differential referential processing rather than communication exchange; does not meet social_communication inclusion.
Although Mother>Self highlights others, the contrast involves self-processing comparisons and is relevant to self-perception (I1).
This contrast specifically shows greater activation for mother (other), directly indexing perception/understanding of others (I1).
Friends vs. Bumper Cars (SAT) is an abstract social attribution task engaging social cognitive processing (I1).
The Friends condition explicitly asks whether shapes are ‘all friends,’ which probes affiliation judgments/relations and thus maps to affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).
SAT requires inferring intentions/mental states from animations rather than studying communicative signaling (facial or verbal), so it does not meet the social_communication definition.
Task probes attribution about others/agents, not self-referential processing, so does not meet perception_self criteria.
SAT requires reasoning about agents' mental states and social relations, directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others (I1).

Analysis derives from the PD vs Gamble contrast (social interactive vs non-social control) and identifies a network active during social interaction; directly measures social processing.
The PD task measures cooperation and social bonding/reward-related behavior (affiliation), so the contrast addresses affiliation/attachment processes.
The iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma requires exchange of socially relevant information and reciprocal behavior (a form of social communication), so the analysis measures social communication.

Results implicate default mode/DMPFC regions and self-referential processing during the PD task (simulation/self-related inference), so the analysis taps perception/understanding of self-related processes.
The study explicitly examines mentalizing/theory-of-mind (DMPFC, TPJ) during interaction and contrasts inferences about partners, directly addressing perception and understanding of others.
This table stems from the same study contrasts/analyses of social vs non-social tasks; it pertains to social interaction processing and thus qualifies as social processing.
Analyses in the paper examine cooperation and in-group/out-group effects (affiliation-related behavior), so this table is relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Data derive from cooperative interactions (PD game) that involve exchange of socially relevant signals and reciprocity, consistent with social communication constructs.
Findings implicate default mode regions (self-referential/DMPFC activity) in task contrasts reported in the study, therefore the analysis relates to self-perception processes.
The analyses assess mental state attribution and partner-related responses (in-group vs out-group), directly measuring perception/understanding of others.
This analysis correlates behavioral discrimination (cooperation difference) with BOLD differences between in-group and out-group interactions — a direct social-processing measure.

The cooperation difference score is an index of affiliation/attachment preferences toward in-group vs out-group partners; the analysis identifies brain regions tracking this affiliation-related behavior.
Cooperation and reciprocity in the PD involve exchange of social signals; correlating cooperation differences with neural responses implicates social communication processes.

Regions implicated (e.g., DMPFC, insula) relate to self-referential and interoceptive processes that influence social decisions; the analysis examines neural signatures tied to the subject’s internal states during social choice.

The cooperation difference reflects differential treatment of others (in-group vs out-group) and the analysis identifies neural correlates of perceiving/valuing others’ social status; this maps onto understanding others (mentalizing, evaluation).
This analysis explicitly contrasts DMPFC functional connectivity for in-group vs out-group interactions, probing social-network dynamics — a core social processing measure.
DMPFC showed stronger connectivity with reward-related regions (OFC, ventral striatum) for in-group partners, directly relating to affiliation and attachment mechanisms.
Connectivity differences during reciprocal interactions reflect exchange and integration of social information between regions, consistent with social communication constructs.
DMPFC is implicated in self-referential simulation and the analysis examines its connectivity patterns during social interactions, indexing self-related processing in social contexts.
The connectivity contrast addresses how mentalizing-related DMPFC coupling differs for in-group vs out-group partners, directly relevant to understanding others’ mental states and social evaluation.

Contrast compares self vs friend across face and name recognition in a familiar/unfamiliar social judgment task; clearly probes social processing mechanisms.

Contrast isolates self vs friend (self-specific effect) but does not directly contrast a close other versus a stranger or test attachment/affiliation per se (friend vs unfamiliar contrasts are more direct for affiliation).

Task involves reception of socially relevant signals (faces and names) and contrasts responses to socially meaningful individuals; face and name recognition are central to social communication/reception.
The contrast targets self-related processing (self > friend) and therefore measures perception/understanding of the self.
Because the contrast compares self to a specific other (friend), it necessarily involves representation/assessment of another person and thus addresses perception of others.
Face-only contrast (self-face vs friend-face) is a social task probing social perception and self/other recognition.
This contrast isolates self versus friend for faces and does not directly test affiliation/attachment (no friend vs stranger contrast here).
Reception of facial signals for identification of self versus a familiar other is a canonical social-communication/reception task (face recognition).
Self-face > friend-face directly measures self-related perception and recognition processes.
Comparing self-face to friend-face necessarily involves processing representations of another person (friend); therefore it taps perception of others.
Name-only contrast (self-name vs friend-name) is a social recognition task (personal identity) and probes social processing.

This contrast compares self versus friend names and does not directly contrast a familiar other versus an unfamiliar stranger (friend vs control would be required for direct affiliation/attachment inference).
Recognition of written personal names involves reception of socially relevant identity signals (non-facial communication) and fits the social_communication construct.
Self-name > friend-name isolates self-related recognition and self-perception processes in the name domain.
Because the contrast involves a familiar other (friend) vs self, it engages representation of another person and thus perception of others.
Interaction isolates face-specific self effects (self-face vs friend-face relative to name), a social perceptual task relevant to social processing.
This interaction targets face-specific self-recognition and does not directly index affiliation/attachment (no familiar vs unfamiliar contrast).
Face-specific self effects concern reception of facial communication (face processing) and map to the social_communication construct (reception of facial cues).
This interaction specifically isolates neural responses linked to self-face recognition, directly measuring self-perception (agency/self-knowledge aspects tied to face).
Contrasting self-face with friend-face implicates perception of another person (friend) as part of the comparison, so perception_others is engaged.
Name-specific interaction isolates self-name effects (self-name vs friend-name relative to face), a social recognition task.
This analysis isolates self-name-specific activation and does not directly test affiliation/attachment (no familiar vs unfamiliar contrast).
Name-specific self effects concern reception of non-facial social signals (written names), fitting social_communication (reception of non-facial communication).
This interaction seeks activation specific to self-name recognition and thus measures aspects of self-perception/self-knowledge in the name domain.
Because the contrast compares self-name to friend-name, processing of the friend (another person) is involved, implicating perception of others.
Main effect friend > self across face and name probes social processing related to representing familiar others vs self and engages social cognition.
Although this contrast highlights responses to a friend relative to self, it is not a direct loved-one vs stranger (familiar vs unfamiliar) contrast that more directly indexes affiliation/attachment.
Friend > self across modalities involves processing socially relevant identity cues (faces/names) and taps social-communication reception processes.
The contrast is driven by greater response to the friend than to self and is primarily informative about representation of others rather than isolating self-perception processes.
Friend > self directly indexes neural responses to a familiar other and thus maps onto perception/understanding of others.
Face-only friend > self contrast probes social perception of a familiar other vs self in the facial domain; clearly social processing.
This face-specific friend > self contrast does not directly contrast friend vs unfamiliar (stranger), so it is not a direct test of affiliation/attachment.
Reception of facial signals (friend vs self) is a canonical social-communication/reception measure.
Because the contrast identifies greater activation for friend than self faces, it is primarily informative about perception of others rather than self-perception.
Face friend > self directly assesses representation of a familiar other (friend) and thus perception of others.
Name-only friend > self contrast is a social identity recognition task and probes social processing.
This contrast compares friend versus self names but does not directly contrast friend versus unfamiliar (stranger), so it is not a direct measure of affiliation/attachment.
Recognition of personal names (friend vs self) concerns reception of non-facial social communication and fits this construct.
Contrast emphasizes greater activation for friend names and thus speaks mainly to perception of others rather than isolating self-perception.
Friend-name > self-name directly involves representation of a familiar other, mapping to perception of others.
Face-specific friend > self interaction isolates face-related processing of a familiar other vs self; a social perceptual contrast.
This interaction isolates friend-face-specific effects versus name and does not explicitly test affiliation (friend vs stranger).
This is a face-specific social-communication (reception of facial cues) analysis contrasting friend and self.
The analysis targets greater activation for friend faces relative to self and thus primarily informs perception of others rather than self-perception.
Because it isolates friend-face effects relative to self, it measures representation/processing of another person (perception of others).
Name-specific friend > self interaction isolates friend-name effects (non-facial social signal); a social processing contrast.
This isolates friend-name-specific effects and does not directly compare friend to an unfamiliar stranger, so not a direct test of affiliation/attachment.
Name-based friend>self effects concern reception of non-facial social communication and fit this construct.
Because the contrast emphasizes greater activation for friend names, it primarily indexes perception of others rather than self-perception.
Friend-name > self-name assesses representation of a familiar other (perception of others) in the name domain.
Familiarity contrast (self+friend vs unfamiliar) directly probes social processing related to person familiarity and social relevance across modalities.

This contrast pits familiar individuals (self and friend) against an unfamiliar person (control), directly mapping onto affiliation/attachment (familiar vs stranger) comparisons used to index social bonds.
Familiarity effects across face and name involve reception of socially relevant identity cues and thus fit social_communication constructs.
The contrast combines self and friend and contrasts them with an unfamiliar person; it indexes person familiarity rather than isolating self-specific perception processes.
Because this contrast explicitly contrasts familiar others (friend) with unfamiliar persons, it targets perception/representation of others and person familiarity.
Face-only familiarity contrast (self+friend vs unfamiliar) probes social processing of familiar vs unfamiliar faces.
Comparing familiar faces (self and friend) to unfamiliar faces directly addresses affiliation/attachment-related familiarity effects (familiar vs stranger).
Face familiarity affects reception of facial social cues; this contrast pertains to social communication (face reception).
Although self is included, the contrast pools self and friend and thus captures familiarity rather than isolating self-specific perception.
Contrast includes friend (a familiar other) vs unfamiliar and therefore probes perception and representation of others (familiarity effects).
Name-only familiarity contrast (self+friend vs unfamiliar) probes social processing of familiar vs unfamiliar identity cues in the name domain.
Comparing familiar names (self and friend) to unfamiliar names captures familiarity/affiliation effects (familiar vs stranger), relevant to attachment/affiliation.
Name familiarity pertains to reception of non-facial social communication (identity cues) and fits the social_communication construct.
Pooling self and friend contrasts familiarity effects rather than isolating self-specific perception, so it is not a pure self-perception measure.
Because the contrast directly contrasts familiar others (friend) with unfamiliar persons in the name domain, it probes perception of others and person familiarity.
Face-specific familiarity interaction isolates face-domain familiarity effects (familiar vs unfamiliar) and therefore probes social processing.
This face-specific contrast compares familiar (self+friend) to unfamiliar faces and thus directly addresses affiliation/attachment-related familiarity (familiar vs stranger) in the face domain.
Face-domain familiarity effects implicate reception of facial social signals and map to social communication (reception of facial communication).
Although self is included in the familiar condition, the contrast pools self and friend and is aimed at familiarity effects rather than isolating self-specific perception.
This analysis contrasts familiar others (friend) and self with unfamiliar faces, thereby probing perception/representation of others (familiarity effects).
Name-specific familiarity interaction isolates name-domain familiarity effects (familiar vs unfamiliar), probing social processing of identity information.
This name-specific contrast contrasts familiar names (self+friend) with unfamiliar names, directly indexing affiliation/attachment-related familiarity (familiar vs stranger) in the name domain.
Name-domain familiarity concerns reception of non-facial social cues (identity via names), consistent with social_communication (reception of non-facial communication).
Pooling self and friend in the familiar condition targets familiarity rather than isolating self-specific perceptual processes.
Because the contrast examines familiar others (friend) vs unfamiliar persons using names, it probes perception/understanding of others and familiarity.

The SELF task explicitly probes empathic processing in an interpersonal context (participants rate their own emotional response to emotional faces), satisfying social processing criteria.
The contrast targets emotional perspective taking/empathy (self-reported emotion) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (no kinship, bonding, cooperation/competition manipulation).
Participants view emotional faces and select emotional descriptors — this is reception of facial communication (affect recognition) within a social task.
The SELF vs baseline contrast explicitly measures awareness/judgment of one's own internal emotional state in response to faces (self-perception/self-understanding).
This contrast focuses on participants' own emotional response (SELF) rather than representation or inference about others' emotional states.
The OTHER task requires evaluating others' emotional states from faces, a clear social processing/empathy measure.
The contrast measures emotion attribution to others (empathic inference), not affiliation/attachment processes such as bonding or cooperation.
OTHER vs baseline requires perceiving and characterizing facial expressions (reception of facial communication).
This contrast targets judgments about others' emotions (OTHER-task), not participants' own internal states.
The OTHER task directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (mental state inference from faces).
This analysis correlates mirror-neuron-related activation during SELF and OTHER tasks with empathy scores, addressing social processing mechanisms across tasks.
The correlations concern empathic response and mirror-system activation, not affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding measures.
Mirror neuron activation during tasks that involve perceiving and interpreting facial emotional communication is directly relevant to social communication (reception of facial cues).
Correlations include activation from the SELF task (self-attribution of emotion), so the analysis measures perception/understanding of self-related emotional states.
Correlations also include activation from the OTHER task (inference about others' emotions), thus measuring perception/understanding of others.
This interaction tests gender differences in the SELF task (females vs males), which probes empathic/social processing of self-related emotion in a social context.
The contrast isolates gender differences in self-related emotional attribution, not affiliation/attachment processes.
Although SELF-focused, the contrast involves responses to facial emotional cues and mirror-system regions, relevant to reception of facial communication.
This interaction specifically concerns the SELF task (self-attribution of emotion) and therefore directly measures perception/understanding of one's own emotional state.
The contrast compares SELF-related activations between genders and does not target perception or inference about others' mental states.
This contrast tests gender differences in the SELF task (males > females) and pertains to social/empathic processing of self-related emotion.
The analysis examines gender modulation of self-related empathic processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
SELF-task activations reflect processing of emotional facial stimuli and are relevant to reception of facial communication and mirror-system engagement.
The contrast directly indexes self-related emotion attribution (perception/understanding of self), so it meets the self-perception criteria.
This contrast focuses on SELF-task gender differences and does not probe perception/understanding of others' states.
This interaction addresses gender differences in the OTHER task, which is an empathic/social task (inferring others' emotions).
The contrast concerns emotion attribution to others (empathic inference) rather than attachment/affiliation measures.
The OTHER task involves perceiving and interpreting facial emotional expressions (reception of facial communication), so this analysis maps to social communication.
This contrast is specific to OTHER-task gender differences and does not measure participants' self-perception or self-evaluation of emotion.
The OTHER-task directly measures inference about others' emotional states (perception and understanding of others).
