Contrast directly isolates social tasks showing activation above rest (social > rest) and contrasts with mechanical deactivation; the analysis measures social cognition (theory of mind, emotion understanding) across text and video modalities.

Social stimuli include interpersonal relationships, parental and romantic contexts and moral/emotional content (e.g., father/child, partners), so the analysis captures affiliation/attachment-related social content.
Social tasks involve interpreting conversations, emotional states and extralinguistic cues in videos and texts — core social communication processes (receptive/interpretive aspects) are measured.
Tasks require reasoning about others' beliefs and emotions (third‑person), not judgments about the participant's own traits or internal states; no self-perception measures.
The contrast targets understanding others (mental states, emotions, beliefs) across modalities — directly measures perception and understanding of others (theory of mind).

Although framed around mechanical activation, the analysis includes the social condition (social < rest) so it assesses social processing (deactivation relative to rest) and contrasts social vs mechanical networks.

The social condition in this contrast comprises narratives with relationship, moral and emotional content (family, partners, friends), so the analysis involves affiliation/attachment related stimuli even if deactivated here.

The social stimuli (videos and texts) require interpretation of conversational and emotional cues; the contrast includes these social communication demands (measured as deactivation relative to rest).
Social stimuli probe others' beliefs and emotions rather than self-related judgments or introspection; no self-perception contrasts are measured.

The social condition involves reasoning about others' mental states and emotions; the analysis therefore includes measures of perception and understanding of others (albeit showing deactivation relative to rest here).
Direct contrast of social > mechanical isolates social processing regions (theory of mind, emotion understanding) across modalities, so it explicitly measures social processing.

Social > mechanical contrast is based on stimuli rich in interpersonal, moral and affiliative content (family, friendship, romantic scenarios), so affiliation/attachment-related processing is captured.
Contrast emphasizes social narratives and videos requiring interpretation of conversational and emotional cues — core social communication processes are probed.
Contrast targets representations of others (beliefs, emotions) rather than self-related judgments or monitoring; no self-perception tasks.
Social > mechanical contrast directly indexes understanding others' mental states and emotions (theory of mind), meeting the perception_of_others construct.
This contrast isolates mechanical > social activity (mechanical processing favored); it does not primarily measure social processing activations.
The contrast focuses on mechanical reasoning over social; it does not target affiliation/attachment processing.
Mechanical > social contrast does not measure social communication processes as the primary effect; social conditions are the baseline comparator rather than the focus.
No self-related perception or self-judgment tasks are involved in this contrast.
The contrast emphasizes mechanical reasoning over social; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.

This analysis contrasts all action-observation conditions against fixation; the task involves social-cognitive processing (observing actions, adopting goals about others’ actions), so it measures broad social processing (I1).
The contrast does not involve affiliation, attachment, relationship or bonding constructs (no loved-one/stranger or cooperation/competition manipulations); does not meet I1 for this construct.

The task involves action observation and mentalizing rather than communicative exchange, facial or non-facial signal reception/production; it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast assesses perception/understanding of others’ actions and intentions, not self-related judgments or self-awareness; it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The contrast measures action perception and inference about others (what/how/why goals and mirror/mentalizing systems), directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception and mental-state understanding) (I1).
This conjunction compares how-goal versus observe-goal across loads, isolating action-understanding processes; these are social-cognitive and fall under broad social processing (I1).
The contrast isolates mechanistic action understanding (how) vs passive observation; it does not probe affiliation/attachment or relationship-related constructs.
The comparison focuses on action understanding (implementation) rather than communicative reception or production; it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
This analysis contrasts different goals for perceiving others’ actions and does not measure self-related processing or self-knowledge.
The how>observe conjunction isolates neural responses to perceiving and understanding others’ actions (action perception subconstruct), satisfying Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).

This analysis tests modulation by cognitive load across goals during action observation — a manipulation of attentional resources on social-cognitive processing; it therefore measures social processing (I1).
The analysis examines load effects on action/mentalizing systems, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation manipulations).
The focus is on load modulation of action/mentalizing processing rather than communicative exchanges or facial/non-facial signaling; does not meet Social Communication criteria.
This contrast probes how cognitive load affects processing of others’ actions/mental states, not self-perception or self-knowledge.
Modulation-by-load analysis targets mirror and mentalizing systems engaged in perceiving others’ actions and inferring mental states, matching Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).
This contrast isolates why-goal at low load versus other conditions, specifically targeting mentalizing about others’ motives — clearly within social processing (I1).
Although mentalizing about motives is social, the contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment or bonding measures; no affiliation-specific tasks or contrasts are present.
The contrast concerns inferring motives/mental states rather than communicative signal reception or production; it does not match Social Communication criteria.
The low-load why contrast targets understanding others’ intentions and mental states, not self-related processes or judgments.

This analysis specifically isolates mentalizing regions (dmPFC, aTC) engaged when inferring others’ motives — directly indexing Understanding Mental States and thus Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).
Load-by-goal interaction examines how attentional resources and task goals influence neural systems for action understanding and mentalizing — clearly social processing (I1).
The interaction assesses cognitive-control effects on action/mentalizing systems, not affiliation or attachment constructs; no relationship/bonding measures are involved.
The analysis addresses goal and load effects on action understanding/mentalizing rather than communicative behaviors or facial/non-facial communication reception/production.
The load-by-goal interaction targets processing about others’ actions and mental states rather than self-related cognition or self-awareness.

The interaction reveals regions of the mirror and mentalizing systems sensitive to goal and load — these regions support action perception and mental-state inference, matching Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).

The analysis measures adaptation between observation and execution of hand actions and observation of shapes after sensorimotor training. This probes processes involved in perceiving and interpreting others' actions (mirror system) and therefore falls under broad Social Processing.

The task does not probe affiliation, attachment, relationship formation, cooperation, or related constructs; it involves sensorimotor training and action observation/execution without any measures of bonding or attachment.

The analysis does not measure social communication (no facial/expressive communication, gaze, or interaction exchanges). It focuses on action observation/execution and associative learning, not communicative behaviors.

Although participants execute actions, the contrasts index mirror responses and perception of observed actions rather than self-related processes (agency, self-knowledge, self-monitoring). The analysis does not target self-perception explicitly.

The analysis directly tests perception and understanding of others' actions (action observation, mirror system responses, adaptation between observed actions and shapes). This matches the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others.

Session 2 examines adaptation between observation of shapes and observation of actions, probing processes involved in perceiving and interpreting others' actions (mirror representations). This constitutes Social Processing.
The task does not involve affiliation, attachment, relationships, or related social-bond measures; it focuses on sensorimotor associations and action observation.
No measures of social communication (facial expression reception/production, gaze, or communicative interaction) are present; the contrast targets action observation/execution mapping.
Session 2 contrasts observation conditions and tests mirror responses to shapes and actions; it does not assess self-related processes such as agency or self-knowledge.

The analysis directly targets perception of others' actions (action observation and mirror-system adaptation), aligning with the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast compares ostensive (interactive) vs non-ostensive (observational) social scenes, directly probing social perception, engagement, and interactive processing across behavior, pupillometry, and fMRI. This meets the general Social Processing definition.

The contrast manipulates ostensive cues and interaction affordances but does not assess affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation vs stranger/loved-one distinctions or relationship measures; it does not target attachment constructs.

Ostensive cues (eye contact, eyebrow flashes, nods) and communicative object-directed gestures probe reception and production aspects of social communication (gaze/face signals and communicative gestures).
The contrast addresses perception of others and interactive affordances, not self-awareness, agency judgments or self-knowledge; the task does not measure perception/understanding of self.

The contrast concerns perception and understanding of others’ communicative and object-directed actions and inferred social intent, matching Action Perception and Understanding Mental States subcomponents.
Non-ostensive > ostensive contrasts observational social cognition vs interactive scenes; this directly measures social processing (observation, mentalizing, action understanding) across measures.
The contrast isolates observational processing (ToM/MNS activity) but does not probe affiliation/attachment, relationship valence, or bonding/cooperation measures.

Even in non-ostensive scenes participants perceive others’ faces and actions and perform communicative/receiving judgments (recognizing actions, intentions), fitting the Social Communication construct (receptive aspects).
This contrast emphasizes perception of others and inferential processing (ToM), not tasks assessing self-related knowledge, agency, or self-monitoring.
Non-ostensive > ostensive elicits ToM- and MNS-related activity reflecting action perception and inference about others’ mental states — directly within Perception and Understanding of Others.
Action vs non-action contrasts probe perception of social/communicative gestures and associated neural systems (pSTS, IFG, IPL) and thus index social processing broadly.
The Action > Non-action contrast manipulates presence of gestures but does not target affiliation/attachment, relationship or bonding measures (no loved-one vs stranger, cooperation metrics).

Action trials contain object-directed, communicative gestures (showing/placing) and elicit mirroring and communicative-processing regions — consistent with production/reception of non-facial communicative acts.
Contrast addresses perception of others’ actions and associated neural mirroring/mentalizing, not self-related introspection or self-knowledge measures.
Action perception engages MNS/pSTS and reflects action perception and understanding of others’ behaviors and intentions, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Eye-movement-corrected ostensive > non-ostensive contrast still probes interactive vs observational social processing (rpSTS effect survives correction) and therefore measures social processing.
Although corrected for eye movements, this contrast remains focused on ostensive interactive affordances rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding measures.

Corrected contrast isolates effects of ostensive communicative cues (eye contact, nods) independent of gaze behavior, still indexing social communication processes (reception/production of communicative signals).
The corrected analysis controls for gaze but remains focused on perception of others and interactive affordances rather than self-perception or agency measures.
Eye-movement-corrected results show rpSTS sensitivity to ostensive stimuli (interactive affordances), reflecting perception/processing of others’ communicative actions and inferred intent.
Eye-corrected non-ostensive > ostensive contrast indexes observational social cognition (ToM/MNS trends) and thus falls under Social Processing.
This corrected contrast emphasizes observational processing rather than measures of affiliation, bonding or relationship dynamics; no attachment-specific measures are present.
Even after eye-movement correction, the contrast engages regions involved in perceiving others’ actions and intentions (receptive aspects of social communication), so it fits the construct.
The contrast reflects processing of others (mentalizing/mirroring) rather than explicit self-related judgments or self-knowledge tasks.
Corrected non-ostensive > ostensive shows activity in ToM/MNS regions related to action perception and mental-state inference about others, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Eye-corrected Action > Non-action still probes perception of others’ gestures and social processing (pSTS, IPL, IFG effects) and thus meets Social Processing criteria.
Although actions are social, the corrected contrast does not target affiliation/attachment, bonding, or relationship-specific measures.
Action conditions contain communicative object-gestures and produce engagement of mirroring/communication-related regions after eye-movement correction, consistent with Social Communication.
The contrast examines perception of others’ actions rather than self-related processes (agency, self-knowledge), so Perception/Self is not measured.
Corrected Action > Non-action engages networks for action perception and understanding of others’ intentions (pSTS, IPL, IFG), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task explicitly manipulates sociality (trustworthiness judgments of faces) and contrasts social vs nonsocial working memory. This directly measures social processing (perception and maintenance of social information) across behavioral and neural measures.

The task assesses trait judgments (trustworthiness) and working memory, but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, or loved vs stranger contrasts).

Participants make perceptual judgments about faces (trustworthiness), which is reception of facial social cues—a form of social communication (receptive facial communication). The contrasts measure this process.
The tasks and contrasts concern judgments about others' facial traits and spatial positions, not self-related processing or self-knowledge/agency.

Trustworthiness judgments require representing and assessing others' traits—directly fitting perception and understanding of others (trait inference). The analysis contrasts social (trait) vs nonsocial information, measuring this construct.

The experimental manipulation includes social (trustworthiness) versus nonsocial conditions and examines behavioral and neural responses to social information in working memory, thus indexing social processing.
No measures or contrasts target affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation); the task focuses on trait inference and spatial location.
Judging trustworthiness from faces is reception of facial social cues (receptive facial communication). The contrasts and load manipulations probe this receptive communication process.
The study does not involve self-referential judgments or self-knowledge; participants judge others' traits and positions.
The core social manipulation requires perceiving and inferring others' trait information (trustworthiness), matching the perception/understanding of others construct.
All contrasts manipulate and measure social content (trustworthiness) versus nonsocial content, assessing social information processing in working memory and brain networks.
The paradigm does not assess affiliation or attachment (no bonding/cooperation/relationship measures), so this annotation is not applicable.
The task involves reception of facial cues (trustworthiness), which falls under social communication (receptive facial communication). The contrasts measure this process.
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are involved; the focus is on others' traits and spatial positions.
Trustworthiness judgments are trait inferences about others, directly mapping onto perception and understanding of others; the analyses measure this construct.

Contrast involves famous faces (social stimuli) vs baseline; assesses processing of socially relevant person knowledge and recognition.
Famous faces reflect semantic person knowledge but do not measure affiliation/attachment (no loved-one vs stranger or close-relationship task).
Task involves face perception/recognition (receptive facial communication), which falls under social communication.
Contrast does not measure self-related processing or self-knowledge; it targets perception/knowledge of other people.
Recognizing famous individuals is a form of perceiving and understanding others' identities/traits.
Contrast involves personally familiar faces (friends/acquaintances) vs baseline; clearly social in nature.
The friend-face task included social closeness judgments (which-friend-is-closest), directly measuring affiliation/attachment.
Perception/reception of familiar faces and social judgments fall under social communication (facial reception).
Although the task asks about closeness, the primary contrast (familiar faces vs baseline) indexes perception of others rather than explicit self-reflection or self-knowledge.
Recognizing and making judgments about friends involves perception and understanding of others' identities and social relationships.
Conjunction of famous and familiar face activations highlights social/person knowledge processing.
Conjunction includes famous faces (semantic) and familiar faces; not specifically a measure of affiliation/attachment across the contrast.
Overlap reflects face-related reception/recognition processes relevant to social communication.
Conjunction reflects perception of other people (familiar/famous) rather than self-related processing.
Shared activations for known people indicate processing/representation of others' identity and associated knowledge.
Faces vs landmarks contrasts elicit face-specific social processing (face perception network engagement).
General face > landmark contrast does not probe attachment/affiliation specifically.
Faces engage receptive facial communication processes (e.g., FFA, TPJ), meeting social communication criteria.
Contrast indexes perception of others (faces) rather than self-related cognition.
Face perception is a canonical example of perception/understanding of others' identities and expressions.
Landmarks > faces highlights non-social scene/landmark processing rather than social processes.
Landmark processing does not probe affiliation/attachment.
Contrast does not involve social communicative signals (faces); it emphasizes non-social visual processing.
No self-related processing is targeted by landmark > faces contrast.
Landmarks are non-social; contrast does not probe perception/understanding of other people.
Famous > novel faces contrast probes social/person knowledge and recognition processes.
Famous faces involve semantic knowledge but do not assess attachment/close relationship measures.
Differential responses to famous faces reflect receptive facial/identity communication processes.
Contrast taps knowledge about others rather than self-referential processing.
Famous face recognition involves representing others' identities and associated knowledge.
Novel > famous faces contrast assesses perceptual/social processing of faces (face discrimination).
Novel face processing does not index affiliation/attachment.
Perceptual discrimination of novel faces is part of receptive facial communication processes.
Contrast concerns perception of other individuals rather than self-related cognition.
Processing novel faces requires perceiving and discriminating other persons (identity perception).
Novel faces vs novel landmarks contrasts social face perception against non-social scenes; engages social processing.
Novel face discrimination does not probe affiliation or attachment.
Face perception (even for novel faces) is reception of facial communication and fits this construct.
Contrast measures perception of others, not self-related processes.
Novel face processing indexes perception and discrimination of others' identities (perception of others).
Novel landmarks > novel faces emphasizes non-social scene processing; not a social task.
Landmark processing does not measure affiliation/attachment.
Contrast focuses on landmark perception; does not probe facial communication.
No self-referential processes are targeted.
Does not involve perception or understanding of other people.
Famous faces vs novel landmarks compares social (faces with person knowledge) to non-social stimuli, engaging social processing.
Although famous faces are social, this contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment specifically.
Face recognition and retrieval of person knowledge implicate receptive facial/social communication processes.
Contrast targets perception/knowledge of others rather than self-related cognition.
Recognizing famous individuals and associated information indexes perception and understanding of others.
Novel landmarks > famous faces targets non-social landmark processing dominating social content.
Landmark processing does not probe attachment.
Contrast emphasizes landmarks (non-social), not facial communication.
No self-related processing is measured.
Does not index perception/understanding of people.
Famous landmarks > novel landmarks concerns scene/landmark knowledge, non-social.
Landmark familiarity does not probe affiliation/attachment.
No facial or social communicative signals are contrasted here.
Contrast does not involve self-related cognitive processing.
Landmark processing is non-social and does not assess perception of people.
Novel landmarks > famous landmarks focuses on non-social scene novelty, not social processing.
No affiliation/attachment content in landmark contrasts.
Contrast does not involve facial or social communicative processes.
No self-related processing is indexed by landmark novelty contrasts.
Does not probe perception/understanding of other people.
Familiar (friend) faces > novel faces directly probes social processing and person knowledge, including social closeness judgments.
This contrast stems from a social closeness task asking which friend is closer, directly indexing affiliation/attachment.
Recognizing familiar friends and making social judgments engages receptive facial communication processes.
The social closeness judgments require participants to evaluate relationships relative to themselves (self-referential social judgment), meeting perception_self criteria.
The contrast involves perceiving and reasoning about other people (friends' identities and closeness), fitting perception_of_others.
Conjunction of famous and familiar faces highlights social/person-related processing across stimuli.
Although familiar faces may include friends, the conjunction does not specifically index attachment versus stranger contrasts.
Overlap indicates shared face-processing/receptive social communication mechanisms for known people.
Conjunction reflects perception of others (known people) rather than explicit self-related processing.
Shared activations for known people reflect perception and representation of others' identities and social knowledge.

Contrast compares receiving social feedback (yes vs no) about romantic partners; task is explicitly social and measures processing of social information and reactions.
Contrast indexes responses to romantic interest (yes) versus rejection (no), directly probing affiliation/attachment-related outcomes and reward value of potential relationships.
Contrast reflects reception of social communicative signals (partners' yes/no decisions and faces) and participants' interpretation of that information.
Participants' own decisions, expectations, and self-relevant affect (happiness, desirability) modulate responses to yes vs no; contrast engages self-related processing.
Contrast involves inferring and responding to others' decisions about the participant (understanding others' choices/intentions), engaging perception/understanding of others.
Reverse contrast of analysis_0 (no > yes) still probes social processing of romantic feedback and its consequences.
Contrast emphasizes social rejection/disinterest which directly pertains to affiliation and attachment processes (loss or absence of reciprocal interest).
Still measures reception of social communicative signals (partners' decisions) and participants' interpretation of those signals.
No > Yes highlights negative self-relevant outcomes (rejection) and engages self-related affective and evaluative processes.
Contrasts participants' perception of others' decisions (rejecting or disinterested partners), implicating understanding others' intentions/choices.
Match vs Unrequited contrasts mutual vs non-mutual social reward — clearly a social processing contrast.
Match (mutual interest) directly indexes affiliation/attachment-relevant outcomes versus unrequited interest.
Contrast involves reception of partner decisions and differences in communicative reciprocity (mutual vs unreciprocated signals).
Match vs Unrequited engages self-relevant valuation and affect (desire for contact, happiness) and thus self-perception processes.
Distinguishing mutual from unrequited interest requires representing and evaluating others' feelings/intentions about the participant.
Rejection versus Disinterest contrasts negative social feedback in a romantic context and probes social processing of that feedback.
Rejection (desired partner says no) is directly relevant to affiliation/attachment dynamics and loss of prospective relationship.
Contrast measures reception and interpretation of communicative signals (partner’s no when participant said yes vs mutual no).
Rejection engages self-related affective processing (hurt, self-image) and thus perception/understanding of self.
Understanding that a desired partner rejected you requires representing the other's decision and intentions, implicating perception of others.
Mismatched vs Matched contrasts probe expectancy violations in social interactions, a core social processing function.
Mismatches (unreciprocated or rejected interest) affect formation and maintenance of affiliative bonds and are central to attachment-related processes.
Mismatched outcomes reflect communicative incongruence between parties (recipient vs sender signals) and involve processing of social communication.
Mismatches engage self-relevant learning/updating (self-desirability, expectations) and thus recruit self-perception processes.
Mismatches necessitate updating beliefs about others' intentions and mental states (mentalizing), engaging perception of others.
Unsigned prediction errors from an RL model index surprise about social feedback and learning across social interactions — a social processing measure.
Prediction errors reflect changing estimates of one’s desirability to others and thus relate to affiliation/attachment learning about social acceptance.
Prediction errors arise from receiving communicative signals (yes/no) and represent how those signals update beliefs — a form of social communication reception.
The RL model specifically captures learning about the participant’s own desirability (self-relevant prediction errors), directly implicating self-perception and self-related learning.
Prediction-error signals are used to update beliefs about others' likely responses, involving representation and inference about others' decisions/mental states.
Contrast at face presentation (partners given yes > no) probes anticipation and processing of social partners and expected reciprocal interest — core social processing.
Faces of partners the participant said yes to index potential affiliative partners and anticipated attachment-related reward, directly relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast measures anticipatory responses to partners' communicative decisions (face + expected decision), i.e., processing incoming social signals.
Anticipation of partner responses is tied to the participant's own choices and expectations (self-relevant valuation), engaging self-related processes.
Faces cue inferences about others (likelihood they will say yes), engaging perception/understanding of others prior to explicit feedback.
Reverse of analysis_6 (partners given no > yes) still examines social processing of anticipated interactions with less-desired partners.
Contrast emphasizes partners the participant rejected (no) which relates to affiliation dynamics and lack of attachment seeking.
Measures processing of social communicative cues (face and expected decision) for partners judged negatively or non-preferred.
Viewing less-desired partners and anticipating their likely response implicates self-related expectations and preferences (self-perception processes).
Inferences about others' likely decisions and attitudes toward the participant are central to this contrast, engaging perception of others.

The analysis contrasts neural responses while holding a friend, a stranger, or alone during threat anticipation—this is a social regulation task directly assessing social processes. It measures how social context modulates threat processing, meeting the inclusion criterion for Social Processing (I1).

The key contrasts compare a familiar/platonic friend versus an anonymous stranger and alone; this directly probes affiliation/attachment-related processes (receptivity to support from close others) and matches the inclusion criterion (I1).

The task involves physical contact (hand-holding) but does not involve exchange of communicative signals, face or gaze processing, or verbal/nonverbal interaction intended as communication. Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion (I1).

Although some regions implicated relate to self-monitoring, the paradigm does not explicitly probe self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency judgments. The contrasts test social regulation of threat rather than explicit self-related processing, so Perception/Self inclusion criterion (I1) is not met.

The design manipulates the presence of another person (friend vs stranger) but does not explicitly require inferring others' mental states or emotions (mentalizing). The primary measure is modulation of threat responses by social context rather than direct assessments of perception/understanding of others, so Perception/Others inclusion (I1) is not satisfied.

This analysis examines insular and subcortical threat-related activations as a function of holding a friend, stranger, or alone—directly assessing social modulation of threat processing and thus meets Social Processing inclusion (I1).

Contrasts involve friend versus stranger versus alone, indexing affiliation/attachment-related regulatory effects of close others on subcortical/insular threat responses; this fulfills the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion (I1).

The insular/subcortical analysis reflects physiological and affective regulation during hand-holding, but not communicative signal processing (faces, gestures, speech). Thus it does not meet Social Communication inclusion (I1).

While insula and ACC can index interoception and self-related affect, the reported contrasts target social regulation of threat rather than explicit self-reflection or agency judgments; therefore Perception/Self inclusion (I1) is not met for this analysis.

Although the analysis involves other people (friend/stranger), it does not directly probe representations or inferences about others' mental states; the focus is on modulation of threat responses, so Perception/Others inclusion (I1) is not satisfied.

Contrast (CSL>TIC) compares complex social laughter vs tickling laughter; stimuli and task involve perception and interpretation of social signals (explicit/implicit tasks), thus measure social processing.

Although tickling laughter is discussed as related to social bonding, the contrast does not directly measure affiliation or attachment (no attachment/relationship tasks or contrasts like loved one vs stranger).
The contrast examines perception of different laughter types — nonverbal vocal signals — directly probing reception of social communication.
Contrast targets perception and processing of others' laughter and socio-relational information, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.

CSL>TIC contrast elicits activity in mentalizing-related regions (arMFC, precuneus) and assesses inference about others' intentions/emotional states, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
Contrast (TIC>CSL) compares tickling vs complex social laughter; the task involves processing social vocalizations and associated interpretation, thus measures social processing.

Although tickling laughter relates to bonding in the background theory, this contrast probes acoustic complexity and processing demands rather than affiliation/attachment per se; no attachment-specific task or contrasts were used.
The contrast addresses perception and neural processing of nonverbal vocal communication (laughter), directly testing social communicative signal processing.
This analysis examines auditory and cognitive processing of others' laughter rather than self-related judgments or self-referential processing.

TIC>CSL modulated connectivity with regions implicated in auditory attention and evaluation relevant to inferring features of others' vocalizations; it concerns representing others' signals and thus perception/understanding of others.
Contrast (CAT>COU) contrasts explicit social evaluation (laughter type categorization) vs an implicit counting task; it directly manipulates and measures social processing.

The categorization task requires identifying laughter type but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship-related judgments; thus it does not meet criteria for affiliation/attachment.
CAT>COU isolates explicit evaluation of a nonverbal communicative signal (laughter type), addressing reception/interpretation aspects of social communication.
The contrast focuses on evaluation of others' vocalizations (external social stimuli) rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge.
Explicit categorization engages mentalizing and evaluative processes about others' social signals (intentions/affect), fitting perception and understanding of others.
Conjunction identifies regions commonly activated by all laughter types and tasks (explicit and implicit), reflecting core social-signal processing networks — thus measures social processing.
The conjunction shows common auditory and frontal activations to laughter generally but does not operationalize affiliation/attachment measures or contrasts.
Regions commonly activated across conditions (auditory cortex, IFG, SMA) reflect processing of nonverbal communicative signals (laughter), matching social communication criteria.
The conjunction represents perception of external laughter stimuli across tasks, not self-related processing.
Common activations likely subserve perception and interpretation of others' vocalizations and thus support understanding of others, meeting inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares imitation (IMI) vs control (CT) across observation and execution, directly probing social behavior (imitation of communicative gestures) and processing of social intent; thus it measures broad social processing.
The task contrasts imitation vs a motor/control discrimination task and does not probe affiliation, bonding, or attachment constructs (no cooperation, kinship, or relationship-based comparisons).

Imitation of communicative gestures and contrasts between IMI and CT directly assess nonverbal social communication (production and perception of gestures), meeting the social communication construct.

Although imitation can involve self/other processing, this specific contrast is a general task effect (IMI vs CT) across phases and is not designed to isolate self-referential processes or agency/self-knowledge.
The contrast targets neural systems engaged when observing and executing others' gestures (mirror and mentalizing systems), indexing perception and understanding of others' actions and intentions.

This interaction contrast isolates effects of social (S) vs non-social (NS) gesture content under imitation vs control during observation, directly probing social information processing and intention recognition.
The interaction addresses communicative intention and imitation but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition).

The contrast specifically tests how social (communicative) gestures modulate neural responses during imitation versus control, directly reflecting nonverbal social communication processes (reception/interpretation of gestures).

While the study discusses self-referential processes elsewhere (mOFC in other contrasts), this particular observation-phase interaction focuses on social vs non-social gesture processing during task selection and does not primarily isolate self-awareness or self-judgment processes.

The interaction tests sensitivity to communicative intentions in others' gestures (S vs NS) during observation with intent to imitate, directly indexing perception and inference about others' actions/intentions (mentalizing/action perception).

The Intention effect analyzes interns’ neural responses while they decide whether to recommend ideas—a social task involving processing of social information (intent to communicate/recommend). This directly measures social processing (self/other relevance in a social influence context).

The task does not probe attachment, bonding, or affiliation constructs (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition specific to attachment). It focuses on recommendation and persuasion rather than affiliation/attachment.

Interns explicitly evaluate and later communicate (videotaped recommendations) about show ideas; the intention contrast indexes communicative intent (production of non-facial/social information). This matches social communication constructs.

The Intention effect was associated with MPFC and precuneus/PCC and is explicitly tied to interns’ own intentions and self-relevant preferences (authors report high correlation between intentions and personal liking), indicating processes of self-perception and self-relevance.

The Intention effect primarily reflected self-relevance processing (MPFC/PC/PCC) and did not engage mentalizing regions for others; thus it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
The Salesperson effect examines individual differences in success persuading producers and correlates interns’ neural activity with social influence outcomes—clearly a social processing measure.
This analysis measures persuasive success/mentalizing rather than affiliation or attachment processes (no kinship, close-bond measures), so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

The Salesperson effect indexes interns’ ability to produce persuasive communication that aligns producers with their preferences (production aspect of social communication), matching the social_communication construct.

The salesperson analysis specifically identifies neural correlates (bilateral TPJ) linked to perspective-taking about others and success persuading them; it does not primarily index self-related processing.

The Salesperson effect was exclusively associated with bilateral TPJ, a canonical mentalizing region involved in representing others’ minds; this directly maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

The Buzz effect links interns’ neural responses during encoding to which ideas ultimately spread across producers—this is inherently social processing (how social information is valued and propagated).
The Buzz effect indexes successful propagation (reward and mentalizing) rather than attachment/affiliation measures; no affiliation-specific tasks or contrasts were used.
Buzz reflects the communicative success of ideas (how well ideas are transmitted and recommended onward), implicating production/reception aspects of social communication.

The Buzz effect was associated with ventral striatum and mentalizing regions and reflects the idea’s appeal and consideration of recipients, not primarily self-referential processing; intention/self measures were separate.
Buzz was associated with TPJ and DMPFC (mentalizing network), indicating representation and reasoning about others’ perspectives and interests—this fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast compares meaningful dyadic social interaction videos versus scrambled controls; task explicitly assesses social perception (naturalness of interactions). This directly measures broad social processing.
The task and contrast do not measure affiliation or attachment (no cooperation/kinship/ bonding measures); ratings target naturalness, not affiliation.
Stimuli are nonverbal communicative dyadic interactions and participants judge communicative plausibility; contrast isolates processing of social communication vs scrambled baseline.
No measures or contrasts probe self-related processing (agency, self-knowledge, or self-reflection); task asks about perceived naturalness of others' interactions.
Contrast involves perceiving and interpreting others' actions/animacy (dyadic interaction vs scrambled), matching Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception).
Contingent > Mirrored isolates neural processing of socially contingent interactions (dyadic social information) — core social processing.
Contrast manipulates contingency of movement, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
Contingency manipulation concerns communicative dynamics between agents (nonverbal social communication); contrast probes receptive non-facial communication and interaction dynamics.
Contrast targets perception of others' interaction contingency rather than self-related processes (no agency/self-judgment tasks).
Contingency vs mirrored directly taps action perception and animacy/inferential processing about others’ interactions (Perception of Others).
Mirrored > Contingent examines processing differences for noncontingent (symmetrical) social displays vs contingent ones; still a social perception contrast.
This contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment; it manipulates visual/contingency properties, not bonding.
Although this contrast emphasizes noncontingent/symmetric displays, it still involves processing of communicative nonverbal behavior and its reception.
No self-related judgments or measures are targeted by this contrast; it focuses on perceptual/interpretive processing of others.
Mirrored > Contingent reflects differences in perceiving others’ actions (symmetry, animacy, visual complexity), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Rigid > Smooth contrasts processing of nonbiological (rigid) vs biological (smooth) kinematics during dyadic social scenes — a social perception manipulation.
Kinematic manipulation addresses biological plausibility and inference about intentions, not affiliation/attachment metrics.
Manipulation of kinematics in communicative interactions affects reception and interpretation of nonverbal communication, thus probing social communication processes.
Contrast does not index self-related constructs (agency or self-knowledge); it addresses perception/inference about others’ motion.
Kinematic differences modulate inference about others' intentions and animacy, directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception/mental state inference).
The interaction (Contingent>Mirrored for Smooth>Rigid) specifically tests combined social factors (contingency and biological motion) in dyadic perception, a core social processing question.
This interaction addresses perceptual/inferential aspects of social interaction (contingency × kinematics), not affiliation/attachment measures.
Interaction examines how communicative dynamics (contingency) and kinematics affect reception of nonverbal communication — directly relevant to social communication.
Although discussion speculates about implicit self-reference for certain stimuli, the contrast does not directly measure self-related processing, so it is excluded.
The interaction probes how observers perceive and infer others' actions/intentions depending on contingency and motion type — central to Perception of Others.

This localizer contrast (form impression > remember order) explicitly isolates impression-formation processes about other people (photos + person info) and thus measures social processing.
The localizer tests impression formation versus a sequencing task; it does not measure affiliation, attachment, cooperation, or relationship bonding specifically.
The task requires reception and interpretation of person-related cues (photo + descriptive information), which fits receptive social communication (processing socially relevant information).
The contrast concerns impressions about others rather than self-related judgments or self-awareness.
Forming impressions from faces and descriptive information directly indexes perception and understanding of others' traits and states.
Remember-order > form-impression still uses person photos and person-related information; it is derived from a social task and thus indexes social processing even if emphasizing sequencing.
This contrast isolates sequencing/memory processes rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, cooperation, or bonding.
The remember-order condition emphasizes temporal sequencing/memory rather than reception or production of social communication; it does not target communicative exchange per se.
The contrast does not involve self-referential processing or judgments about the self.
Although it emphasizes sequencing, the stimuli are person-related (photos + info), so the contrast still engages perception/processing of others' information.
Dependent > independent contrasts outcome-dependency in impression formation about people the participant met; this directly probes social processing.

Outcome dependency manipulates interpersonal motivation and functional interdependence (akin to cooperation/relevant social bonds), aligning with affiliation/attachment constructs (attention and social learning toward partners).

Participants read socially-relevant teaching notes paired with faces (reception of non-facial social communication); the contrast examines processing of that social information under different dependency conditions.
This contrast targets impressions of others under different dependency states, not self-related processing.
The contrast evaluates how information about other people (expectancy-confirming/disconfirming) is processed depending on outcome dependency, directly indexing perception and understanding of others.
Independent > dependent is the reciprocal comparison of outcome-dependency effects during impression formation of real partners and therefore probes social processing.

Because this contrast reflects differences when participants are outcome-independent versus outcome-dependent, it targets interpersonal motivational context related to cooperation/dependency and thus affiliation-related processes.
The contrast examines processing of socially-relevant written and visual information (reception of non-facial communication) under differing dependency, fitting social communication inclusion.
The contrast concerns processing of others and does not index self-perception or self-knowledge.
Independent > dependent reflects changes in how information about other people is processed, directly relevant to perception and understanding of others.
Consistent > inconsistent contrasts expectancy-confirming versus -disconfirming information about known partners during impression formation, a core social processing manipulation.
This contrast tests expectancy-consistency effects on impression formation rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, or bonding per se.
The manipulation involves reception of socially-relevant textual information (teaching notes) about targets; processing confirmatory vs disconfirmatory cues fits receptive social communication.
This contrast addresses perception of others' behaviors and expectations, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
Differentiating consistent vs inconsistent person-related information is directly about perceiving and understanding others' traits and behaviors.
Inconsistent > consistent similarly manipulates expectancy-violation processing about other people during impression formation, indexing social processing.
This contrast deals with processing expectancy-disconfirming information, not affiliation/attachment constructs specifically.
Participants receive socially-relevant statements that disconfirm expectations; this is reception of non-facial social communication and fits the annotation.
The contrast targets perception and updating about others rather than self-related processes.
Processing expectancy-disconfirming information about targets directly reflects perception and understanding of others' traits/behaviors.
The dependence × consistency interaction in dmPFC tests how social dependency alters impression-formation processing of others — a central social processing question.

The interaction explicitly examines outcome dependency (interpersonal dependence/cooperation) effects on processing partners, which relates to affiliation and attachment processes (motivated attention toward partners).

The interaction reflects differential processing of socially-relevant communicative information (teaching notes and faces) as a function of dependency, fitting social communication (reception) criteria.
The contrast concerns how information about others is processed under different dependency states; it does not probe self-referential processes.
This interaction directly tests how perception and understanding of others (expectancy-confirmation vs -disconfirmation) are modulated by outcome dependency, squarely within perception-of-others.

Contrast and ROI are based on faces>objects and examine face-preferential activation (FFA) across children — directly measures social processing (face perception).
Task contrasts (faces vs objects) do not assess affiliation or attachment (no loved-one vs stranger or bonding paradigms).
Analysis probes reception of facial information (face-selective responses), which maps onto social communication (receptive facial communication).
No measures or contrasts assessing self-related processing or self-knowledge/agency are reported; this is a face-perception (other) task.
Face perception and face-preferential activations index representations of others' identity/emotional cues; directly measures perception/understanding of others.
Teens' right-hemisphere FFA analysis contrasts faces>objects — directly probes social face processing.
No task or contrast targets affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., loved-one vs stranger).
Examines reception of facial cues (face-selective activation) — fits social communication (receptive facial communication).
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing assessed in this analysis.
FFA responses to faces reflect perception/representation of others (identity/emotion) — meets criteria for perception of others.
Adults' right FFA ROI analysis contrasts faces>objects and assesses face-preferential/social processing.
Study does not manipulate or measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
Face perception measures (receptive facial information) support annotation for social communication.
No self-related tasks or contrasts present.
FFA activation to faces indexes perception/understanding of others (identity/emotion).
Left-hemisphere FFA ROI (children) derived from faces>objects contrast — measures face-related social processing.
No measures of attachment/affiliation in the task or contrasts.
Left FFA responses to faces reflect reception of facial communication cues; meets social communication criteria.
No self-perception or self-referential processing assessed.
Face>object activations index perception/understanding of others' faces (identity/emotion) — included.
Teens' left FFA analysis examines face-preferential activation (faces>objects), thus social processing is measured.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs.
Analysis targets reception of facial information (face-selective responses) — fits social communication.
No self-related measures are present in this analysis.
Left FFA face responses index perception/representation of others; included under perception_others.
Adults' left FFA ROI analysis contrasts faces>objects and therefore measures face-related social processing.
No experimental manipulation or contrast assesses affiliation/attachment.
Left FFA activity to faces reflects reception of facial cues and thus social communication.
No self-related processing or judgments measured in this analysis.
Face-preferential activation in left FFA measures perception/understanding of others' faces.

Whole-brain analysis of regions showing a positive relationship with age for face>object contrast evaluates developmental changes in face-related social processing. Even if few/no positive regions reported, the analysis itself targets social processing.
The contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no loved-one vs stranger).
The analysis inspects age-related modulation of face-preferential responses — relevant to reception of facial communication across development.
No self-related contrasts or tasks are evaluated in this whole-brain age analysis of faces>objects.
Analyzes developmental changes in neural responses to others' faces (identity/emotion), meeting perception_others criteria.
Whole-brain analysis of negative relationships to age in face>object contrast examines developmental changes in social face processing (extended network hyperactivation in children).
No measures of affiliation/attachment were employed; contrast does not address bonding or attachment.
Findings concern hyperactivation in extended face network to faces in children versus adults — directly related to reception of facial/social communicative cues.
This analysis does not probe self-related processing or self-knowledge.
Results characterize developmental differences in neural representation of others' faces (amygdala, temporal pole, etc.), satisfying perception_others.

The contrast isolates social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) versus emotional and cognitive controls, directly assessing social-evaluative processes on voices. This meets criteria for social processing.

Trustworthiness and attractiveness are social-evaluative constructs that influence affiliation and relationship choices (e.g., cooperation, mate selection); the task measures these judgments explicitly, satisfying affiliation/attachment relevance.

Participants evaluate vocal stimuli (reception of non-facial social communication, including prosody and social trait cues). The task is reception-based social communication, so it meets the construct.

The task asks participants to judge others’ traits/emotions from voices; it does not directly measure self-awareness, self-knowledge, or explicit self-related judgments. Although dmPFC involvement may reflect self-related integration, the contrast does not operationalize perception/understanding of self.
The contrasts explicitly measure perception and evaluation of others’ traits and emotional states (trustworthiness, attractiveness, happiness, age), directly matching this construct.
This conjunction identifies regions common to social (TR, AT) and emotional (HA) judgments versus AG, directly indexing social/evaluative processing of voices.

TR and AT judgments relate to affiliation-relevant evaluations and are included in this conjunction with HA; the analysis measures processes relevant to social bonding/affiliation (e.g., trust, attractiveness).
The conjunction highlights reception-related processing of vocal social cues (affective prosody and trait information), fitting reception of non-facial social communication.

The contrast compares judgments about others (social and emotional) to age judgments and does not operationalize self-related processing; any dmPFC involvement is inferred but not a direct measure of self-perception.
This analysis isolates brain regions engaged in perceiving and evaluating others’ emotional and trait information from voice, directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others.
This conjunction isolates regions shared by social trait (TR, AT) and cognitive (AG) judgments versus HA, capturing social-evaluative processing components related to trait inference from voices.

Although AG is a cognitive/control judgment, the conjunction still includes TR and AT (social evaluations linked to affiliation/selection), so the analysis probes affiliation-relevant social judgments.
The contrast again involves reception and evaluation of vocal social information (trait-related cues), corresponding to reception of non-facial social communication.
The analysis contrasts judgments about others’ traits and age against happiness and does not measure self-perception or self-knowledge directly; thus it does not meet perception_self inclusion.
This conjunction emphasizes neural correlates of judging others’ stable traits (trustworthiness, attractiveness, age) from voice, directly reflecting perception/understanding of others.

Contrast examines sad vs neutral across all three social-cognition conditions (empathy, ToM, self-reference); therefore it measures social processing broadly.
The task manipulations involve empathy, ToM, and self-reference about pictured individuals, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship bonding.
Analyses probe inference of feelings and mental states rather than exchange or production/reception of communicative signals; no explicit social-communication task.

The contrast pools the self-reference condition (SRS/SRN) with empathy and ToM, thus it includes processes related to perception/understanding of self (self-reference trials are part of the contrast).
The contrast includes empathy and ToM conditions (involving inference about others' emotions/mental states), so it measures perception and understanding of others.
Empathy sad>neutral directly probes social-cognitive processing (inferring others' emotions), so it is clearly social processing.
The empathy condition asks participants to imagine what a pictured person feels; it does not assess affiliation/attachment or relationship bonds.
Task involves emotion inference rather than communicative exchange or explicit reception/production of social signals.
This contrast isolates empathy (inferring others' feelings) and does not target self-related judgments or self-awareness processes.
Empathy condition requires representing and inferring another person's emotional state (Understanding Mental States), matching perception_others.
ToM sad>neutral examines social-cognitive inference (what would make the person feel better), thus is social processing.
The ToM manipulation probes reasoning about others' mental states and remedial actions, not affiliation or attachment measures.

Although ToM can involve inferring communicative intent, here the task asks what would make someone feel better rather than explicit communicative exchanges; does not match social_communication criteria.
This contrast isolates ToM (other-focused reasoning) and does not target self-related judgments.
ToM condition requires representing another person's mental states and intentions (Understanding Mental States), matching perception_others inclusion.
Self-reference sad>neutral is part of the social-cognition paradigm (imagining oneself in another's situation) and thus falls under social processing.
Self-reference probes one's own emotional reaction in a scenario, not affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding measures.
The self-reference condition involves internal self-simulation, not communicative behaviors or reception/production of social signals.
Self-reference condition explicitly asks participants to imagine how they would feel (self-awareness/self-related judgment), directly matching perception_self.
This contrast isolates self-referential processing (how I would feel) rather than representing others' mental states.
Empathy vs ToM contrast compares two social-cognitive processes (both involve inferring internal states), so it is within social processing.
Contrast compares empathy and ToM about pictured individuals, not affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding.
Neither condition explicitly targets communicative signal reception/production; the contrast assesses inference about feelings and remedial actions.
Both empathy and ToM conditions are other-focused; this contrast does not probe self-referential judgments.
Empathy and ToM both require representing others' emotional/mental states; the contrast isolates aspects of perception/understanding of others.
ToM > Empathy compares two social-cognitive processes and identifies regions preferentially engaged for ToM, so it is social processing.
Contrast targets ToM vs empathy about pictured individuals; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
Task emphasizes mental-state inference rather than communicative signal reception/production.
This contrast contrasts two other-focused conditions and does not target self-related judgments.
ToM and empathy involve understanding others' internal states; this contrast isolates differential processing of others' mental states.
Empathy > Self-reference contrasts other-focused with self-focused processing within the social-cognition paradigm, so it is social processing.
Contrast compares empathy and self-reference; neither condition operationalizes affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding.
Contrast centers on inferring feelings and self-perspective-taking rather than communicative exchanges.
Because this contrast directly pits empathy (other) against self-reference (self), it probes self-related processing and self–other differentiation.
The empathy arm of the contrast involves inferring another's feelings (understanding mental states), so perception_others is relevant.
Self-reference > Empathy contrasts self-focused versus other-focused social-cognitive processing and is therefore part of social processing.
The contrast compares self-reference and empathy; it does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation measures).
Contrast focuses on self-versus-other internal state inference rather than communicative signal production/reception.
Self-reference > Empathy emphasizes self-related judgments (imagining how I would feel), directly matching perception_self.
Because the contrast involves comparing self-reference to empathy, it also interrogates processing of others' states (empathy arm), so perception_others applies.

The analysis examines neural correlates of cooperative versus defect decisions in one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma games and compares prosocial vs proself individuals — a prototypical social task involving perception, interpretation, and response to social information (mentalizing, norm congruence). This directly measures social processing.

The contrast addresses cooperation and competition (cooperate vs defect) and how social value orientation (affiliation-like prosocial vs proself) and trust modulate cooperation — directly measuring affiliation/attachment-related processes.

The task involves interactive social decision-making (cooperation/competition) and inferring others’ intentions; examples in the annotation map explicitly list cooperation/competition as relevant tasks, so this analysis indexes social communication processes (receptive/inferential aspects).

Analyses and discussion explicitly reference self-referencing, agency, and precuneus activation related to self/third-person perspective taking; the contrasts probe processes of perceiving and reasoning about the self in social decisions.

The study focuses on mentalizing and inferring others’ intentions (TPJ, medial PFC, precuneus), i.e., understanding others’ mental states — matching perception/understanding of others inclusion criteria.
This analysis tests interaction of dispositional trust with social value orientation on neural activation during social decision-making (cooperation context) — clearly a social processing measure.

The interaction concerns how trust (an affiliation-related trait) modulates cooperation in PD across prosocial vs proself individuals — directly relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition task).

The analysis examines modulation of social cognition regions (TPJ, STG, medial frontal) by trust and SVO during cooperative/defect decisions, implicating processes of inferring and responding to social information (social communication).

Results and interpretation discuss self-referencing and agency (precuneus) and how trust affects engagement of these processes across SVO groups; thus the contrast probes perception/understanding of self in social contexts.
The interaction highlights activity in regions involved in understanding others’ intentions (TPJ, medial PFC, STG) as modulated by trust and SVO — matching perception/understanding of others.

Contrast (Partner > Unfamiliar) explicitly probes social processing: familiarity with a loved person, activation in extended face/social cognition network (PCC, pSTS). This directly measures social processing.

Partner versus matched unfamiliar face is a prototypical affiliation/attachment contrast (loved one vs stranger); the study specifically targets partner-related familiarity and emotional/attachment-related responses.

The contrast involves reception of facial information (recognition/familiarity) and retrieval of person knowledge/mental states (pSTS, PCC) — fits social communication (receptive facial communication).
The contrast targets perception/representation of another person (partner) rather than processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure self-related constructs.
Partner > Unfamiliar measures representations about another person's identity, familiarity, and inferred mental states (PCC, pSTS) — directly taps Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast (Child > Unfamiliar) probes social processing of a close/familiar other; activates extended face processing and person-knowledge systems relevant to social cognition.
Child is a close, attachment-related person; Child vs unfamiliar matches the affiliation/attachment construct (loved one vs stranger).
Contrast involves reception of facial cues and retrieval of person-related information (facial recognition, affective/person knowledge) — fits social communication (receptive facial communication).
This contrast concerns perception of another person (child) rather than self-related judgments or self-awareness, so it does not meet perception-self criteria.
Child > Unfamiliar measures knowledge and representations about another person (familiarity, episodic/person knowledge), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast (Friend > Unfamiliar) examines processing of a familiar social other and engages extended face/person knowledge networks, meeting broad social processing criteria.

Although the friend is described as less emotionally related than partner/child, Friend vs Unfamiliar still probes affiliation/attachment-related processing (familiar relationship vs stranger) and fits the construct.
The contrast relies on reception of facial information and retrieval of person-related information (facial familiarity), aligning with social communication (receptive facial communication).
The contrast addresses perception/representation of another person (friend), not self-related processes; it does not measure perception/self constructs.
Friend > Unfamiliar assesses representations about another person (familiarity, traits, possible mental states) and therefore fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis uses the ultimatum game (unfair–fair contrast) to probe strategic social decision-making, reputation building, cooperation, and theory-of-mind processes across age groups. This is a canonical social task and the contrast directly measures social processing associated with perceiving and responding to social offers, so both inclusion criteria are met.

The ultimatum game involves cooperation/competition and reputation-building between partners (human vs. computer) and the analyses examine behavioral and neural correlates of strategic interaction and acceptance rates over time, which map onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation). The unfair–fair contrast captures responses relevant to affiliation and social bonding strategies.

The task requires exchanging socially relevant information (offers), interpreting partner behavior and intentions, and adjusting responses—core elements of social communication. The contrast (unfair–fair) indexes processing of social signals and communication of social value, satisfying the inclusion criteria.

Although participants make decisions about accepting/rejecting offers, the primary focus of the analysis and contrast is on responses to others' offers, theory-of-mind, emotional and reward networks, and strategic interaction rather than explicit self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. The contrast does not directly measure Perception and Understanding of Self (no explicit self-evaluation or self-referential judgment), so I2 is not met.

The study explicitly examines understanding of others' intentions, perspective-taking, and theory-of-mind networks (TPJ, IFG), and compares neural responses to unfair vs fair offers from partners. This directly measures Perception and Understanding of Others (mental state attribution), meeting inclusion criteria.

The children>adults contrast in response to unfair vs fair offers examines social decision-making and the associated neural networks (AI, dACC, DLPFC), reflecting social processing across development. The task and contrast measure social processing directly.

This contrast addresses how children respond in cooperative/competitive interactions (ultimatum game) compared to adults, including reputation effects and acceptance behavior—core affiliation/attachment constructs. The unfair–fair contrast captures affiliation-related responses.

Children's neural responses to unfair offers reflect interpretation of partner behavior and communicative intent (mentalizing, perspective taking), which fall under social communication. The contrast measures processing of socially communicated offers.

The contrast highlights children's neural reactions to others' offers (norm violations, emotional reactivity) rather than explicit self-referential processes or judgments about the self. There is no direct measure of self-perception or agency in this contrast, so inclusion criteria for perception_self are not met.

The contrast examines neural correlates of perceiving and reacting to others' intentions and unfair behavior (theory-of-mind and mentalizing networks are discussed), so it directly measures Perception and Understanding of Others.

The adolescents>children contrast examines developmental changes in responses to unfair vs fair offers, probing social cognition (theory-of-mind, reward anticipation) and strategic social decision-making—squarely within social processing.

Adolescents' greater activation in nucleus accumbens, IFG and fusiform gyrus relative to children reflects maturation of reward anticipation and social-cognitive processes during cooperative/competitive interactions in the UG, mapping onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation and reputation). The contrast measures affiliation-related processes.

The contrast captures adolescents' enhanced processing of socially relevant offers and partner-related signals (mentalizing and face/social-signal processing regions), reflecting social communication processes (reception/interpretation of social cues).

This contrast focuses on adolescents' neural responses to others' offers and maturation of theory-of-mind and reward systems, not on explicit self-evaluation, agency, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the criterion for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The adolescents>children contrast explicitly targets regions associated with understanding others' intentions (mentalizing, TPJ/IFG) and reward responses to social interaction, directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.
