The analysis derives from a live social-interaction task (reciprocal imitation) that explicitly probes social cognition and role-switching; contrasts (imitating, being imitated vs observation) measure social processing. Meets criteria I1 (social task) and I2 (contrast measures social processing).

The task involves social interaction but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved vs stranger contrasts). Inclusion criterion I1 (must measure affiliation/attachment) is not met.

Reciprocal imitation and gesture exchange are direct forms of non-facial social communication (both production and reception of hand gestures); contrasts probe communicative exchanges. Meets I1 and I2 for social communication.

The task requires self-related processes (monitoring one’s own actions, agency, anticipating one’s role in interaction) and engages cortical midline structures discussed in the paper; contrasts probe self-related processing. Meets I1 and I2 for perception/understanding of self.

The study explicitly examines perception and understanding of others’ actions and intentions (action perception, mentalizing) via imitating and being imitated contrasts; thus it meets criteria for perception/understanding of others (includes action perception and mental state understanding). Meets I1 and I2.
Same dataset/contrast set probing live reciprocal imitation and social cognition (being imitated contrast directly measures social processing). Meets I1 and I2.
Being imitated is a social interaction but the analysis does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures); I1 not met.
Being imitated involves reception/production of hand gestures and communicative exchange; meets social communication I1 and I2.
Being imitated requires self-monitoring and agency-related processes (anticipation of role, monitoring of own actions), aligning with perception_self criteria I1 and I2.
Being imitated directly involves perceiving and understanding the partner’s actions and intentions (action perception, mentalizing); meets I1 and I2.
Observation of hand gestures in the interactive context still probes social perception and contrasts are used to index social processing; meets I1 and I2.
Passive observation does not test affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship comparisons); I1 not met.
Observation of gestures is reception of non-facial communication and is relevant to social communication; meets I1 and I2.
Even during observation, the paradigm involves self-other distinctions and processing relevant to agency/self-monitoring in the social context; meets I1 and I2 for self-perception.
Observation condition assesses perception of others’ actions and intentions (action perception), satisfying I1 and I2 for perception_others.
PPI analysis tests connectivity changes of mirror neuron seeds during imitating vs observation — directly probes social interaction processing and integration; meets I1 and I2.
Connectivity analyses focus on imitation-related integration, not measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding; I1 not met.
Imitating involves production/reception of communicative gestures and the PPI examines neural coupling during this exchange, meeting social communication criteria I1 and I2.
PPI examines seeds (IFG/IPL) coupling with medial frontal/self-related regions during imitation, implicating self-related processes (agency/monitoring); meets I1 and I2.
PPI results show coupling with mentalizing regions (understanding others’ intentions/action perception), directly addressing perception_others; meets I1 and I2.
PPI for Being Imitated vs observation probes social interaction dynamics and connectivity relevant to social processing; meets I1 and I2.
Although being imitated can relate to social rapport, the analysis does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs; I1 not met.
Being imitated is a communicative exchange of gestures; the connectivity analysis assesses neural correlates of this communication (I1 and I2 met).
Being imitated requires self-monitoring and may engage agency/self-related processing (medial structures reported); meets I1 and I2 for perception_self.
PPI shows coupling between mirror seeds and mentalizing regions during being imitated, addressing perception and understanding of others’ actions/intentions; meets I1 and I2.
Imitating-IPL PPI assesses social interaction-specific connectivity (imitation vs observation) and thus measures social processing; meets I1 and I2.
Connectivity of IPL during imitation examines action-understanding and integration, not affiliation/attachment constructs; I1 not met.
IPL involvement in action perception/execution during imitation pertains to production/reception of non-facial communication; meets I1 and I2.
IPL seed connectivity during imitation relates to self-other mapping and action planning (self-related processes/agency), fulfilling I1 and I2.
IPL connectivity with mentalizing regions during imitation addresses action perception and understanding others’ intentions; meets I1 and I2.
Being imitated-IPL PPI investigates connectivity changes during social exchange (being imitated vs observation) and thus measures social processing; meets I1 and I2.
Although social, the connectivity contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment (no relational/bonding measures), so I1 not met.
Being imitated engages communicative gesture exchange; IPL connectivity here reflects processing of communicative action (I1 and I2 met).
Connectivity of IPL during being imitated implicates self-monitoring and self-other distinctions (agency-related processing), satisfying I1 and I2.
This analysis examines coupling between mirror and mentalizing systems during being imitated, directly addressing perception of others’ actions and intentions; meets I1 and I2.

The analysis contrasts face versus house perception and links these neural measures (N170, fusiform activation) to quantitative social-cognition measures (EQ, SRS, SAT-MC). The task and reported correlations directly assess social processing and brain–behavior social cognition relationships.
The task and contrasts (faces vs houses, unfamiliar faces; social trait questionnaires) do not probe affiliation or attachment (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, or bonding paradigms).

Face perception and facial-feature processing (N170, fusiform activation) are core receptive components of social communication (affect/facial recognition). The analysis examines reception of facial communication and its relation to social measures, meeting the construct.

Analyses focus on perception of external social stimuli (faces, animacy) and associations with social trait measures; they do not assess self-related processes, self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.

The study explicitly probes perception and understanding of others via face processing (fusiform, N170) and the Social Attribution Task (animacy/intent inference). These map onto animacy perception and understanding others’ mental states.

The main effect of age group is derived from a task set that probes social evaluations (direct self, direct other, reflected self, malleability) across social/academic/physical domains. As such it measures social processing broadly across the sample.

The task included evaluations about a participant's named best friend and reflected perspectives from that close peer, tapping affiliation/peer attachment influences; the main effect of age group therefore concerns data from an affiliation-related task.

Although not a face/gesture communication task, the paradigm probes social evaluation and social comparison processes (including peer perspective-taking), which fall under broad social communication constructs used in the annotation guidelines.
The dataset includes direct and reflected self-evaluations; the main effect of age group reflects differences in self-processing across participants and thus meets the self-perception criterion.

The task includes direct evaluations of a close other (best friend) and reflected self-evaluations adopting the friend's perspective, so the main effect of age group draws on representations and reasoning about others.
The main effect of evaluative perspective contrasts direct self, direct other, reflected self, and malleability — all social evaluation conditions — and thus directly indexes social processing.
Evaluative perspectives include judging a best friend and taking the friend's perspective, directly engaging affiliation/attachment processes (peer influence, closeness).
Perspective-taking and social evaluation are forms of social information exchange and comparison; the evaluative perspective contrast taps these processes.
Direct and reflected self-evaluations are explicit measures of self-perception and self-knowledge, so this analysis measures perception of self.
Direct other-evaluations and reflected self-evaluations (from the friend's perspective) require representing and reasoning about another person, meeting the perception-of-others criterion.

The Age group × evaluative perspective interaction examines how developmental groups differ across the social evaluation perspectives (self/other/reflected/malleability), directly addressing social processing differences across ages.

This interaction tests whether age groups differ in how affiliation-related perspectives (e.g., best friend, reflected peer perspective) are processed, implicating attachment/peer influence mechanisms.
The contrast involves perspective-taking and social evaluative comparisons across ages, which are components of social communication (exchange/processing of socially relevant information).
Because the interaction includes direct and reflected self-evaluations and tests developmental modulation, it directly assesses self-perception processes across age groups.
The evaluative-perspective factor includes direct other-evaluations and adopting another's perspective; the interaction therefore indexes representation and understanding of others across age groups.

The main effect of domain (academic/physical/social) reflects differences in social evaluative content; the social domain condition and others are all part of the social evaluation paradigm, so this is social processing relevant.
One domain is explicitly social (popularity/etc.) and the study examines how peer-related evaluations vary by domain, implicating affiliation and attachment processes tied to the social domain.
Domain-based contrasts include social content and social comparison, which are elements of social communication per the annotation examples; thus this analysis is relevant to social communication.
Domains are applied to self- and other-evaluations; the domain main effect indexes differences in self-related judgments across academic/physical/social traits, meeting the self-perception criterion.
Because domains were evaluated for both self and a close other (best friend) and in reflected perspective, the domain effect informs perception/understanding of others as well as self.

The Age group × domain interaction assesses developmental differences in processing different evaluative domains (including social), drawing on the social evaluation task and thus on social processing.
This interaction can reveal whether age groups differ specifically in affiliation-relevant (social) domain processing (e.g., peer-related social traits), implicating attachment and peer influence.

Domain differences include social comparisons and evaluations, which are forms of social information processing/communication; the age × domain interaction therefore maps onto social communication constructs.
Because domains were applied to self-evaluations and this analysis tests age-related modulation of those domain-based self judgments, it meets the self-perception inclusion.
Domains were also applied to direct-other evaluations and reflected self (other's perspective), so age × domain tests differences in perceiving others across domains and is included.

The Evaluative perspective × domain interaction probes how perspective (self/other/reflected) and content domain (academic/physical/social) jointly shape social evaluations — core social processing constructs.

Because the interaction includes reflected/self/other perspectives applied to the social domain and uses a close peer target, it taps affiliation and attachment-relevant processing (peer influence, closeness).
Perspective-taking combined with social vs non-social domains involves social inferencing and comparison (forms of social communication), so this analysis is relevant to social communication.
The interaction includes direct and reflected self-evaluations across domains, directly measuring self-perception processes in relation to content domain and perspective.
Direct other-evaluations and reflected self from another's perspective are central to this interaction, reflecting processes of representing and reasoning about others across domains.

The three-way Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction reported in the paper (notably in bilateral ventral striatum) arises from the social evaluation task (direct/reflected/self/other across domains) and hence indexes social processing.

The significant three-way interaction specifically highlights adolescents’ increased ventral striatal response during reflected social self-evaluations from a best friend's perspective — a direct affiliation/peer attachment effect.

The interaction involves perspective-taking about peers and social-domain evaluations (social comparison/salience), processes that fall under social communication as defined by the annotation guidance.
The three-way interaction specifically differentiates reflected social self-evaluations (self-perception from another's perspective) and thus is directly a self-perception measure.

Because the effect depends on adopting the friend's perspective and direct other-evaluations, it necessarily involves representing and reasoning about another person and is therefore included under perception of others.

The contrast tests the parametric effect of number of bystanders on neural activity during witnessing an emergency; this is a social task probing social influence on helping behavior, meeting I1.

The study manipulates group size/bystander presence but does not assess affiliation, attachment, or social bonds (no measures of kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition specifically), so I1 for affiliation/attachment is not met.

The task does not target communicative exchange, facial/expressive reception or production, or other social communication constructs; stimuli are emergencies rather than communication-focused, so I1 is not met.
The contrast does not probe self-related processing, agency, or self-knowledge; it examines responses to others and group context, so I1 for self-perception is not met.

The analysis examines participants' neural responses to another person's emergency and the presence/number of bystanders, which is directly about perceiving and understanding others' states and actions (action perception/mental state inference), satisfying I1.
This contrast maps increases in activity with group size during viewing of social scenes (bystanders present) and thus assesses social processing broadly (influence of social context), meeting I1.

Although group presence is manipulated, the analysis does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding, kinship, or relationship-specific comparisons), therefore I1 is not met for this annotation.
The measured increases are in visual/attention regions and the task is not designed to probe communicative reception or production (faces blurred, no communicative exchanges), so I1 is not met.
This analysis contrasts variations in viewing others and does not involve self-related judgments or agency; thus it does not meet criteria for perception_self.

The contrast examines how the number of bystanders (others) modulates neural responses, directly relating to perception and understanding of others' presence and actions (action/animacy perception), satisfying I1.

Control > bystander contrasts visual complexity and presence/absence of bystanders in social scenes; it is a social-task contrast evaluating social context effects and thus meets I1 for social processing.
The control contrast addresses visual/control stimulus differences rather than affiliation or bonding; it does not measure attachment-related constructs, so I1 is not met.
This contrast isolates visual and complexity effects and is not aimed at communicative signals or facial/expressive communication; I1 for social_communication is not satisfied.
The contrast concerns perception of others/visual aspects rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge; it does not meet perception_self criteria.

Even though this contrast emphasizes visual/control differences, it contrasts scenes with and without bystanders and thus pertains to perception of others and their presence/behavior, meeting I1 for perception_others.
Falling > standing contrasts perception of an emergency (another person's distress) versus non-emergency; this is a social task about observing others in need and thus meets I1 for social processing.
The contrast compares an emergency versus standing but does not probe affiliation, attachment bonds, or relationship-specific variables; it does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.
The analysis targets responses to an emergency event rather than communicative signals (no exchange or facial communication focus), so it does not satisfy I1 for social_communication.
This contrast is about perceiving another person's state (falling) not self-related judgments or agency; it therefore does not meet perception_self criteria.

Comparing falling (emergency) to standing involves perceiving another's state and likely inferring need for help; this directly targets perception and understanding of others (animacy/action/mental state), satisfying I1.

Standing > falling is a contrast within socially relevant stimuli (same person standing vs falling); although reversed direction, it still probes social perception/context and thus meets I1 for social processing.
This contrast differentiates action states of another individual but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no bond/relationship measures), so I1 for affiliation_attachment is not met.

The contrast is not focused on communicative behavior or facial/exchange signals; it compares physical states of another person (standing vs falling), so it does not meet social_communication criteria.
The contrast concerns perception of another person's action/state rather than self-related cognition or agency, so perception_self criteria are not met.
Standing > falling contrasts how participants perceive another person's state and actions, which falls squarely within perception and understanding of others (animacy/action perception), meeting I1.

The localizer contrast (Self > Other) derives from a trait-judgment task comparing self vs President Obama — this is a canonical social processing task indexing self- vs other-related social cognition and thus qualifies as general social processing.
The localizer does not measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition, or bonding); it is a pure trait self/other judgment task unrelated to attachment constructs.
The task is trait judgment (self vs other) not a social communication task (reception/production of communicative signals), so it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.
The Self > Other contrast directly indexes perception and understanding of the self (self-referential processing) via explicit self-judgments, meeting the perception_self inclusion criteria.

Although the localizer includes an other condition (President Obama), the Self > Other contrast specifically emphasizes self-related processing; it does not primarily index perception/understanding of others.
The Other > Self localizer contrast comes from the same social trait-judgment task and therefore indexes social cognition broadly (processing about another person), so it meets social processing.
The localizer Other > Self contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding, cooperation, or competition.
This contrast reflects trait judgments about another person rather than communicative reception/production, so it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.
The Other > Self contrast emphasizes processing of another person rather than self-referential processing, so it does not meet the perception_self inclusion criteria.
Other > Self explicitly indexes processing of another person (President Obama) and thus meets the perception_others inclusion criteria for understanding others' traits/states.

The Communication > Moral contrast derives from the main experiment which is embedded in a social competitive context and involves processing socially relevant stimuli (remote-communication statements vs moral statements); this is social processing in the broad sense.

Although the overall experiment includes competition, this specific contrast isolates communication content (communication vs moral) and does not directly index affiliation/attachment measures (e.g., bonding, cooperation).

The Communication > Moral contrast specifically isolates remote-communication content, directly mapping onto social communication (reception of non-facial/communication-related stimuli), meeting the social_communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast collapses across self/other and isolates content type (communication), so it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self.
Because the contrast is about communication vs moral content and is collapsed across self/other, it does not specifically index perception or reasoning about others' mental states or traits.

The Moral > Communication contrast is from the main social-competition experiment and isolates processing of moral statements (socially relevant moral content) and thus falls under broad social processing.
This contrast isolates moral versus communication content and does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding or cooperation/competition outcomes.
The contrast focuses on moral content rather than communicative signals; it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.
Moral > Communication collapse is across self/other and therefore does not specifically index self-perception or self-referential processing on its own.
Similarly, because the contrast collapses across self/other and targets moral content broadly, it does not specifically measure perception or reasoning about others' mental states or traits.

The Self > Other contrast in the main experiment isolates self-referential processing within a social competitive task (first-person vs third-person statements), meeting the broad social processing definition.

Although the main experiment occurs in a competition context, the Self > Other contrast specifically measures self-referential processing (self vs other statements) rather than affiliation/attachment per se (no direct measures of bonding/cooperation).
This contrast indexes self- versus other-referential processing of statements rather than communicative reception/production, so it does not meet social communication criteria.

Self > Other directly measures self-referential processing (first-person vs third-person statements) in the main task and therefore meets the perception_self inclusion criteria (self-awareness/self-knowledge).
The contrast emphasizes self-related processing relative to others and does not primarily index perception/understanding of others, so perception_others is not included.
The Other > Self contrast in the main experiment indexes processing of third-person statements within the social competitive context and therefore qualifies as broad social processing.
This contrast isolates other-referential processing and does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation outcomes.
The contrast concerns self vs other referents for moral/communication statements rather than communicative exchange per se, so it does not meet the social_communication criteria.
Other > Self emphasizes processing of others (third-person statements) rather than self-referential processing, so perception_self is not appropriate.

Other > Self explicitly highlights processing of third-person statements (others) in the main experiment and therefore meets the perception_others inclusion criteria (understanding others' traits/states).

The study investigates facial color as a social cue used to infer emotion and health (social information). The task presents faces and tests responses in face-selective regions; this directly measures social processing of facial cues.

The task does not probe affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related judgments (no loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, or bonding measures). It focuses on facial color and emotion/health perception rather than affiliation/attachment.
The analysis examines reception of facial communication (facial color conveying emotion/health) and contrasts face conditions; this fits Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
The study does not involve self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it examines perception of other faces, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The experiment measures perception and assessment of others' emotional/health states via facial color, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast examines neural responses to social feedback (self vs other) in a face-to-face interaction paradigm — directly measures social processing (feedback reception, self/other evaluation).
Task involves social interaction, social comparison and conformity to peer feedback — processes central to affiliation/attachment motives (cooperation/competition and consensus).
Participants receive and process communicated feedback from peers (exchange of socially relevant information), so the contrast indexes social communication/reception.
The contrast is self > other feedback onset, directly indexing self-referential perception and self-related processing during feedback.
By contrasting self and other feedback, the analysis also measures perception/understanding of others (other-related feedback processing).
Contrast examines neural responses to other- vs self-feedback in a social feedback task; directly probes social information processing.
Processing feedback about others involves social comparison and relationship-relevant evaluation, fitting affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast indexes reception of communicated peer evaluations (other-related feedback), a form of social communication.
Although focused on other > self, the contrast is part of the self/other processing set and informs about self-related processing by comparison; thus included.
Directly measures neural processing of other-related feedback and understanding of others' traits (perception of others).
This interaction tests cultural modulation of social feedback processing (self vs other), directly within the social domain.
Interaction addresses cultural differences in conformity/relations to others during feedback — relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
Examines whether cultural group modulates processing of communicated peer feedback (self vs other), i.e., social communication differences.
Interaction tests culture × target effects specifically on self-related feedback processing (ACC/MPFC), directly relevant to self-perception.
Because the interaction contrasts self vs other across cultures, it also indexes perception/processing of others and cultural modulation thereof.
This whole-brain covariate links neural self>other feedback effects to behavioral updating (conformity), integrating neural and social-processing measures.
Behavioral updates index conformity/social comparison (affiliation-related), and the correlation with neural self>other activity addresses affiliation/attachment processes.
Correlates brain responses to received peer feedback (communicated information) with updating behavior — a social communication measure.
Contrast relates self-referential feedback responses to behavioral updating, directly measuring self-perception and its neural correlates.
Because the analysis uses the self>other contrast and relates it to updating, it informs how other-related processing and its relation to self influences behavior; thus included.
Parametric modulation of feedback ratings (self > other) indexes reward-related social feedback processing — clearly social.
Reward value of self-related social feedback and differential sensitivity to feedback from peers relates to social learning and affiliation processes.
This contrast captures the reception and neural encoding of socially communicated evaluative feedback (self-specific), a form of social communication.
Feedback-rating parametric effect for self directly indexes self-relevant valuation and self-perception processes.
The contrast is defined relative to other feedback (self > other), so it involves comparison to other-related processing and thus is informative about perception of others.
Parametric correlation with feedback discrepancies (self and other) indexes social comparison processes (how feedback differs from self-view) — core social processing.
Feedback discrepancy reflects social comparison and conformity dynamics relevant to affiliation/attachment and social learning.
This analysis captures reception and processing of peer-provided comparative information — a communicative social exchange.
Feedback discrepancies for self measure how external feedback updates self-knowledge — a direct self-perception measure.
Feedback discrepancies for other measure processing and understanding of others' trait evaluations — directly relevant to perception of others.
Negative correlation with feedback discrepancies still indexes social comparison processes (sensitivity to closeness of feedback to self/other) — part of social processing.
Patterns of decreased activity with larger discrepancies may relate to social comparison and affiliative evaluation processes.
Captures neural response patterns to communicated peer feedback (inverse relationship to discrepancy), thus within social communication.
Negative correlation with discrepancy for self and other constrains how self-knowledge representations respond to feedback closeness — relevant to perception of self.
Also informs how representations of others' traits respond to feedback closeness (inverse relationship), thus included.

Contrast a1>n1 compares reactive–aggressive vs neutral social interactions presented from a first-person perspective; task probes social processing broadly (perception, appraisal, response preparation).
This contrast isolates reactive–aggressive > neutral (threat/provocation) and does not probe positive affiliation/attachment processes; it does not measure affiliation/attachment.
Participants view interpersonal interactions (gestures, body language) and the contrast assesses neural responses to communicative social cues; task measures social communication.

Videos are shown from a first-person perspective and participants were instructed to put themselves in the observer’s role — the contrast probes self-related processing (agency/own-response preparation).
Contrast involves perception and evaluation of another person’s aggressive actions (others’ intent/behavior); it measures perception/understanding of others.
Contrast p1>n1 compares social-positive vs neutral interactions (first-person videos); clearly probes social processing across perception, emotion, and response tendencies.
Social-positive > neutral directly targets positive interpersonal interactions (affiliation, friendly behavior), meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
Social-positive interactions convey communicative cues (offers of handshake, friendly gestures); the contrast measures reception of social communication.
First-person perspective and instruction to empathize implicate self-related processing (putting oneself into scenario) for this contrast as well.
Contrast involves perceiving others’ friendly actions and intentions; it measures perception/understanding of others’ behavior.
Conjunction of reactive–aggressive and social-positive vs neutral identifies common social-processing networks engaged by affective interactions; clearly social.
The conjunction includes the social-positive condition (affiliation) and thus identifies activations common to affiliation-related processing; it therefore relates to affiliation processes.
Conjoined activations arise from viewing interpersonal communicative actions in both affective conditions; the analysis indexes social communication processing.
Both conditions were presented from a first-person perspective and required empathic engagement; the conjunction captures self-related engagement common to both.
Conjunction reflects shared processing of others’ actions/intent across affective interactions, meeting the perception-of-others construct.
Contrast D (a2>n2) compares final-phase reactive–aggressive vs neutral interactions; still a social task probing processing of affective interactions in time-extended stimuli.
Final-phase reactive–aggressive > neutral emphasizes threat/aversion and inhibitory control rather than positive affiliation; it does not measure affiliation/attachment.
Final-phase videos contain communicative bodily cues and enacted responses; this contrast addresses social communicative content in interactions.
The final-phase shows the observer’s (implied) response and participants still adopted first-person perspective, implicating self-related processing (agency, response evaluation).
Final-phase contrasts require assessment of the other actor’s behavior/outcome (intent, threat), indexing perception and understanding of others.
Contrast E (p2>n2) compares final-phase social-positive vs neutral interactions; probes social processing of affiliative outcomes and responses.
Final-phase social-positive > neutral specifically targets positive affiliative interactions and thus meets the affiliation/attachment criterion.
Final-phase social-positive clips include communicative acts (friendly responses) and the contrast assesses processing of such communicative content.
Participants’ empathic immersion and first-person perspective extend to the final phase, implicating self-related processing (own-response representation).
Final-phase social-positive > neutral requires understanding the other actor’s friendly intentions and actions; it measures perception of others.
Conjunction D & E identifies common final-phase activations across affective vs neutral interactions; these reflect shared social processing components.
The conjunction includes the social-positive final-phase condition and thus captures activations overlapping with affiliation processes; it is relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Shared final-phase activations arise from communicative elements present across affective interactions; the analysis addresses social communication processing.
Final-phase conjunction reflects common self-perspective engagement (empathic immersion, implied action) across affective interactions.
Common activations reflect processing of others’ actions/outcomes across affective final phases, indexing perception/understanding of others.
Analysis A (initial phase) presents reactive–aggressive initial-phase social videos vs neutral — a social task probing appraisal and response preparation; meets social processing criterion.
Initial-phase reactive vs neutral focuses on threat/provocation and not positive affiliation; it does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Initial-phase first-person perspective and instruction to empathize implicate self-related processing (placing oneself in scenario).
Initial-phase contrast evaluates perception of the other’s aggressive acts/intent — fits perception-of-others construct.
Analysis B (initial phase) contrasts social-positive initial-phase vs neutral — clearly probes social processing (positive interactions).
Initial social-positive vs neutral targets affiliative/social bonding cues (friendly gestures), meeting affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
Initial-phase social-positive clips include communicative gestures (offers, greetings); analysis measures social communication reception.
First-person perspective and instruction to empathize apply to initial-phase social-positive stimuli, implicating self-related processing.
Initial social-positive vs neutral requires perceiving others’ friendly intent and actions — measures perception/understanding of others.
Analysis C (final phase) examines final-phase social interaction videos vs baseline (task-wide); final-phase scenes remain social and affective, probing social processing.
Final-phase clips include social-positive outcomes in the experiment and thus this analysis can index affiliation-related processing (positive interaction outcomes).
Final-phase sequences contain communicative/responsive behavior (approach/withdraw, handshake, push-back) and the analysis captures social communication components.
Final-phase videos present implied participant actions and continued first-person immersion, engaging self-related representations (agency, response).
Final-phase contrasts require evaluating others’ actions and consequences (intent/outcome), indexing perception and understanding of others.
Analysis D (final phase) contrasts reactive final-phase vs neutral; final-phase stimuli are social and engage appraisal/response processes — meets social processing.

Final-phase reactive clips include communicative and action cues from the other and implied responses; analysis reflects social communication processing.

The contrast compares atypical (incongruent) vs typical social interactions using point-light displays of two agents. Although the overt task was orthogonal, the stimuli and contrasts explicitly probe social processing (perception/interpretation of others’ interactions).

The experiment does not measure affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition paradigms). It probes perception of interaction congruency rather than affiliation/attachment constructs.

The task involves perception of nonverbal social cues (biological motion of two agents) and interpretation of their interaction, which falls under receptive aspects of social communication (reception of non-facial communication). The contrast probes communicative/social information exchange between agents as perceived by observers.
The study does not assess self-related processing, agency, or self-knowledge. Participants performed a task orthogonal to the social meaning and no contrasts target self-perception.

The analysis targets perception and understanding of others: animacy/action perception (point-light biological motion of agents) and higher-level interpretation of others’ intentions/interaction congruency (third‑person perspective), matching this construct’s subcomponents.

Same contrast (atypical vs typical interactions) using a subset-split approach still probes social processing of observed interactions. Results and ROI analyses focus on social interpretation and precuneus involvement.

The subset analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding, cooperation, or related scales). It focuses on detecting incongruency in observed interactions rather than attachment.
Subset analysis still examines reception of nonverbal social cues (biological motion and interaction congruency), consistent with receptive social communication processing.
The subset analysis does not involve self-related judgments or agency measures; it remains focused on third‑person perception of others.
The subset analysis targets action perception/animacy and understanding of others’ interactions (third‑person perspective), consistent with perception_of_others construct and its subcomponents.

The conjunction analysis tests brain activity common to triad, self, and other conditions, all of which are social/mentalizing tasks (triadic interaction, self- and other-referential processing). Therefore it measures broad social processing.

The tasks do not assess affiliation or attachment specifically (no measures of close relationships, cooperation/competition framing, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). The triad condition asks about imagining interactions but not affiliation per se.

Although triad trials involve imagined interaction, the conjunction isolates overlap across triad, self, and other conditions and does not specifically index exchange of communicative signals (facial/non-facial communication) or communicative behavior; thus the conjunction is not a specific social-communication contrast.
The conjunction includes the self condition (self-referential judgments) and therefore reflects processes relevant to perception/understanding of self present in the data.

The conjunction includes other-referential and triad trials that involve representing another person’s relation to objects; thus it captures aspects of perceiving/understanding others (mentalizing, action/animacy representation).
The contrast isolates triadic interaction processing (triad > self & other), a social interaction task engaging mentalizing and action-understanding systems—therefore it indexes social processing.
The triad contrast probes imagining a social interaction but does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, close relationships, cooperation vs competition explicitly).

Triadic trials require imagining coordinated interaction and joint attention/coordination with another agent, which maps onto social-communication constructs (exchange/coordination aspects); thus this contrast indexes social-communication processes.
This contrast specifically highlights triadic interaction relative to self- and other-trials and therefore does not primarily measure self-referential processing.
Triad trials require representing another agent’s role/actions (action understanding, joint attention), so the contrast taps perception/understanding of others (mentalizing/action perception).
The Self > (Other & Triad) contrast isolates self-referential processing, which is a core component of social cognition and thus counts as social processing per I1.
The self contrast targets self-relevance judgments and memory effects; it does not measure affiliation or attachment (no relationship/bond measures).
Self-referential judgments do not probe exchange of communicative signals or production/reception of social communication; thus this contrast does not index social-communication.
This contrast explicitly isolates self-referential processing (self > other & triad) and therefore directly measures perception/understanding of self (self-knowledge/agency).
The contrast isolates self-related activity relative to other- and triad-conditions, so it does not index perception/understanding of others.
The Other > (Self & Triad) contrast isolates other-referential mentalizing (thinking about Angela Merkel), which is a form of social processing and meets I1.
The other-referential contrast assesses theory-of-mind about a public figure, not affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding measures, so it does not meet affiliation criteria.

Other-referential judgments here index mentalizing about another person's relevance to an object, not communicative exchange or production/reception of social signals; thus it is not a social-communication contrast.
This contrast isolates other-related processing relative to self and triad, so it does not measure self-perception/understanding.

The contrast explicitly targets judgments about another person's self-relevance to objects and recruits right TPJ/PCC—classical areas for understanding others’ mental states—so it directly measures perception/understanding of others.

The angry > neutral contrast tests neural responses to angry vs. neutral facial expressions presented in an interactive social (competitive) task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm). This directly measures social processing (perception of others and social interaction).

The task is a competitive social interaction (TAP) that probes social behavior in the context of interpersonal competition/provocation, which falls under affiliation/attachment-related constructs (competition/cooperation). The contrast measures responses to socially relevant cues within that interaction.
The contrast isolates responses to facial expressions (angry vs. neutral), i.e. reception of facial communication, which is a core social-communication process.

The contrast examines perception of the opponent's facial expressions and related neural responses; it does not probe self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about one's own traits/states. Thus it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.
The contrast directly measures perception and interpretation of another person's emotional state (angry vs neutral expression) within an interaction, meeting the Perception/Others criteria.

This angry > neutral contrast (likely another phase/contrast in the same TAP) probes social information processing in an interactive context (responses to opponent's facial expressions), so it measures social processing.

The contrast occurs within a competitive interpersonal task (TAP) probing social interaction and responding to provocation, which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (competition/cooperation).
The contrast isolates neural responses to facial expressions (reception of facial communication) within a social interaction, meeting the social communication inclusion criteria.

The analysis focuses on perception of the opponent and reactive behavior; it does not involve explicit measures of self-knowledge, agency judgments, or introspective self-processing required for Perception/Self.
The contrast targets perception and interpretation of another person's emotional expression in a social context (angry vs neutral), directly addressing Perception/Others.

The parametric modulation (angry > neutral) links trial-by-trial variations in participants' punitive selections (social behavior) to neural responses to the opponent's expressions—this directly probes social processing in an interactive context.

Parametric modulation examines how social competitive behavior (punishment choices in TAP) relates to neural responses; this pertains to competition/cooperation aspects of affiliation/attachment constructs.
The modulation is driven by responses to facial expressions (reception) and how they influence communicative/social decisions (punishment selection), fitting the social communication construct.

Although the analysis relates neural responses to the subject's behavior, it does not directly measure self-awareness, agency judgments, or self-knowledge; it focuses on social-reactive behavior and perception of others rather than explicit self-perception.

The parametric effect evaluates how neural representations of another's emotional expression relate to the subject's behavior, i.e. perception and understanding of others' emotional states, meeting Perception/Others criteria.

The analysis tests how pre-formed impressions (mind-holderness) modulate activity in canonical social brain regions (mPFC, TPJ, PCC, temporal pole) during a social competitive game—clearly a social processing task.

The task is a competitive social interaction (matching-pennies) and the analysis examines modulation of brain regions by interpersonal impressions formed during short social interactions—this fits the affiliation/attachment domain (competition/cooperation example given in I1).

Participants exchanged brief conversational/behavioral cues with opponents and then engaged in a socially relevant interactive task; the analysis addresses neural responses to those social interactions/communications (competition), consistent with the social communication inclusion examples.

The focus of the analysis is on perception and mentalizing about others (mind-holderness) and modulation of social brain regions by impressions of opponents; it does not directly measure self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge).

The analysis directly targets representations and inference about others' minds (mind-holderness), using questionnaires and neural modulation in theory-of-mind regions—this matches Perception and Understanding of Others (Understanding Mental States).

The analysis examines how perceived mind-readerness (impressions that an opponent can infer the participant's strategy) modulates activity in social brain regions (ventral TPJ, temporal pole) during an interpersonal competitive task—clearly social processing.

Although competitive rather than affiliative, the task is an interpersonal interaction (competition) and the analysis probes how impressions from prior social interactions modulate neural responses—competition is an example within the affiliation/attachment domain per I1.

The analysis concerns neural processing following brief social exchanges and during interactive gameplay where social information (opponent identity/intent) is exchanged or inferred, aligning with social communication constructs.
This analysis centers on inferences about opponents’ capacities (mind-readerness) and associated neural modulations; it does not index self-focused judgments or agency/self-knowledge measures.

Mind-readerness is explicitly about attributing capacities to others (their ability to read the participant), and the analysis identifies modulation in regions implicated in understanding others—meeting the Understanding Mental States subconstruct.

The interaction contrast tests neural responses during impression formation of faces varying by social status dimension (moral vs financial) and level (lower/same/higher). This is clearly a social-related task assessing social processing.

The task involves social comparison and judgments about likeability/similarity that relate to affiliation and bonding; the interaction assesses how status dimension and level influence evaluations that bear on affiliation/attachment.
The analysis involves perception and evaluation of faces (receptive facial communication) and spontaneous person evaluation, fitting within social communication measures.

The paradigm includes social comparison relative to the participant (targets labeled as lower/same/higher than the participant) and post-scan similarity ratings; the interaction likely engages self-referential/social-comparison processes.
The contrast directly examines neural representations of others varying in moral and financial status, i.e., perception and understanding of others' traits and value.
The Status Type main effect (financial vs moral) probes social-dimension information processing during impression formation of others, constituting social processing.
Differences between moral and financial status influence affiliative evaluations (likeability) and social judgments, mapping onto affiliation/attachment processes.
Status Type comparisons operate on face-based social cues and person knowledge, implicating reception of facial/social information consistent with social communication.

Although focused on target attributes, Status Type contrasts may engage self-referential processing via social comparison and subjective status manipulations (participants informed of their status), meeting the self-perception inclusion.
This contrast directly evaluates how different status dimensions of others (moral vs financial) are represented, fitting perception-understanding of others.
The Status Level main effect (lower/same/higher) concerns relative social status comparisons during impression formation and thus is a social processing measure.
Status level modulates likeability and perceived similarity (affiliative judgments), so this main effect taps affiliation/attachment-related processes (social comparison/cooperation-related).
Level-based contrasts operate on face presentations and evoke social-evaluative processing of facial stimuli, aligning with reception of facial communication within social communication.

Comparisons across lower/same/higher status necessarily involve social-comparison relative to self (same vs different), and post-scan similarity ratings indicate self-referential judgments; thus include.
This contrast indexes how others differing in status level are represented and evaluated (traits/likeability), directly measuring perception of others.

The CV>NV contrast compares campaign videos designed to elicit empathy (social-emotional responses, mentalising) versus neutral videos. This is a social task probing socio-cognitive and socio-emotional processing and neural substrates (STS) linked to understanding others. It therefore measures Social Processing.

The contrast probes empathy and understanding of victims rather than explicit measures of affiliation, bonding, attachment, cooperation, or kinship. The task does not operationalize attachment/affiliation constructs (no loved-one vs stranger, cooperation paradigms), so it does not meet criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

Stimuli depict social interactions and cues (actors, actions, expressions) and participants provided verbal descriptions; STS activation relates to social perception and communicative cues (gaze, biological motion, voice). The contrast therefore engages Social Communication (receptive processing of social signals).

The primary manipulation contrasts viewing campaign vs neutral videos to probe empathy for others; although some behavioral indices included self-referencing, the main neuroimaging contrast does not target processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Thus it does not meet the Perception/Self criteria.

The study explicitly tests perception and understanding of others’ mental and emotional states (empathic expression correlated with STS activation). The CV>NV contrast and behavioral measures target understanding others’ emotions and mental states, fulfilling the Perception/Others criteria.

The experiment examines cross-modal recognition of other people (voice-face matching/mismatching), a social-related task measuring processing of social identity information across modalities.

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonds, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation) but rather identity recognition; therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The study tests reception of socially relevant communicative signals (voices and faces) and how they are integrated for identity recognition, matching the social communication construct.
The analyses concern perception and recognition of other people (faces/voices), not self-related judgments or self-awareness, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The contrasts explicitly measure perception and representation of other persons' identities across modalities (voice→face predictions and mismatches), directly addressing perception/understanding of others.
The FFA analysis examines neural responses during cross-modal identity recognition of other people, a social processing task.
The contrast targets identity representation and mismatch signals, not affiliative or attachment-related processes (no loved-one/stranger or bonding measures).
FFA responses to voice-primed faces reflect reception and integration of communicative social cues (voice and face identity), fitting social communication.
Analyses concern recognition of other individuals rather than self-related cognition or judgments; does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The contrast measures neural representation and discrimination of others' identities across modalities (voice-face matching/mismatch), directly probing perception of others.
The aTL analysis tests identity-specific responses to voices and faces, addressing social processing of person identity across modalities.
The aTL contrasts index identity representations and mismatch signals, not measures of affiliation or attachment between individuals.
aTL activity reflects representation of communicative identity information (voices priming faces), consistent with reception of facial/auditory social cues in communication.
These analyses focus on perception of other persons' identities rather than self-related processing, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
aTL contrasts probe conceptual identity representations of other individuals across modalities (voice-driven face identity predictions and mismatches), fulfilling perception-of-others criteria.

The analysis used a biological-motion perception task (intact vs scrambled point-light displays) and correlated neural responses with social-network measures. This directly measures social processing (perception and decoding of social cues) and relates to social behavior.

The task and contrast do not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation). It used neutral biological-motion stimuli to probe social perception and related network diversity, not attachment/affiliation processes.

Biological-motion perception is a form of social communication (reception of non-facial communicative signals such as gestures and actions). The contrast (biological vs scrambled motion) measures reception of non-facial social communication and was used to relate neural responses to social-network measures.
The analysis does not probe self-perception, self-awareness, or judgments about the self. Stimuli and contrasts target perception of others' motion, not self-related processes.

The task assesses perception and understanding of others (action perception/animacy via point-light biological motion). The contrast isolates brain responses to others' actions and these responses were correlated with social-network characteristics, matching the construct.

Contrast HA>NE examines participants labeling briefly presented happy faces vs neutral masks — a social task probing recognition of others' emotional cues. This fits broad Social Processing.
The task measures recognition/labeling of facial emotion, not affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related processing (no loved-one/stranger or bonding manipulation).
HA>NE requires reception of facial communication (affective face recognition), matching the reception of facial communication subconstruct.
Contrast probes perception of others' emotions; it does not assess self-awareness, agency, or self-evaluative judgments.
HA>NE directly measures representations and recognition of others' emotional states (perception/understanding of others).
Contrast AN>NE examines labeling of angry faces vs neutral — a social emotion-recognition task tapping social processing.
No measures or contrasts related to affiliation/attachment (no relationship or bonding manipulation).
AN>NE involves reception and identification of facial expressions (receptive facial communication).
Task focuses on perceiving others' emotions; it does not probe self-related evaluation or agency.
AN>NE directly measures understanding and representation of others' emotional states (anger).
Contrast FE>NE examines labeling of fearful faces vs neutral — clearly a social perception/recognition task and part of Social Processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs or comparisons are present in this contrast.
FE>NE requires reception/interpretation of facial affect (receptive facial communication).
This contrast targets perception of others' fearful expressions, not self-perception or agency.
FE>NE assesses representation and recognition of others' emotional states (fear), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis tests correlations between brain responses to happy>neutral and TAS-20 total — linking social emotion perception to individual differences; it falls under Social Processing.
The correlation with alexithymia and happy-face response does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
Correlation probes reception of facial communication (emotion recognition) as modulated by TAS-20 total — relevant to Social Communication.
Analysis addresses brain responses to perceiving others' emotions and trait alexithymia; it does not probe self-knowledge or agency.
Relating TAS-20 to HA>NE responses indexes individual differences in perceiving/understanding others' emotions, meeting Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis examines correlations between AN>NE responses and TAS-20 total — a social emotion perception analysis addressing Social Processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts are present; the focus is emotion recognition and alexithymia.
AN>NE × TAS-20 addresses reception/identification of facial emotions as communicative signals — fits Social Communication (reception).
This regression targets perception of others' emotions and does not probe self-related processing.
Relates individual differences (alexithymia) to neural processing of others' angry expressions — directly about Perception/Understanding of Others.
Analysis links FE>NE neural responses to TAS-20 total, probing social emotion perception and individual differences — clearly Social Processing.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; the contrast is emotion perception related to alexithymia.
FE>NE × TAS-20 addresses reception of fearful facial communication and its modulation by alexithymia, matching Social Communication.
Focus remains on perceiving others' emotion signals; does not measure self-perception or agency.
This regression examines how alexithymia relates to neural representations of others' fear, directly mapping to Perception and Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF correlations with HA>NE reflect modulation of social emotion perception by a trait measure — thus Social Processing applies.
The analysis targets emotion recognition and alexithymia facet DDF, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
HA>NE × TAS-20-DDF involves reception/decoding of facial affect (receptive facial communication).
Analysis concerns processing of others' faces; it does not probe self-awareness or self-evaluative judgments.
Relating TAS-20-DDF to HA>NE measures individual differences in perceiving others' emotions — fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF correlations with AN>NE probe modulation of social emotion recognition (angry faces) — Social Processing applies.
No affiliation/attachment constructs are manipulated; the focus is emotion labeling/recognition.
AN>NE × TAS-20-DDF addresses reception/identification of facial signals (receptive facial communication).
This analysis concerns perceiving others' anger, not self-perception processes.
Examines how a facet of alexithymia relates to neural processing of others' angry expressions — directly Perception/Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF × FE>NE correlational analysis probes social emotion perception (fear) modulated by alexithymia facet — fits Social Processing.
No affiliation/attachment measures or contrasts are present in this analysis.
FE>NE × TAS-20-DDF targets reception/decoding of fearful facial expression signals (receptive facial communication).
Analysis involves others' emotional face perception, not self-related cognition.
Relates an alexithymia facet to neural responses to others' fearful faces — directly maps to Perception and Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with HA>NE probe modulation of social emotion labeling by an observer-rated alexithymia facet — falls under Social Processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs are involved; this is about emotion recognition and alexithymia.
HA>NE × TSIA-DDF assesses reception of facial affect and its modulation by an alexithymia interview score — relevant to Social Communication.
This analysis does not assess self-perception or self-knowledge; it concerns perceiving others' faces.
Relates observer-rated alexithymia to neural processing of others' happy faces — directly about Perception/Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with AN>NE probe modulation of anger-face processing by alexithymia interview scores — part of Social Processing.
No attachment/affiliation processes are manipulated or measured in this analysis.
AN>NE × TSIA-DDF concerns reception/decoding of angry facial expressions, aligning with Social Communication (reception).
Analysis focuses on perceiving others' emotions rather than self-related cognition.
Links interviewer-rated alexithymia to neural responses to others' angry faces — fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with FE>NE assess modulation of fearful-face perception by alexithymia interview scores — within Social Processing.
No measures of affiliation or attachment are present in this analysis.
FE>NE × TSIA-DDF probes reception and interpretation of fearful facial communication modulated by TSIA-DDF — matches Social Communication (reception).
This analysis addresses perception of others' fearful expressions and does not measure self-awareness or agency.
Relates TSIA-DDF to neural processing of others' fear expressions — directly about Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast compares processing of messages believed to be from a real-life friend vs a computer; this is a social task assessing how social context modulates neural processing, thus measures social processing.

Contrast directly compares friend (close other) versus computer (non-social agent), matching an affiliation/attachment-type contrast (loved/close other vs non-human), so it indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The task involves reception of short text messages (non-facial communication) and the contrast tests sender-dependent processing, so it falls under social communication (reception of non-facial communication).

The contrast addresses processing of messages from another (friend vs computer) and does not probe self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge, so it does not index perception/understanding of self.

The contrast targets neural responses when receiving messages attributed to another person (friend) versus a non-human source, engaging processes of representing/understanding others and mentalizing (the mentalizing network was activated).

Searchlight MVPA decodes affect-related message content (‘happy’ vs ‘sad’) during a social communication task; although cross-sender, it is embedded in a social communication paradigm and thus indexes social processing.

This analysis decodes message content (happy vs sad) independent of sender; it does not test affiliation/attachment or contrasts close vs stranger, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
The analysis addresses reception of non-facial social communication (text messages) and decodes socially relevant message content, fitting the social_communication construct.
The MVPA addresses decoding of message content and not self-related processing, so it does not index perception/understanding of the self.
Messages communicate the affective state of a (third) person and decoding ‘happy’ vs ‘sad’ pertains to representing others' emotional content; thus it relates to perception/understanding of others.
MVCA tests sender-dependent changes in information flow (friend vs computer) and links sensory encoding to the mentalizing network; this is a clear social-processing analysis.

The MVCA contrast examines differential coupling when messages are believed to come from a friend versus a computer (close other vs non-social agent), directly probing affiliation/attachment-related modulation.

This analysis explicitly addresses how socially transmitted message content is relayed to social-cognitive regions (reception of non-facial communication and its gating), fitting social_communication.
The MVCA examines interregional coupling related to processing others' messages and mentalizing; it does not probe self-related judgments or agency, so perception_self is not applicable.

MVCA links sensory content encoding to the dmPFC (mentalizing region) in a sender-dependent manner, reflecting representation and inference about others' states; thus it indexes perception/understanding of others.

Contrast isolates neural activity for responding to joint attention in an interactive social task (RJA vs matched non-social control). This directly measures social processing.
Task is cooperative (Catch the Burglar) requiring cooperation with an (apparent) partner; contrast isolates social cooperation-related processes beyond non-social control.
Responding to joint attention requires reception/production of gaze-based communication (gaze following, mutual gaze); contrast specifically targets gaze-mediated social communication.
RJA trials require representing one’s own attentional state and shifts in agency when following the avatar; authors discuss self-monitoring and agency (insula, precuneus).
RJA requires representing the avatar’s attention and intentionality (disambiguating guiding gaze), directly probing perception/understanding of others’ attentional states.
Contrast isolates initiating joint attention vs matched non-social control; it is a social interactive task measuring social processing.
IJA occurs within the cooperative game context where participants guide a partner to a shared goal, engaging affiliation/attachment-relevant cooperative behavior.
Initiating joint attention involves production of gaze-based communicative acts (guiding the partner’s attention); contrast directly measures gaze production and social communication.
IJA requires self-monitoring and planning of one’s own attentional actions (representing one’s own attention to guide the partner) and involves agency-related processing (ACC, SMA noted).
IJA also requires representing partner readiness and their subsequent attentional shift (monitoring partner’s gaze and intentionality), probing perception of others’ attentional states.
Conjunction identifies regions common to both initiating and responding joint attention; this explicitly indexes shared social processing.
Common network supports cooperative interactive behaviors in the task context, reflecting affiliation/attachment-relevant processes (shared goal coordination).
Conjunction highlights brain regions supporting gaze-based communication processes that are common to both producing and receiving communicative gaze cues.
Common network is interpreted as supporting simultaneous representation of self-attentional perspective (self-monitoring, precuneus involvement), satisfying perception_self criteria.
Conjunction includes TPJ, pSTS and other regions implicated in representing others’ attention/mental states, directly meeting perception_others criteria.
This contrast compares initiating over and above responding (both social) controlling for non-social demands; it isolates differential social processing and thus meets social_processing_all.

IJA>RJA engages additional cooperative/goal-directed social coordination processes in the cooperative task context (more recruitment of shared network during initiating), fitting affiliation/attachment inclusion.
Contrast isolates neural activity specifically related to producing communicative gaze (IJA) relative to receiving it (RJA), thus indexing social communication production processes.
IJA>RJA shows greater activation in regions tied to self-monitoring and motor planning (SMA, precuneus), reflecting enhanced self-related attentional control and agency.
IJA>RJA also shows amplified recruitment of regions implicated in representing others’ attention/intentions (rTPJ, IFG), so perception_others is relevant to this contrast.

The contrast IC>NG examines gesture presence during a face-to-face communication task where participants judged whether they felt addressed. This is a social task probing processing of social cues and engagement, satisfying Social Processing.

The task examines feeling addressed and gesture/orientation effects but does not probe affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation/loved-one contrasts). Thus it does not meet criteria for Affiliation/Attachment.

IC>NG directly manipulates co-speech gesture (a communicative signal) during spoken sentences and the task requires judgments about being addressed — a core social communication measure (reception of non-facial communication).

Although primarily a gesture vs. no-gesture contrast, the behavioral task required subjects to report whether they felt addressed (self-related judgment) on every trial. Therefore the contrast reflects processes tied to self-perception/self-involvement.
IC>NG probes perception of another person's communicative behavior (gesture), engaging action/animacy and mentalizing networks; thus it indexes perception/understanding of others.
The ego>allo contrast manipulates actor orientation (egocentric vs allocentric) during a social addressment task, directly measuring social processing and self-involvement.
Actor orientation manipulates perceived addressment/self-involvement but does not assess affiliation, bonding, or attachment constructs, so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Egocentric vs allocentric orientation alters communicative intent and addressment; this is directly within Social Communication (reception of non-facial and contextual communicative cues).

Egocentric orientation increases feelings of being addressed and recruits self-referential/mentalizing processes (ACC, SMA) — the contrast indexes perception/understanding of self-involvement in interaction.
Differentiating actor perspectives requires representing the other's orientation and intentions (mentalizing/action perception), so the contrast also indexes perception and understanding of others.
The allo>ego contrast similarly manipulates social orientation and addresses how allocentric presentation affects social processing, meeting Social Processing criteria.
Allocentric>egocentric contrasts reflect perspective and addressment but do not measure affiliation/attachment (no bonding/cooperation measures), so excluded.
Allocentric vs egocentric orientation changes communicative relevance and how speech/gesture are interpreted — a Social Communication construct (reception of communicative cues).
Although allocentric conditions are rated as less addressing, the contrast still reflects participants' self-related evaluations of addressment and thus relates to perception of self-involvement.

Allocentric presentation requires representing the speaker's orientation toward others and interpreting their communicative intent — indexing perception/understanding of others (mentalizing/action perception).
This interaction ((IC-ego>IC-allo)>(NG-ego>NG-allo)) probes how gesture modulates egocentric addressment and neural correlates of feeling addressed — clearly social processing.
The interaction targets addressment and mentalizing related to gesture and orientation, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding/cooperation), so excluded.
The contrast examines how co-speech gestures interact with body orientation to affect perceived addressment — central to Social Communication (reception/integration of non-facial communicative cues).

This interaction identifies ACC and fusiform responses that correlate with individual addressment ratings (IC-ego>IC-allo), directly indexing self-related perception (feeling addressed) and self-involvement.

Interpreting gestures in different orientations requires representing the other's communicative intent and actions; the contrast engages mentalizing and action perception systems relevant to perception of others.
This interaction ((IC-allo>NG-allo)>(IC-ego>NG-ego)) tests how gesture effects differ by perspective, relating to social processing of communicative cues and addressment judgments.
The contrast probes gesture-by-orientation effects on addressment and neural correlates (SMA, IFG, insula) but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so excluded.
The interaction isolates gesture-related modulation of communicative intent depending on perspective — a Social Communication measure (integration/reception of non-facial cues).

Correlations between gesture-related BOLD changes and addressment ratings in the egocentric context (IC>NG) indicate this contrast reflects self-related perception (feeling addressed) and self-involvement.
The contrast engages SMA, IFG and insula linked to action understanding and empathy, reflecting representation of others' communicative actions and intentions — perception/understanding of others.
