Localizer identifies face- and body-selective ROIs used in the social perception experiment; part of study of person perception and social scene processing, so it measures social processing broadly.
The localizer and ROI coordinate table do not measure affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, or cooperation/competition).
Localizer contrasts include faces and bodies (receptive aspects of facial/body communication), which are core receptive social communication processes used in the main experiment.
The analysis concerns localization of perceptual areas for faces and bodies, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
The localizer identifies regions selective for perceiving others' faces and bodies, directly indexing perception/representation of others (animacy/action perception).
Contrast compares congruent vs incongruent person interactions (types of social scenes) during sex-categorization task; clearly a social processing contrast.
Contrast manipulates interaction meaningfulness but does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition).
Comparing types of dyadic interactions involves reception of facial/body cues and gaze/posture relationships—receptive social communication processes are engaged.
Contrast addresses perception of others and scene relations, not self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge.
Contrast probes how observers encode and represent other people and their relations (action/animacy perception and understanding others' interactions).
Incongruent > congruent contrast examines neural processing of social interaction incongruency; part of social scene processing.
The contrast targets incongruency/meaningfulness but does not measure affiliation or attachment per inclusion criteria.
Processing of incongruent dyads engages reception of facial/body cues and implied communicative signals; thus fits social communication.
This contrast concerns perception of others and scene relations rather than self-related processing.
Directly measures how observers perceive and represent other people and their actions/relations (action perception/understanding mental states).
Congruent interactions > non-interactions contrast compares different social scene types and their processing; clearly social processing.
Although congruent interactions are more meaningful, the task/contrast does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment constructs.
Contrast contrasts dyads with mutual facing/interaction vs non-facing dyads—engages receptive social communication cues like gaze/posture.
Contrast concerns perception of others and their relations, not self-perception or self-knowledge processes.
Directly examines how others are perceived in different relational configurations (animacy/action perception and understanding others).
Non-interactions > congruent interactions is a contrast between social scene types and thus measures social processing.
No measures of affiliation/attachment (bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger) are present in this contrast.
Contrast involves perception of dyadic orientation and implied communicative relations (gaze/posture), engaging social communication processing.
This contrast does not probe self-related processes or self-reflection; it concerns perception of others and scene structure.
Directly targets representation of other people and their relational configurations (action/animacy perception).
Incongruent > non-interactions examines neural processing of different social dyad types—falls squarely under social processing.
Although semantic meaningfulness is manipulated, the contrast does not specifically index affiliation or attachment constructs.
Contrast differentiates dyads with differing communicative coherence (incongruent vs non-facing), engaging receptive social communication mechanisms.
Analysis focuses on perception of other agents and scene relations, not on self-perception or agency judgments.
Contrast assesses how observers perceive and represent other people's actions and relations; fits perception of others.
Non-interactions > incongruent interactions compares different social scene types; part of broader social processing analyses.
The contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no direct measures of bonding, kinship, or attachment).
Differentiates dyads based on facing/interaction coherence and thus engages reception of social communicative cues (gaze/posture).
This contrast concerns perception of other agents and their relations, not self-related processes.
Directly addresses representation and perception of others (action/animacy perception) across dyad types.

Contrast compares responses to fearful vs happy/neutral crowds using dynamic social stimuli and tests neural correlates of crowd emotion and interaction — clearly a social processing task measuring social perception and processing.
The contrast examines emotional crowd perception (fearful vs others) and interaction dynamics but does not probe affiliation, bonding, kinship, cooperation or attachment-specific processes.
Stimuli are dynamic bodily expressions in crowds conveying affective/social signals (nonverbal communication); the contrast assesses reception of social communicative cues.
This contrast focuses on perception of others' emotions and group dynamics, not on self-awareness, agency, or self-related judgments.
Directly assesses perception and understanding of others' emotional states and group behaviors (action/animacy perception), matching this construct.
Contrast examines combined fearful+happy vs neutral crowd stimuli — a social task probing processing of group-emotional information.
Contrast does not specifically test affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, cooperation); it contrasts emotion vs neutral group displays.
Emotional body and group dynamics convey social communicative signals; this contrast probes reception of such cues.
No measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge are assessed in this contrast.
Contrast measures how observers perceive others' emotions and group behavior versus neutral crowds, fitting perception-of-others.
Contrast (fear+neutral > happy) involves social-emotional crowd perception and thus measures social processing networks.
Contrast distinguishes emotion types but does not probe affiliation or attachment-related constructs explicitly.
Contrasts emotional displays that convey socially relevant information via body movements; assesses reception of nonverbal social signals.
No self-related judgments or agency measures are involved in this contrast.
Directly probes observers' perception of others' emotions and actions in crowds (action/animacy perception).
Happy>fear+neutral contrast assesses social processing of joyful group displays versus others—social task measuring group emotion perception.
Although happy crowds might imply affiliation, the contrast does not directly measure attachment or bonding processes (no explicit affiliation task).
Happy bodily expressions in groups are nonverbal communicative signals; this contrast measures reception of such social communication.
Contrast focuses on perception of external group emotions rather than self-related processing.
Addresses perception and understanding of others' emotional states and group behaviors (fits action/animacy perception).
Neutral>fear+happy contrast involves social scenes of crowds and thus relates to social processing (perception of group behavior when neutral).
Neutral crowd contrasts do not index affiliation/attachment processes; no measures of bonding or close relationships are present.
Even neutral body expressions and group dynamics convey nonverbal cues; the contrast taps reception of such social communication.
No self-related judgments or agency measures are assessed by this contrast.
Contrast examines how observers perceive others in neutral crowds versus emotional crowds — matches perception-of-others construct.
Main effect of dynamics (interactive>individual) directly tests sensitivity to social interaction dynamics across emotions — a core social processing measure.

While interactive scenes may imply social bonding, the task contrasts interaction vs individual behavior but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation metrics).
Interactive vs individual crowds probe exchange and perception of social signals/nonverbal communication between agents; fits social communication reception (non-facial) domain.
Although discussion mentions self-representation, the contrast examines perception of others' interactions rather than explicit self-related processing.
Directly measures perception and understanding of others' interactions and actions (action perception and animacy), meeting inclusion criteria.
Interactive fear>individual fear tests neural responses to interactive (panic-like) social situations — clearly social processing.
Contrast focuses on threat-related interaction dynamics (panic) rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding processes.
Interactive fearful crowds convey strong nonverbal communicative signals; this contrast assesses reception of these social communications.
Although results interpret integration with self-positioning, the contrast itself measures perception of others and not self-related judgments.
Contrast examines observers' perception of others' fearful interactions and action-relevant cues, matching perception-of-others inclusion criteria.

Contrast combining interactive fear>individual fear and interactive happy>individual happy examines social interaction effects on communicative/emotional processing across valences — social processing.
Although happiness interacting could relate to affiliation, the contrast is not designed to measure attachment or bonding per se; no affiliation-specific task.
Directly probes how interaction dynamics modulate reception of affective nonverbal signals across emotions — social communication.
No explicit measures of self-related processing; focus remains on perceiving others' interactive behavior.
Explicitly targets perception of others' interactions across emotional contexts (action/animacy perception), meeting inclusion criteria.
Contrast combining interactive fear>individual fear and interactive neutral>individual neutral assesses social interaction effects across emotions — a social processing measure.
This contrast addresses interaction dynamics but not attachment/affiliation constructs explicitly.
Assesses how interactive dynamics modulate reception of nonverbal social cues in fear and neutral contexts — fits social communication domain.
No direct assessment of self-awareness or agency; task focuses on perception of others' interactions.
Examines observers' perception of others' interactive behavior (action perception, scene/animacy understanding), meeting inclusion criteria.
Contrast interactive fear>individual fear + individual neutral>interactive neutral tests how dynamics and emotion interact in social processing — clearly social processing.
Focus is on threat-related interaction dynamics and neutral comparisons rather than affiliation/bonding measures.
Contrast probes perception of communicative body movements and interaction cues across emotional contexts — within social communication domain.
The contrast concerns perception of others' interactions rather than explicit measures of self-related processes.
Directly assesses perception and understanding of others' interactions (panic/neutral), fitting the perception-of-others construct.
Interactive neutral>individual neutral contrast probes sensitivity to social interaction dynamics even in neutral crowds — social processing.
Neutral interaction contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.
Even neutral interactions convey nonverbal communicative cues; this contrast measures reception of such social communication.
Contrast examines perception of others' interactions rather than self-related processes.
Directly assesses perception and understanding of others' interactive behavior (action/animacy perception), meeting inclusion criteria.

Contrast examines intention to deceive in a social interactive sender–receiver game and reports activation in ToM/social cognition regions (rTPJ, precuneus, aFG), directly measuring social processing.

The task is a strategic sender–receiver game involving cooperation/competition and social comparison of payoffs, so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment-related social decision processes (competition for monetary benefit).
The paradigm centers on exchange of messages (sending truthful or deceptive communications) and the contrast isolates neural correlates of that social communication.
Analyses probe the sender’s intentions, expectations, RTs, and self-reports (veridical intention to deceive), indexing self-related processing and monitoring.
The contrasts specifically test theory-of-mind and understanding of the receiver’s beliefs (rTPJ, STG), directly measuring perception and understanding of others’ mental states.
Simple deception vs. truth isolates social cognitive processes involved in deceptive behavior in an interactive social task, with activation in rTPJ, dACC, precuneus and aFG.
Simple deception occurs in a competitive/strategic monetary game between sender and receiver, fitting affiliation/attachment inclusion (cooperation/competition) and measuring those processes.
Contrast captures production of deceptive messages (non-facial communication) and neural correlates of message exchange in the interactive paradigm.
Contrasting lying vs. truth examines the sender’s intention, cognitive control, and self-monitoring (longer RTs, reported deliberation), indexing self-related processes.
Simple deception requires inferring the receiver’s beliefs and expectations; activation in rTPJ and STG indicates engagement of processes for understanding others’ mental states.
Sophisticated deception vs. truth contrasts intention to deceive (while telling the truth) in an interactive social paradigm, engaging ToM/social processing regions (rTPJ, precuneus, aFG).

Sophisticated deception is used strategically to advantage the sender in a competitive social game; thus the contrast measures affiliation/attachment-relevant decision processes (cooperation/competition).
This contrast isolates communicative acts (telling a true message intended to deceive) and the neural basis of those communicative strategies in the sender–receiver exchange.
Sophisticated deception requires the sender’s representation of their own intention to deceive and monitoring of that intention (self-related cognitive processes assessed).
Key to sophisticated deception is modeling the receiver’s likely beliefs (ToM); the contrast reports rTPJ and temporal activations linked to understanding others’ mental states.
Direct comparison of sophisticated vs. simple deception addresses different social-cognitive strategies and reports bilateral TPJ and temporal activations, reflecting social processing differences.

The contrast distinguishes different strategic (competitive/cooperative) deceptive behaviors within a social exchange paradigm, relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition).
This contrast compares two communicative strategies (truth used to deceive vs. outright lie), directly targeting neural mechanisms of social communication.

Comparing these deception types probes differences in the sender’s intentions and self-monitoring required for each strategy (heightened demands for sophisticated deception), indexing self-related processing.
Sophisticated deception > simple deception shows greater engagement of regions for inferring others’ beliefs (lTPJ, STG, MTG), directly measuring understanding of others’ mental states.
Truth vs. deception isolates neural correlates of genuine truth-telling in the interactive social task (habenula, frontal operculum, pregenual ACC), a social processing contrast.
Genuine truth trials reflect decisions in the sender–receiver social game and relate to cooperative/competitive motives and social bonding dynamics underlying truthful behavior.
This contrast examines truthful communication (vs. deception) in an interpersonal message-exchange task, satisfying social communication criteria.
Genuine truth trials are defined by the sender’s intention and expectation that the receiver will believe them, reflecting self-related decision and monitoring processes.
Even truthful trials require considering the receiver’s belief; contrasts probe neural substrates of reasoning about others (inclusion of ToM-related processes).
Parametric modulation of incentive to deceive examines how social-motivational conflict modulates neural social-cognitive circuits (dACC, amPFC, aFG) in the interactive task.
The parametric contrast models the tension between sender and receiver payoffs (competition/cooperation), directly addressing affiliation/attachment-related motivational dynamics.
Modeling how incentive/conflict modulates neural responses during deceptive messaging targets mechanisms of social communication under varying motivational contexts.
The parametric effect captures how self-related conflict and decision monitoring (e.g., effort to lie) scale with incentive, indexing perception/understanding of self processes.
Incentive to deceive is defined by interactional payoffs and requires reasoning about the receiver’s choices; the parametric contrast probes how understanding others varies with conflict.

Contrast tests portrait-based predictions combining Rules and Desires conditions — a social prediction/impression formation task engaging ToM and social evaluation. Meets inclusion for social processing.
Task yields interpersonal evaluative judgments (trustworthiness/likeability) and concerns forming social impressions relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Participants view faces and infer behavior from social cues; the contrast involves reception of socially-relevant facial information.
Contrast addresses perception/prediction of others' behavior, not self-related processes or self-evaluation.
Directly probes representations and inferences about others' mental states and behavior (desires vs rules).
Conjunction of Rules and Desires portrait effects — clearly a social processing contrast (impression formation/prediction).
Conjoint portrait effects reflect processes used to form interpersonal evaluations that underlie affiliation/attachment (trust/likeability judgments collected).
Conjunction involves perceiving faces and extracting socially relevant information; thus maps onto social communication (reception) processes.
Effect reflects perception and inference about others rather than self-related cognition.
Directly measures representation and understanding of others across scenarios, satisfying the perception_of_others construct.
Desires > Rules contrast isolates mental-state-based social inference (ToM-related), clearly social processing.
Desire-based inferences inform interpersonal evaluations (liking/trust) and can contribute to affiliation-related impressions measured post-scan.
Desire condition involves interpreting social cues and inferred intentions from faces/text; maps onto reception aspects of social communication.
Contrast focuses on understanding others' desires; not self-related processing.
Targets understanding of others' mental states (desires) and how these guide behavior — a core perception_of_others construct.
Rules > Desires contrast isolates deontic-based social inference (inference about others under rules) — social processing.
Rule-based predictions altered trust/dominance ratings, indicating relevance to affiliation/attachment evaluations.
Although not communication per se, this contrast involves extracting socially-relevant information from faces/context, fitting social_communication (reception) criteria.
Contrast concerns inference about others' rule-following, not self-related representations.
Directly assesses representation and prediction of others' behavior under rules, meeting perception_of_others criteria.
Feedback events decreasing (0 > Rules + Desires) reflect learning about others' behavior — social processing related to updating impressions.
Feedback and learning about characters' compliance/violation inform later affiliation-relevant judgments (trust/dominance), so relevant to attachment/affiliation.
Feedback displays depict characters engaged in activities (faces/behavior) and convey socially relevant signals (reception of facial/behavioral cues).
Feedback contrasts index processing of others' behavior and prediction errors, not self-related cognition.
Feedback analyses concern updating representations of others' actions and dispositions — core perception_of_others.
Feedback: Desires > Rules contrast addresses differential processing of social feedback about others' actions — social processing.
Differential feedback about desire-based behavior can influence interpersonal evaluations relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast involves reception and interpretation of social feedback signals about others' behavior; maps to social communication (reception).
Contrast focuses on others' feedback processing rather than self-related processes.
Directly examines understanding and updating of others' behavioral models based on feedback — perception_of_others.
Main effect (Rules+Desires)/2 > Neutral on final bins isolates social-predictive processing when models are established — core social processing.
Final-bin portrait effects relate to established impressions influencing affiliation judgments (trust/likeability ratings collected), relevant to attachment.
Established portrait-based predictions require decoding socially relevant facial/contextual cues — social communication (reception) processes engaged.
Analysis concerns representations of others after learning, not self-related processing.
Explicitly contrasts social scenarios (rules/desires) vs neutral; assesses representation and prediction of others' behavior — perception_of_others.
Conjunction (Rules>Neutral) ∩ (Desires>Neutral) in last bins isolates shared social-cognitive activity when predictions are accurate — social processing.
Shared activations for social scenarios likely underlie evaluative processes (trust/liking) relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Conjunction reflects reception/processing of socially informative portraits/contexts, fitting social communication reception criteria.
Conjunction reflects other-focused processing rather than self-related cognition.
Conjunction directly measures common representations of others across scenarios — perception_of_others.
Neutral > (Rules+Desires)/2 contrast (last bins) still concerns social stimuli and their differential engagement; social processing is relevant.
Even contrasts favoring neutral contexts pertain to social judgments and impressions about characters, which can influence affiliation/attachment measures.
Contrast involves perception of portraits and contexts (social cues); thus relates to social communication (reception).
Contrast addresses others/contexts rather than self-processing.
Neutral versus social scenarios still involve perception/representation of others and their behaviors — perception_of_others.
Desires > Rules in last two time-bins isolates mature mental-state-based social reasoning — classic social processing.
Late-session desire-driven predictions shape interpersonal evaluations (likability/trust) and therefore relate to affiliation/attachment.
Decoding desire-based information from portraits/text engages reception of socially communicative cues from faces/context.
Analysis concerns others' desires and predictions, not self-related cognition.
Specifically addresses understanding others' mental states (desires) and predicting behavior — core perception_of_others.
Rules > Desires in last bins isolates deontic-based social inference — a social cognitive process relevant to the study's aims.
Rule-based predictions influenced trust/dominance ratings; thus relevant to affiliation/attachment measures.
Inference about rule-following requires decoding contextual/face cues; relates to social communication reception of signals.
Contrast targets other-focused deontic inferences rather than self-perception or self-evaluation.
Directly measures representations of others' rule-based behavior and related evaluations — perception_of_others.
Interaction contrast isolating anticipation of inconsistent feedback (violations) engages social predictive/updating processes — social processing.
Responses to violating profiles affect trustworthiness/dominance evaluations relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Detecting and anticipating violations from faces/contexts involves reception of socially informative signals and cues.
Contrast measures anticipatory processing about others' violating behavior, not self-related processes.
This interaction probes understanding and anticipation of others' propensity to violate expectations — perception_of_others.
Opposite interaction contrast isolates anticipatory processing for non-violating profiles — still a social predictive/updating process.
Processing patterns for compliant profiles inform interpersonal evaluations and are relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Discriminating compliant vs violating profiles relies on perception of socially relevant cues; maps onto social communication reception.
Contrast concerns others' behavior patterns and predictions, not self-related cognition.
Targets representation and prediction of others' behavior across profiles and scenarios — core perception_of_others.

Exogenous system (Ω+) was derived from a dyadic eye-contact task and identifies social-brain networks (empathy, mirror-related regions). This analysis measures social processing (face-to-face interaction, reciprocity), satisfying that it is a social-related task and that the contrast indexes social processing.

The study did not manipulate or contrast affiliation/attachment (no loved vs. stranger or bonding manipulation). Although an IOS closeness score was collected, the analysis/contrast does not test affiliation/attachment constructs directly.

The exogenous analysis targets responses to eye contact and external social cues (reciprocal gaze), which is a core social-communication behavior (production/reception of facial/eye cues). The contrast measures social communication-related activation.
Ω+ is described as an externally-focused/exogenous network (empathy, mirror, sensorimotor) rather than self-referential processing. The analysis does not target self-specific judgments or agency.

The exogenous system reflects perceiving others' actions/emotions (empathy, mirror networks) and responses to partner’s gaze, matching perception/understanding of others (action and affect perception).

Endogenous system (Ω-) was identified from the same dyadic eye-contact paradigm and involves mentalization/DMN regions engaged during reciprocal social interaction; this clearly measures social processing.

The endogenous analysis highlights mentalization and default-mode activity but does not directly test affiliation or attachment (no contrasts or tasks manipulating relationship/attachment). Collection of IOS scores does not constitute an affiliation contrast in the reported analyses.

Although Ω- emphasizes internal/mentalizing networks, it arises from reciprocal eye-contact and supports aspects of social communication (understanding others’ intent/states during interaction). The contrast measures communication-relevant mentalizing.

The endogenous system includes DMN/medial frontoparietal regions and is discussed as engaging self-referential/default states (ξ = 0) and self-related processes during reciprocity; thus it relates to perception/understanding of self.

Ω- is interpreted as the mentalization network involved in reasoning about others’ mental states; this matches the perception/understanding of others (mental state attribution) and the analysis measures those processes.

The why>how conjunction across stimulus categories includes social attribution trials (emotional expressions and intentional actions) and isolates attributional (social) processing; thus it measures social processing alongside nonsocial processing.

The task and contrast index general attributional processing and mental state inference, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship bonding; no manipulations or contrasts target loved vs. stranger or kinship/cooperation-specific processes.

The stimulus set includes emotional facial expressions and intentional actions and the why>how contrast taps affective and action-related inference (reception of facial and non-facial communicative signals), meeting criteria for social communication.

The contrast concerns attribution about external scenes and other people's emotions/actions rather than self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.

The why>how contrast directly targets representations and inferences about others' mental states and actions (understanding emotions and intentions), satisfying the criteria for perception and understanding of others.
This contrast isolates regions showing stronger why>how responses for social versus nonsocial stimuli, directly indexing social-specific attributional processing and thus social processing.

The contrast tests social vs nonsocial attributional processing broadly; it does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, bonding) or related task manipulations.

The social > nonsocial why>how contrast emphasizes processing of emotional expressions and intentional actions (reception of facial and action cues), which fits the social communication construct (reception subcomponents).
The contrast reflects processing about others and social scenes rather than self-related evaluation or agency/self-knowledge; it does not measure perception of the self.

The contrast identifies regions selectively engaged when attributing mental states and intentions to others (social>nonsocial), directly mapping onto perception and understanding of others, including understanding mental states and action perception.

Contrast Incongruent>Congruent assesses regulation of automatic imitation (mimicry) in presence of social-affective stimuli (faces). This directly measures social processing (perception and response to social cues) across the task.
The study operationalizes mimicry as an affiliative signal and the Incongruent>Congruent contrast indexes regulation of mimicry relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.

The task presents facial expressions and measures imitative responses (receptive and productive aspects of social communication); the contrast taps neural mechanisms supporting communicative mimicry control.
Incongruent>Congruent captures processes of self–other distinction and control of one's own actions versus observed actions (agency/self-awareness), evidenced by TPJ and related activations.
The contrast indexes representations of others' actions and states (action perception/animacy) because observed hand movements and facial cues drive the effect.
This contrast isolates mimicry regulation specifically for Happy faces (Happy incongruent>congruent masked by Happy>Angry), directly probing social-affective processing of affiliative signals.
Happy faces are explicit affiliative signals; this contrast targets neural regulation of mimicry in response to affiliative cues, matching affiliation/attachment constructs.
Happy facial expressions are a form of facial social communication; the contrast measures reception of facial communication and its influence on imitative/expressive behavior.
The analysis examines self–other distinction and control processes (e.g., rTPJ involvement) when regulating mimicry in response to affiliative stimuli, thus probing self-related perception/agency.
Contrast specifically concerns perception of others' affiliative emotional states (happy faces) and how these representations modulate action perception and imitation.
This contrast isolates mimicry regulation for Angry faces (Angry incongruent>congruent masked with Angry>Happy), addressing social-affective processing of non-affiliative/threat cues.

Although angry faces signal non-affiliative/dominance cues, their modulation of mimicry relates to affiliative/appeasement processes (study frames mimicry as affiliative regulation), so this contrast is relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Angry facial expressions are communicative social signals; the contrast measures reception of facial affect and its impact on imitative behavior, fitting social communication.
Regulation for angry faces engages self–other control mechanisms (to either withhold or upregulate mimicry), implicating perception/understanding of one's own action tendencies and agency.
This contrast probes representation of others' threatening or non-affiliative emotional states and action cues, directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Out-group (Incongruent>Congruent masked with Out>In) contrast directly assesses social processing related to group membership and its effect on mimicry regulation.
The out-group contrast tests mimicry as an affiliative/appeasement response toward perceived out-group threat; this directly measures affiliation/attachment-related regulation.
Group-membership cues (face ethnicity) are communicative social signals; the contrast measures how reception of these cues influences imitative/communicative behavior.
Out-group modulation involves self–other control and behavioral regulation (AI/MCC, TPJ, vPMC activations) reflecting processes of self-related control/agency in social contexts.
This contrast explicitly probes perception and inferred threat/intent of others (out-group), indexing representation and evaluation of others' social attributes and states.
In-group (Incongruent>Congruent masked with In>Out) contrast examines social processing related to same-group stimuli and mimicry regulation within affiliative contexts.
In-group contrasts tap affiliative dynamics (reciprocation of affiliation) and mimicry as an attachment-related signal; thus directly relevant to affiliation/attachment measures.
In-group facial cues and their effect on imitation are social communication phenomena (reception of facial cues and expressive reciprocation), so this contrast measures social communication.
Regulation of mimicry to in-group stimuli involves self-related control and agency (maintaining task focus vs reciprocation), consistent with perception/self constructs.
This contrast addresses representation of others (in-group members' emotional states and actions) and how those representations modulate action perception and imitation.

Contrast compares Eye Contact vs Averted Gaze while participants view social agents; the task probes social cues and processing of social attention relations, thus measuring social processing broadly.
Contrast manipulates observed eye contact but does not measure affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment constructs (no measures of relationship or attachment).
Eye contact and gaze are core social communicative signals; this contrast directly probes reception/processing of facial communication cues.
The contrast concerns perception of others' gaze and social relations, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge.
This contrast probes perception and interpretation of others' gaze/attentional relation (observed eye contact vs averted) and therefore measures perception/understanding of others.
Averted Gaze > Eye Contact examines processing of social gaze cues and attentional relations between agents, reflecting social processing.
Although socially relevant, the contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation measures).
Contrasts involving averted gaze probe reception of facial/ocular communication and thus are measures of social communication.
The contrast targets perception of others' gaze and spatial attention, not self-referential processing or agency.
Averted vs eye contact involves interpreting others' gaze behavior and social intentions, fitting perception/understanding of others.
Congruent > Incongruent contrasts target gaze-following, a social attention phenomenon, and thus reflect social processing.
The contrast tests gaze congruency effects (attention) rather than affiliation, bonding, or attachment-related processes.
Gaze congruency (gaze following) is a form of social communication/reception of facial cues; this contrast measures that communicative processing.
This contrast concerns attentional orienting to others' gaze, not self-awareness or self-related judgments.
Congruent vs incongruent gaze cues probe how participants perceive and interpret others' gaze and intentions, matching perception/understanding of others.
Incongruent > Congruent contrasts involve processing of others' gaze and attentional shifts, which are social processes.
This contrast concerns attentional and perceptual costs of gaze incongruency, not measures of affiliation or attachment.
Incongruent gaze cues alter reception/processing of communicative gaze signals; the contrast measures social communication aspects.
The contrast indexes processing of external gaze signals and attentional reallocation, not self-related cognition.
This contrast reflects participants' perception and interpretation of others' gaze behavior and implied attention/intent, fitting perception of others.
Contrast compares congruent gaze trials following Eye Contact vs Averted Gaze; this examines how observed social relations modulate gaze processing—clearly social processing.
Although this contrast manipulates social context, it does not assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship-level constructs.
This interaction contrast specifically tests how an observed communicative signal (eye contact) modulates reception/processing of gaze cues, a social communication process.
The contrast addresses perception of others' interactions and gaze, not self-related cognition or agency.
This contrast examines how observing others' eye contact influences perception and interpretation of their subsequent gaze—directly relevant to perception of others.
Averted Gaze incongruent > Averted Gaze congruent contrasts are within the social task and index processing differences in gaze-following under no-attentional-relation context.
This contrast examines gaze congruency effects under averted gaze context, not affiliation or attachment measures.
Contrast concerns reception and processing of communicative gaze signals (congruent vs incongruent) in the averted-gaze context; measures social communication.
This contrast addresses perceptual and attentional processing of others' gaze, not self-referential processing.
The contrast probes how participants perceive and interpret others' gaze directions and congruency, fitting perception and understanding of others.

Task involves processing of social stimuli (angry and happy faces) and compares emotional face processing to neutral shapes; this clearly measures social processing (perception and interpretation of social/emotional cues).

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or love/stranger contrasts); it focuses on gender identification and emotion processing rather than attachment-related behaviors.

The analyses involve reception of facial communication (emotion in faces, implicit emotion processing via gender identification), which fits the 'reception of facial communication' subconstruct and measures social communication.
The contrasts do not assess self-related processes (agency, self-knowledge, or judgments about oneself); they concern perception of external social stimuli.
The task requires perceiving and interpreting others' emotional expressions (angry, happy faces) and contrasts these with neutral shapes, directly targeting perception and understanding of others.

Task involves processing of social stimuli (angry and happy faces) and compares emotional face processing to neutral shapes; this clearly measures social processing (perception and interpretation of social/emotional cues).

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or love/stranger contrasts); it focuses on gender identification and emotion processing rather than attachment-related behaviors.

The analyses involve reception of facial communication (emotion in faces, implicit emotion processing via gender identification), which fits the 'reception of facial communication' subconstruct and measures social communication.
The contrasts do not assess self-related processes (agency, self-knowledge, or judgments about oneself); they concern perception of external social stimuli.
The task requires perceiving and interpreting others' emotional expressions (angry, happy faces) and contrasts these with neutral shapes, directly targeting perception and understanding of others.

Task presents social reputational comments paired with faces and asks participants to judge pleasantness — a social processing task assessing perception and response to social information; contrast (Positive vs. Neutral) measures social processing of positive reputation.

Positive reputational feedback reflects socially rewarding information that can drive affiliation/attachment-related processes (positive social valuation); the Positive vs. Neutral contrast measures receipt of positive social appraisal relevant to affiliation.

Participants receive communicative comments (verbal appraisal) paired with faces and rate them — clearly involves reception of social communication; the contrast isolates neural response to positively valenced social communication.
Reputational comments are directed at the participant (self-referential); Positive vs. Neutral measures self-related evaluation (pleasantness) and associated neural response.
Contrast involves perceiving facial identities and the source of reputational comments (other agents) and evaluating information from others; thus it engages perception/understanding of others.
Negative reputational comments about the participant are social information; (Negative vs. Neutral) contrasts social processing of negative reputation.

Negative reputation reflects social punishment/negative evaluation rather than positive bonding or affiliative reward; the contrast measures negative appraisal and arousal rather than affiliation/attachment per se.
Subjects receive negative communicative messages paired with faces, engaging reception of social communication; this contrast isolates neural responses to negative communicative feedback.
Negative comments are directed to the self and thus engage self-referential processing; the contrast measures self-related negative evaluation.

Participants perceive the faces/sources delivering negative comments and must interpret others’ evaluations — engaging perception of others; contrast indexes processing of others’ negative appraisals.
Inclusive mask (Positive > Neutral) AND (Negative > Neutral) identifies regions responding to social reputational feedback of either valence; clearly measures social processing.

The conjunction captures regions responsive to both positive and negative reputation (valence-independent), which is not specific to affiliation/attachment (typically linked to positive bonding/reward); therefore affiliation_attachment is not specifically measured by this conjunction.
Conjunction identifies regions engaged by reception of communicative reputational feedback regardless of valence — fits Social Communication reception criteria.
Conjunction finds regions responding when participants receive self-directed reputational comments (both positive and negative), indexing self-related processing.

Regions common to both valences reflect processing of information coming from others (faces and comments) and interpretation of others’ evaluations — consistent with perception/understanding of others.

This contrast [(Positive vs Neutral) vs (Negative vs Neutral)] isolates positive-specific social-reputation processing in the brain (vmPFC reported) — directly measures social processing of valenced reputation.

Positive-specific activation reflects processing of socially rewarding reputation, which maps onto affiliation/attachment-related processes (positive social valuation); thus this contrast measures affiliation-relevant processing.
Contrast isolates neural response to positively valenced communicative feedback — clearly within Social Communication (reception) domain.
Contrast identifies self-referential valuation responses to positive reputation relative to negative reputation — engages perception/understanding of self.
Positive-specific effects depend on the source (gender of giver) and perception of others’ positive appraisals; thus the contrast engages perception/understanding of others as evaluators.
This contrast isolates regions more engaged by negative reputation relative to positive reputation; it targets social evaluative processing of negative feedback — therefore social processing applies.

Negative-specific activation reflects processing of negative social evaluation/punishment rather than affiliation/attachment (positive bonding), so affiliation_attachment is not specifically measured.
Contrast focuses on reception of negative communicative feedback from others and isolates neural correlates of processing such communication — fits Social Communication.
Negative > Positive reflects self-referential processing of adverse reputational comments and thus engages perception/understanding of self.
This contrast depends on perceiving others as sources of negative evaluation (faces/genders) and thus engages perception/understanding of others’ evaluations.

EmpaToM emotionally negative>neutral videos directly probe social processes (empathy/compassion) — clear social cognition task measuring perception and response to others' emotional states.

Contrast measures empathy/compassion but not affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of kinship, bonding, cooperation or loved-one vs stranger comparisons); does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.

Task probes empathic and mental state understanding rather than communicative exchange, facial expression production/reception, or explicit communicative behavior; does not meet social communication inclusion criterion.
Participants provide valence and compassion ratings about their own affective state after videos (self-report of internal state), so the contrast indexes self-perception processes.
Contrast reflects perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathy) — directly measures understanding others' affective states and thus 'perception and understanding of others'.
EmpaToM ToM>nonToM questions explicitly probe social cognition (Theory of Mind) — clearly a social processing contrast.
ToM questions assess inferring others' beliefs/intentions, not affiliation/attachment or bonding-specific constructs; does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
The contrast targets mentalizing (inferring mental states) rather than communicative reception/production per se; does not target social communication measures as defined.

The ToM>nonToM question contrast indexes inference about others' mental states; it does not primarily assess self-awareness or explicit judgments about one's own traits/states, so Perception_Self is not a primary target.
Theory of Mind questions require representing and reasoning about others' beliefs/intentions — directly meets inclusion for perception and understanding of others (understanding mental states).
EmpaToM emotionally negative>neutral videos in Experiment 2 probe empathy/compassion and related social processes — clear social processing measure.
Although compassion is assessed, the task does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/bonding/cooperation contrasts); does not satisfy affiliation inclusion criterion.
Contrast focuses on empathic responding to others' narratives rather than explicit communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals per the social_communication definition.
Participants provide trial-by-trial valence and compassion ratings reporting their own affective state; the contrast reflects self-perception of internal affective responses.
Contrast indexes perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy), satisfying the 'understanding others' inclusion criterion.
EmpaToM ToM>nonToM questions (Exp 2) are explicit social-cognitive measures of mentalizing — clearly social processing.
This contrast probes mental state inference (ToM), not affiliation/attachment (no bonding or loved-one comparisons), so it does not meet affiliation inclusion criterion.
Primary target is Theory of Mind (understanding others' mental states) rather than communicative reception/production; does not match social_communication inclusion.
The ToM question contrast indexes others' mental-state reasoning rather than self-focused perception or self-knowledge; self-perception is not the primary construct in this contrast.
ToM questions require representing others' beliefs and intentions — directly maps onto Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others (Understanding Mental States).
The differential contrast (emotional>neutral videos)>(ToM>nonToM questions) isolates empathy-related social processing and so is a social processing measure.
This differential contrast isolates empathy-specific neural responses but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation manipulations); does not meet affiliation inclusion.
Contrast differentiates affective vs cognitive social cognition, not communicative exchange or reception/production aspects, so it does not meet social_communication inclusion.

The empathy>ToM contrast reflects affective responding (and associated self-report of affect/compassion) and processes related to perceiving one's own emotional reactions; thus Perception_Self is relevant.
The contrast identifies empathy-specific regions involved in representing others' affective states, satisfying Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion.
The differential contrast (ToM>nonToM questions)>(emotional>neutral videos) isolates ToM-specific processing and is clearly social processing.
This contrast isolates mentalizing (ToM) regions, not affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding or loved-one vs stranger comparisons; does not meet affiliation inclusion.
Contrast targets cognitive inference about others' mental states rather than communicative reception/production; does not fulfill social_communication inclusion.
The ToM>Empathy differential isolates others' mental-state processing rather than self-perception or self-knowledge, so Perception_Self is not primary here.
This contrast isolates ToM-specific regions supporting representation and reasoning about others' beliefs/intentions — directly meets Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others.

The study uses a gaze-following task with political in-group/out-group faces and assesses neural and behavioural responses to social cues; contrasts (incongruent>congruent, in-group vs out-group) directly measure social processing. Measures include SDO and perceived similarity. Thus it both uses a social-related task and measures social processing.

The design manipulates political group membership (in-group vs out-group), measures in-group bias, perceived similarity with political personages, and examines effects of affiliation-related variables (in-group attachment, emotional valence). The task therefore addresses affiliation/attachment constructs.

Gaze-following is a core social-communication behaviour (production and reception of gaze cues). The task explicitly probes receptive/produced gaze signals and their communicative impact on observers (and associated neural responses), meeting the social communication definition.

Participants provided self-ratings on personality adjectives and the study computed perceived similarity (self vs each political personage). Analyses correlate these self-related measures with neural activity, so the contrast indexes perception/understanding of self-related traits.

Participants rated political personages on personality traits, influence, emotional valence and political orientation; contrasts examine responses to others' gaze and how perception of others (in-group vs out-group) modulates neural activity, fitting perception/understanding of others.

The ToM > R whole-brain contrast tests Theory of Mind processing using moving-triangle animations that elicit attribution of intentionality; this is a canonical social cognition task and therefore measures broad social processing.

The task involves attributing intentions to animated shapes (ToM) but does not probe affiliation, attachment, or relationship bonding (no loved-one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation-specific manipulations).

The paradigm measures mental state attribution and animacy perception rather than explicit communicative exchanges (facial/verbal/nonverbal social communication); it does not map to the specified social communication examples.
The contrast targets perception/understanding of others' mental states (ToM) and does not assess self-related processes, self-knowledge, or agency judgments.
The ToM > R contrast directly measures understanding of others' mental states (animacy and intentionality attribution), matching the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct.

This Bayesian VOI analysis evaluates mPFC response relative to a right posterior superior temporal gyrus region for the ToM > R effect; it is directly testing neural responses related to a social (ToM) task, and thus measures social processing.

The Bayesian comparison concerns regional BOLD responses during ToM stimuli but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or relationship-specific contrasts).

Although the analysis is of ToM-related activity, it does not index communicative reception or production (faces, gestures, or explicit information exchange) as defined by the social communication construct.
The VOI Bayesian test compares mPFC and temporal responses for ToM but does not measure self-referential processes, self-knowledge, or agency judgments.

The analysis specifically addresses neural responses underlying attribution of mental states (ToM) by comparing region-specific BOLD changes during ToM stimuli, matching 'Understanding Mental States'.

This VOI (right posterior superior temporal gyrus) analysis examines the mean BOLD response during the ToM > R contrast, which is directly probing social cognitive processing (mental state attribution).
The VOI measurement in right posterior STG pertains to ToM/animacy perception and not to affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship-specific tasks.

Although the STG region can be involved in social perception, this specific analysis measures ToM-related activation (understanding intentions) rather than communicative reception/production per the social communication definition.
The analysis targets perception/understanding of others (ToM) and does not probe self-related constructs such as agency or self-knowledge.

The right posterior STG VOI analysis assesses activity related to animacy and intentionality perception (understanding others' mental states) in the ToM > R contrast, fitting the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct.

This contrast (main effect of pain, FWE-corrected) is from an empathy-for-pain task with a social manipulation; it measures social processing (perceiving and responding to others’ pain).

The main effect of pain (pain vs neutral) indexes empathic response to others’ pain but does not test affiliation/attachment or ingroup vs outgroup differences directly, so it does not meet criteria for affiliation/attachment.
The contrast measures reception of socially relevant affective signals (others’ pain) and therefore taps receptive aspects of social communication/affect recognition.
This contrast assesses perception of others’ pain, not self-related awareness or judgments; it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.
The pain vs neutral contrast directly measures representation and assessment of others’ emotional states (pain), satisfying Perception/Others criteria.
Main effect of condition (ingroup vs outgroup) directly tests social group membership effects on empathy — clearly a social processing contrast.
The ingroup vs outgroup contrast operationalizes affiliation/attachment (minimal-group membership), matching examples like Loved one vs Stranger and meeting the affiliation inclusion criteria.
Ingroup/outgroup manipulation changes processing of social signals (others’ pain); the contrast involves reception of socially relevant cues and therefore relates to social communication.
The contrast concerns perception of others (ingroup/outgroup) rather than self-awareness or self-judgment, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
This ingroup vs outgroup contrast measures differences in representing and evaluating others’ emotional states (pain) and thus meets Perception/Others criteria.
Although this is a main effect of gender, it derives from the social empathy task; it reflects social processing differences in responses to others’ pain and thus meets Social Processing criteria.
A main effect of gender does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment (no direct test of ingroup vs outgroup or bonding), so it does not satisfy Affiliation/Attachment criteria.

This contrast reflects gender differences in task responses but does not directly index reception or production of social communicative signals (the contrast is not a communication-specific manipulation), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The gender main effect does not probe self-related processing or self-knowledge; it is focused on group differences in processing others’ stimuli.
Even as a gender main effect, the analysis reflects differential neural responses while perceiving others’ pain (the paradigm is about others’ emotional states), satisfying Perception/Others I1.
The pain×condition interaction (pain by ingroup/outgroup) is a canonical social processing contrast examining how social group membership modulates empathy — it meets Social Processing criteria.
Pain×condition explicitly tests differential responses to ingroup vs outgroup (affiliation) in empathic processing, directly matching Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criteria.

This interaction tests how reception of others’ affective signals (pain) is modulated by group membership — it taps receptive social communication mechanisms (affect recognition) and so meets Social Communication criteria.
The interaction concerns how others’ pain is represented depending on group membership, not self-related awareness or judgments; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Pain×condition assesses differential representation and evaluation of others’ emotional states depending on group membership — it clearly meets Perception/Others criteria.
The pain×gender interaction examines social-empathic processing modulated by participant gender; derived from a social task, it reflects Social Processing.

Pain×gender tests gender differences in empathic responses rather than affiliation or attachment processes (no ingroup/outgroup or bonding contrast), so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
This interaction involves reception/processing of others’ affective signals (pain) with modulation by gender; it therefore engages receptive social communication processes.
Pain×gender focuses on perception of others’ pain and gender differences in that perception, not self-awareness or self-judgment, so Perception/Self is not met.
The interaction reflects gender-modulated representation and evaluation of others’ emotional states (pain), satisfying Perception/Others criteria.

Contrast 'Self-referential > social' isolates neural activity specific to self-referential processing (Se+So− > Se−So+). Although social stimuli are present in the design, this contrast emphasizes self-related processing and does not measure social processing per se.

No tasks or contrasts assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related processing (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation). The contrast targets self-referential processing, not affiliation/attachment.

The paradigm uses pictures depicting humans but does not probe social communication (facial expression recognition, gaze/communicative exchange). The contrast isolates self-referential > social and is not a social-communication measure.

This contrast directly isolates self-referential processing (judgments whether a picture relates personally to the subject) by comparing self-referential non-social stimuli to social non-self stimuli. It therefore measures Perception and Understanding of Self (self-knowledge/agency).

Although social stimuli depicting others are present in the comparison, the contrast is set to highlight self>social and thus does not serve as a primary measure of perception/understanding of others (animacy, action, mental states).

Contrast 'Social > self-referential' (Se−So+ > Se+So−) isolates neural activity associated with social stimulus processing (pictures depicting humans, implicit social processing). This directly measures social processing.

The social condition uses images of humans but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition). The contrast targets general social stimulus processing rather than attachment-related processes.

While social stimuli include humans, the task does not probe communicative interactions, facial expression judgments, or production/reception of communicative acts. Thus it does not meet criteria for Social Communication.
This contrast isolates social > self-referential processing and therefore is not a primary measure of perception/understanding of the self (self-knowledge/agency).

Social stimuli were defined as depicting one or more humans and implicit social processing relates to perceiving others (animacy, intentionality, bodies/faces). The Social > non-social contrast therefore measures Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action/mental-state-related perception).

The contrast examines racial prejudice effects on perception of disgusted vs neutral faces (in-group vs out-group), which is a social task probing perception and interpretation of social/emotional cues. This directly measures social processing.

The study focuses on prejudice, emotion perception, and neural connectivity, not on positive social bonds, attachment, or affiliation behaviors (no tasks contrasting loved ones/attachment). Thus it does not measure affiliation/attachment.

The task is passive viewing and emotion recognition of faces (reception of facial communication). The contrast targets perception of others' facial expressions (disgust) and racial modulation, matching social communication (receptive facial communication).

Analyses examine perception of others' facial emotions and prejudice, not self-related processing, self-awareness, or judgments about one's own traits/states. No self-perception contrasts are present.

The contrast explicitly tests perception and understanding of others' emotional states (disgust in in-group vs out-group faces) and how prejudice modulates that perception, satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

The PPI analysis examines task-modulated insula connectivity during racial-biased disgust perception, a social-emotional process involving interpreting social cues; thus it measures social processing.
The functional connectivity analysis probes emotional/prejudicial processing and regulation, not affiliation or attachment processes (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or attachment).

The gPPI targets insula coupling while participants perceive facial expressions (reception of facial communication) and racial bias in emotion perception, fitting social communication (receptive facial communication).
The connectivity analysis addresses perception of others' emotions and prejudice rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge; no self-related contrasts or tasks are used.

The PPI examines neural mechanisms supporting perception/interpretation of others' emotional states (insula coupling with amygdala/ACC when viewing out-group disgust), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
This analysis (negative connectivity results) addresses social-emotional regulatory processing (insula–ACC coupling) during racialized disgust perception, a clear social processing measure.
The negative connectivity analysis concerns emotion regulation and prejudice, not affiliation/attachment or bonding measures; no relevant tasks for attachment are present.

Negative functional coupling of insula with ACC during perception of others' disgusted faces pertains to receptive processing of facial emotion and social signals, consistent with social communication.
The analysis focuses on neural responses to others' facial emotions and regulatory circuitry, not self-perception or self-referential judgments.

The negative connectivity findings index mechanisms for perceiving and regulating responses to others' emotional states (out-group disgust), directly addressing perception and understanding of others.

The analysis examines brain responses to agentic and communal (social trait) words during a valence classification task — a social cognition task measuring processing of social content. This directly meets the social processing inclusion criterion.

Communal words explicitly index affiliation/communion (warmth, morality). The analysis contrasts communal (affiliation-related) stimuli with baseline, so it measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The task involves classifying valence of trait words rather than exchange/recognition of communicative signals (faces, gaze, speech) or production/reception of communicative behavior. It does not target social communication constructs.

Participants were not instructed to reflect on the self; the task was a valence classification of trait words and the authors explicitly note they dissociated content from perspective. Thus it does not measure self-perception or self-referential processing.

Processing trait adjectives (agency/communion) engages representations about social traits and invokes mentalizing-related regions; even though perspective was not explicitly manipulated, the task measures perception/understanding of others’ trait-related information.
This analysis compares agentic and communal word blocks to the fixation baseline; it clearly involves social trait processing and thus meets the social processing inclusion criterion.
Communal (affiliation-related) stimuli are included in the contrast against fixation, so the analysis indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing (communal content).

The fixation-contrast analysis assesses trait word processing, not social communicative exchanges or recognition/production of communicative signals, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The task did not require self-referential judgments and the authors note the task did not ask participants to contemplate the self; thus this analysis does not index perception/self-processing.

Trait word processing (agency/communion) engages representations about others’ traits and mental states; contrasts vs fixation capture neural responses relevant to perceiving/understanding others’ social content.
The direct Agency vs. Communion contrast examines neural differences in processing two fundamental social cognition dimensions; it clearly targets social processing.
The contrast directly compares communal (affiliation-related) to agentic content, making it a targeted test of affiliation/attachment-related processing differences.

Although both conditions contain social content, the contrast compares content types rather than communicative behaviors or signal processing (faces/gaze/expressions), so it does not measure social communication per the defined construct.

The contrast isolates content dimensions (agency vs communion) within a valence classification task and did not instruct self-referential processing; thus it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.

Comparing agency and communion assesses how participants process trait-related social content about agents/others; authors interpret findings in terms of mentalizing and perceiving others’ traits, so this contrast indexes perception/understanding of others.

The Communion vs. Agency contrast targets neural responses to communal (social-affiliation) content versus agentic content — a clear social cognition manipulation, meeting the social processing criterion.

This contrast emphasizes communal (affiliation-related) words relative to agentic words and therefore measures affiliation/attachment-related processing differences (greater deactivation/activation for communion).

The analysis contrasts content domains (communion vs agency) in a valence classification task rather than assessing communicative signal reception or production, so it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.

Participants were not prompted to reflect on themselves; authors report dissociation of content from perspective and do not interpret results as self-perception, so this analysis does not index perception/self.

The contrast investigates processing of communal content, which is inherently about social traits and others’ interpersonal qualities; authors link results to mentalizing and attention to others’ social information, supporting inclusion.

The Words>Faces contrast compares speech acts presented in social interactive video scenes against face-only controls. The task required participants to attend to communicative interactions and the contrast produced activation in right TPJ and language/auditory areas, indicating engagement of social processing. Thus it both involves a social-related task and measures social processing.

The study does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding, or attachment measures). The Words>Faces contrast contrasts communicative language processing with face-only stimuli and does not index affiliation/attachment.

The analysis contrasts linguistic communicative events (words in dialogues) against face-only blocks; the stimuli and task specifically involve reception of communicative acts and interpretation of others' utterances, meeting the Social Communication construct.
The task involved observing interactions between others and did not require judgments about the participant's own traits, states, or agency. Thus it does not measure Perception/Understanding of Self.

Participants viewed and interpreted others' communicative intentions and actions; the contrast produced right TPJ activation (a mentalizing area) and object/action-related regions, indicating engagement of action perception and understanding of others' mental states.

The Request>Naming contrast directly compares comprehension of two speech act types in social interactive contexts. It elicited activation in premotor, IFG, TPJ and pSTS, reflecting social processing of communicative actions; thus it meets both social-task and social-processing requirements.
The contrast examines directive vs referential speech acts (Request vs Naming) and action prediction/intention processing, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or bonding between partners.

This contrast isolates different communicative functions (Requests vs Naming) using identical utterances in interactive settings; it therefore directly targets social communication processes (reception/interpretation of communicative acts).
The task required understanding others' speech acts and did not probe self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; hence it does not index Perception/Understanding of Self.

Request>Naming engaged regions implicated in action perception and mentalizing (premotor, IFG, aIPS, right pSTS), reflecting perception and understanding of others' intentions and predicted actions, matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

This analysis (Request>Naming) again contrasts social communicative functions in interactive videos and engages social cognitive systems (action prediction, intention understanding). It therefore measures social processing in a social task.
The contrast focuses on communicative function and action prediction, not on affiliation or attachment constructs.
The contrast compares communicative speech act types (Requests vs Naming) presented in social interaction contexts, directly indexing social communication processes.
No measures of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge were involved; the task targets observation and interpretation of others' communicative actions.

Request>Naming involves predicting and interpreting others' intended actions (handing over, refusal) and recruited action-perception and mentalizing regions consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.

Even though the Naming>Request contrast yielded no significant activations at corrected threshold, it is derived from the same social-communicative task (Naming vs Requesting) and is intended to measure social processing (referential vs directive speech acts). Therefore it qualifies as social processing.
The contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding; it contrasts speech act types (Naming vs Requesting) without affiliation measures.

Naming>Request is directly concerned with communicative function (referential Naming vs directive Request) in social interactions and therefore measures social communication processes despite null whole-brain effects.
This analysis does not assess self-related perception or self-knowledge; participants observed interactions rather than making self-assessments.

The contrast targets processes of interpreting others' communicative acts and referential links between words and objects (left AG trend), which are aspects of perceiving and understanding others and their communicative intentions.
