EBA localizer contrasts visual perception of human bodies—a form of social perceptual processing relevant to recognizing others' bodies and actions; thus it falls under broad social processing.
The EBA localizer measures perceptual processing of body parts and does not assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship/ bonding constructs.
The task presents body stimuli but does not involve exchange of social signals (gaze, communication, or reciprocal interaction), so it does not index social communication.
The localizer measures perception of body stimuli (others) rather than self-related processing, so it does not target self-perception or agency/self-knowledge.
EBA localizer explicitly targets visual perception of human body parts and action-related features, which maps onto perception and understanding of others (action/animacy perception).
MG1 mutual gaze is a direct face-to-face social interaction condition; the analysis addresses shared attention and inter-individual neural synchronization, so it is broadly social processing.
Mutual gaze here probes shared attention and synchronization rather than measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship/bonding per se (no attachment scales or kinship contrasts).
Mutual gaze involves production and reception of facial/eye signals and real-time exchange of social information (eye contact), meeting the social communication definition.
The analysis focuses on inter-brain synchronization and perception of the partner rather than explicit self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge measures.
Mutual gaze entails perceiving another person's eye/face behavior and temporal coordination (eye-blink synchronization), directly indexing perception/understanding of others' actions and states.
MG2 is mutual gaze after joint attention training and examines pair-specific social memory and inter-brain synchronization, clearly broad social processing.
Although MG2 reflects pair-specific changes, the measures do not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding scales or attachment paradigms).
MG2 involves interactive eye contact and retained coordination from prior joint attention—forms of social communication (reception/production of facial/eye signals).
The contrast targets inter-individual synchronization and shared attention rather than explicit self-perception or self-knowledge.
MG2 measures perception and temporal coordination of another's gaze/blinks and neural responses to the partner, fitting perception-of-others constructs (action perception/animacy).
The MG2–MG1 contrast captures learning-dependent enhancement of inter-brain synchronization and retained shared attention — a social memory/process, fitting broad social processing.
This contrast indexes neural changes after joint attention training, not measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship strength explicitly.
The enhancement reflects changes in interactive gaze-based coordination and communication (shared attention), consistent with social communication constructs.

Although right IFG is discussed as an interface between self and other, the contrast tests pair-specific inter-brain synchrony not explicit self-related judgments or agency measures, so perception_self is not a primary target.
Contrast shows neural synchronization tied to perceiving/responding to partner's gaze and blink timing (action perception/understanding of others), meeting perception_others criteria.
Experiment 2 MG1 involves mutual gaze without prior joint attention training; it is an interactive social condition addressing social processing (inter-individual synchronization analyses).
The task does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no relationship/bonding assessments), so affiliation_attachment is not appropriate.
Mutual gaze is an exchange of facial/eye signals (reception and production of facial communication), satisfying social communication criteria.
Analyses focus on interpersonal synchronization/perception of partner behavior rather than explicit self-perception or agency measures.
Mutual gaze requires perceiving partner's gaze/face and temporal coordination; it indexes perception and action-perception of others.
Experiment 2 MG2 (Day 2 mutual gaze) remains a dyadic social interaction; the neural synchronization analysis examines social processing between partners.
No measures of attachment or relationship formation are used, so affiliation/attachment annotation is not satisfied.
MG2 involves eye contact and interactive coordination, i.e., production/reception of facial/eye signals — social communication.
The analysis addresses inter-brain synchronization during interaction rather than explicit self-related cognitive judgments or agency measures.
MG2 examines perception of the partner's gaze/eye-blink timing and behavioral coordination, mapping to perception and understanding of others (action perception).
Experiment 3 MG1 (Day1 mutual gaze) is a face-to-face social interaction; analyses concern inter-individual synchronization and social processing.
The task does not measure affiliation/attachment or bonding explicitly, so this annotation is not applicable.
Mutual gaze constitutes exchange of facial/eye cues and real-time interactive signals, consistent with social communication.
This analysis focuses on interpersonal perception and synchronization rather than self-evaluative processes or agency metrics.
Mutual gaze requires perceiving the partner's gaze/expressions and coordinating timing (eye-blinks), fitting perception_others (action/animacy perception).
Experiment 3 MG2 (Day2 mutual gaze with a different partner) examines dyadic social interaction and inter-brain synchronization, a broad social process.
Although partner was swapped, the analysis does not probe attachment or bonding constructs specifically, so affiliation/attachment is not met.
MG2 with a different partner still involves reciprocal eye contact and exchange of social cues (gaze/blink coordination), meeting social communication criteria.
The focus is on inter-individual synchronization and perception of the other rather than explicit self-related cognitive processes or agency.
This condition entails perceiving and responding to another person's gaze and eye-blink timing, consistent with perception_others (action perception).
Eye-blink-related activation during MG2 is tied to shared attention and social coordination; it contributes to social processing of temporal attention windows between partners.
Eye-blink activation indexes attentional dynamics and does not assess attachment or bonding measures, so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
Eye-blink synchronization is used as a behavioral index of shared attention and interactive timing—an aspect of social communication (temporal coordination of signals).
Although blinks relate to internal attention shifts, the modeled activation relates to blink events and partner coordination rather than explicit self-awareness or self-knowledge measures.
Eye-blink timing and synchronization reflect perception of and coordination with the other's behavior (action perception), aligning with perception_others.

Contrast examines processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (DSG task) and how extraversion modulates neural responses — directly measures social processing.

The social gestures (friendly wave, handshake, beckoning, joint attention, imploring) are affiliative in nature and the contrast targets social intent (social vs nonsocial), fitting affiliation/attachment constructs.
The task uses dynamic gestures and facial information (face-visible vs blurred) and assesses reception of nonverbal/social cues — directly assesses social communication.
The contrast assesses perception of others' gestures and how personality modulates that processing; it does not measure self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge).

Participants perceive and interpret others' actions and social intent (action perception, animacy/intent), and the contrast probes neural responses to others' gestures — fits perception/understanding of others.
This analysis tests how neuroticism modulates neural responses to social features (actor-orientation, face-visibility) of gestures — clearly a social processing contrast.
Although effects may reflect perceived social rejection/threat, the task/contrast does not directly measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one contrasts).
Interaction involves face-visibility and actor-orientation which are core to reception of facial and non-facial communicative cues; the contrast assesses social communicative perception.
The contrast addresses perception of others' gestures and facial visibility, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge.
The interaction isolates action/face perception and inferred social intent (others’ orientation and facial cues) — directly probes perception and understanding of others.

The contrast (Attitude > Age) involves explicit control of interpersonal trust and distrust toward faces, a social-related task measuring social processing (evaluation and change of social attitudes).
The task manipulates interpersonal trust/distrust, which directly relates to affiliation/attachment processes (formation/modulation of social bonds and willingness to depend on others).
Participants evaluate facial stimuli for trustworthiness and are instructed to adopt mental stances toward others (trust/distrust), engaging receptive facial social communication processes.

The contrast focuses on evaluating others (trust/distrust) and changing interpersonal attitudes; it does not directly measure self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge processes required by this annotation (does not meet I1 for self-related processing).
The contrast explicitly targets perception and evaluation of others’ trustworthiness and intentions (mentalizing), matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.
Trust > Age isolates explicit control/up-regulation of interpersonal trust toward faces, a social task measuring social processing.
The trust condition modulates affiliative attitudes (increase in perceived trustworthiness), tapping affiliation/attachment-related processes.
Trust condition requires reception and interpretation of facial cues and social information (facial evaluation), fitting Social Communication reception subconstructs.
This contrast targets changing attitudes about others (trustworthiness) rather than self-related judgments or agency; it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Trust > Age examines judgments about others’ intentions/traits (trustworthiness), directly assessing perception and understanding of others (mentalizing).
Distrust > Age involves explicit control/down-regulation or formation of distrust toward faces — a social processing task.
The distrust condition modulates negative affiliative attitudes (reduced perceived trustworthiness), which relates to affiliation/attachment dynamics (avoidance, bonding).
Distrust condition requires interpretation of facial cues and assigning negative social meaning, engaging receptive social communication mechanisms (facial evaluation).
The contrast concerns evaluation of others (distrust) and not self-reflection or self-knowledge; it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Distrust > Age directly targets representations about others’ traits/intentions (negative attribution), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others (mentalizing).
Individual-differences analysis (Trust) links change-in-trust behavior to brain activity during the trust condition — a social processing measure of interpersonal attitude change.
This analysis examines individual variability in increasing trust (affiliative attitude formation), which pertains to affiliation/attachment processes.
Change-in-trust is derived from face-based evaluations and thus involves reception of facial social cues; the analysis probes neural correlates of this social-communication reception.
The individual-differences regressor indexes change in evaluations of others (trust) rather than self-related processes; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
This analysis tests how neural responses supporting mentalizing and representation of others (precuneus activity) relate to change in trust—directly assessing perception and understanding of others.
Individual-differences analysis (Distrust) relates change-in-distrust behavior to brain activity during the distrust condition — a social processing measure of interpersonal attitude change.
Change-in-distrust captures modulation of affiliative/attachment-related attitudes (reduced trustworthiness), so it pertains to affiliation/attachment processes.
This analysis links facial-evaluation-derived change scores (distrust) to neural activity, engaging receptive aspects of social communication (face-based interpretation).
The regressor indexes changes in evaluations about others (distrust) and not self-referential awareness or agency; it does not satisfy Perception/Self criteria.
The analysis explicitly probes representations and evaluation of others (IFG associated with distrust), matching Perception and Understanding of Others (mentalizing) criteria.
Precuneus Connectivity-Positive PPI examines networks whose connectivity with PrC relates to change-in-trust (a social attitude) — a social processing connectivity analysis.

The PPI identifies networks (mPFC, dlPFC, ACC, IPL) whose coupling with PrC scales with increased trust—these networks support affiliative/social-bonding-related processing, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
The connectivity analysis concerns neural systems supporting face-based social evaluations and mentalizing, implicating reception/processing of social communication cues.
The PPI targets connectivity related to changing evaluations of others (trust) and does not directly probe self-awareness or self-knowledge processes required for Perception/Self.
Precuneus connectivity related to change-in-trust reflects networks involved in representing and evaluating others (mentalizing, social cognition), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
IFG Connectivity-Negative PPI examines networks whose inverse coupling with left IFG relates to change-in-distrust — a social processing connectivity analysis about interpersonal attitude change.
Negative IFG connectivity associated with changing distrust implicates regulatory networks that modulate affiliative attitudes (withdrawal/avoidance), relevant to affiliation/attachment.
The PPI concerns neural systems engaged during facial social-evaluation (distrust) and their communication/interaction, fitting Social Communication reception/processing.
This connectivity analysis addresses representations and regulation of others' trustworthiness (distrust) rather than self-related processes; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
IFG connectivity tied to change-in-distrust reflects neural mechanisms for representing and evaluating others’ intentions/traits (mentalizing), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The study uses affective Theory of Mind cartoon tasks requiring participants to judge protagonists' emotional states—this is a social-related task assessing social processing broadly (emotion recognition, mentalizing).

The tasks and contrasts probe affective ToM and emotional facial expression detection, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or close relationships (no kinship/cooperation/ loved-one vs stranger comparisons).
Analyses involve perception of emotional facial expressions (EFE) and affect recognition as part of ToM judgments, which falls under Social Communication (reception of facial communication).
Analyses focus on inferring others' emotions (ToM) rather than self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency; no self-perception measures were used.
The core task is affective Theory of Mind—representing and inferring others' emotional states—which fits Perception and Understanding of Others (Understanding Mental States).
EFE > no EFE contrast tests how emotional facial expressions affect affective ToM judgments—directly assessing social processing.
Contrast compares presence vs absence of facial expressions during ToM judgments; it does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation/loved-one contrasts).
This contrast isolates processing of emotional facial expressions (reception of facial communication) during social judgments, meeting Social Communication inclusion.
Contrast addresses perception of others' emotions, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
EFE > no EFE examines inference about others' emotional states and how facial cues alter that process—directly about Perception and Understanding of Others.
No EFE > EFE contrast examines neural systems engaged when facial expressions are absent during affective ToM—still a social cognitive manipulation.
This contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs; it contrasts presence/absence of facial cues during ToM judgments rather than relationship/bond measures.

Even when facial expressions are absent, the task concerns interpreting social cues and emotions; the contrast reflects aspects of social communication (reception/interpretation of communicative signals or their absence).
The contrast pertains to inferring others' emotional states and associated network engagement, not self-perception or agency.
No EFE > EFE probes mechanisms used to understand others' emotions when facial information is lacking—this is squarely Perception and Understanding of Others (mental state inference).
This correlation links neural differential activation (EFE > no EFE) to RT reduction by EFE in an affective ToM task, reflecting social processing mechanisms affecting behavior.
The correlation concerns task performance and neural response related to emotion/ToM processing, not affiliation or attachment measures.

Because the neural differential activation pertains to processing of emotional facial expressions (EFE) and its behavioral facilitation, this analysis indexes social communication (reception of facial cues) relevance.
The analysis relates neural and behavioral indices of perceiving others' emotions, not self-related judgments or introspection.
The analysis directly concerns inference about others (how EFE-driven neural activation relates to improved ToM RT), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Correlation of differential activation no EFE > EFE with RT reduction examines social cognitive processing when facial cues are absent—part of social processing domain.
This analysis does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs; it examines neural/behavioral effects tied to ToM and facial cue absence.
Although focused on absence of facial expressions, the analysis still evaluates processing/interpretation of social cues and their behavioral impact, relevant to Social Communication.
This correlation pertains to perceiving and reasoning about others' emotions rather than self-related processes.
The analysis targets mechanisms used to understand others' emotional states when facial cues are absent, aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.
This interaction assesses how EFE effects differ with explicit demand for affective ToM—clearly a social-processing manipulation examining mentalizing under different stimulus conditions.
The interaction concerns task demand and facial-expression presence during ToM, not affiliation/attachment measures (no bonding or relationship variables).
The interaction probes whether facial-expression signals modulate social communicative processing (reception/interpretation) specifically when affective ToM is demanded—fits Social Communication.
This analysis manipulates demands to infer others' emotions, not self-related perception or introspection.
The contrast directly examines inference about others' emotional states under varying conditions (ToM demand × EFE), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Complementary interaction contrast testing EFE effects across ToM demand again probes social cognitive processing of emotions—social processing domain applies.
This contrast does not target affiliation or attachment constructs; it manipulates EFE and ToM demand only.
As a contrast examining facial-expression effects under differing ToM demands, it indexes social communication processes (reception/interpretation of facial cues) and is included.
The analysis concerns understanding others' emotions under task manipulations, not self-related perception or agency.
This contrast evaluates how the brain infers others' affective states depending on EFE and task demand—core Perception and Understanding of Others.
PPI examines task-dependent connectivity between right BLA and ToM network regions modulated by EFE during affective ToM—this is a social-processing connectivity analysis.
PPI targets amygdala-ToM connectivity related to processing facial expressions, not affiliation/ attachment constructs or relationship-specific processing.

PPI tests how processing of emotional facial expressions modulates connectivity with regions involved in interpreting others' social signals—relevant to Social Communication (reception/interpretation).
Connectivity analysis focuses on networks for perceiving others' emotions and does not probe self-perception or self-related processes.
The PPI addresses how amygdala interactions support inferring others' emotional states (EFE-dependent), directly within Perception and Understanding of Others.
Positive correlations between affective ToM matching (behavioral) and PPI effects relate neural connectivity to social cognitive performance—broad social processing.
Correlations link ToM performance and connectivity; no measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific variables are included.

Because the behavioral measure indexes matching of inferred emotional states (often aided by facial signals) and its relation to connectivity, this addresses Social Communication (reception/interpretation).
The correlation examines performance inferring others' emotions and neural connectivity, not self-related perception or self-knowledge.
This analysis ties PPI connectivity to accuracy of understanding others' affective states (matching with consensus), directly fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Negative correlations between affective ToM matching and PPI effects still probe relationships between neural connectivity and social-cognitive performance—within social processing.
These correlations do not assess affiliation/attachment constructs; they relate ToM performance to connectivity, not relationship measures.
Negative correlations involve how connectivity relates to accuracy of inferred emotions (a communicative/receptive social function), meeting Social Communication inclusion.
The analysis is about inferring others' emotions and connectivity, not self-related perception or agency.
This analysis links neural connectivity to performance at understanding others' emotional states—directly Perception and Understanding of Others.

Negative vs. positive performance feedback contrast involves responses to social feedback (verbal evaluative comments) and induction of social-emotional states; it directly probes social processing of feedback and resultant affective/social-cognitive processing.

The feedback and reward/punishment manipulation affect social evaluation and bonding-relevant processes (receiving approval vs. criticism) and relate to affiliation/attachment constructs (positive vs. negative social feedback).
The contrast hinges on reception of verbal feedback (socially communicative utterances: 'That was bad' vs 'That was good'), so it measures reception of social communication.

Negative vs. positive feedback elicits changes in participants’ own emotional state and awareness (valence ratings, respiration, SCR), tapping processes of self-perception and internal state representation.
Processing feedback also involves inferring the intent and meaning behind the communicator’s evaluation (why they judged performance as bad/good), engaging representation of others’ mental states.
EE > EN contrasts responses to emotionally empathic versus unempathic verbal comments, directly probing social-emotional processing of interpersonal support and its neural correlates.
Emotionally empathic vs. unempathic comments manipulate social support and bonding signals (compassion vs. indifference), which map onto affiliation/attachment processes.
This contrast is based on reception of verbally expressed empathy or lack thereof, a clear social communication manipulation (receptive processing of affective speech).
Hearing empathic vs. unempathic comments influences participants’ self-reported feelings and internal state, implicating self-perception and affective self-monitoring.
Differentiating empathic from unempathic utterances requires inferring the speaker’s affective stance and intentions, engaging understanding of others’ mental states.
(EN+CN) > (EE+CE) contrasts unempathic vs. empathic comments, indexing social processing of denial vs. provision of empathy and its emotional/neural consequences.
Unempathic comments (indifference, lack of understanding) versus empathic comments directly manipulate signals relevant to affiliation and attachment (social rejection vs. support).
This contrast tests how different types of verbal social communication (unempathic vs. empathic) are received and processed, fulfilling social communication criteria.
Unempathic vs. empathic comments modulate participants’ internal affective state and ratings, implicating processes of self-perception and affective awareness.
Distinguishing unempathic from empathic remarks involves attributing intentions and mental states to the speaker, engaging perception/understanding of others.
CN > CE contrasts cognitively unempathic vs. cognitively empathic comments, probing social cognitive processing related to understanding/denial of understanding another’s state.
Cognitive unempathic comments ("I don't understand") vs. cognitive empathic comments affect perceived social support/validation and hence affiliation-related processes.
The contrast manipulates reception of verbal communicative content (paraphrasing/understanding vs. denial thereof), a social communication manipulation.
These cognitively framed comments influence participants’ own appraisal and emotional state (valence ratings), engaging self-perception and introspection.

Cognitive empathy specifically taps mentalizing and understanding of others; even when presented to recipients, processing involves representing the speaker’s mentalizing stance, thus perception of others.
Empathic (EE+CE) > baseline compares processing of empathic comments during distress vs. a non-distressed baseline, indexing social processing of support in context.
Receiving empathic comments when distressed vs. baseline taps affiliation-related processes (support, bonding, perceived understanding) relevant to attachment dynamics.
This contrast tests how empathic verbal communications are processed differently from baseline statements, a social communication effect.
Comparing empathic comments during distress vs. baseline examines changes in subjects’ internal affective state and self-reported feelings, implicating self-perception.
Processing empathic comments in a distress context involves attributing supportive intent and mental states to the speaker, engaging perception of others’ mental states.
EE > baseline isolates neural response to emotionally empathic comments compared with non-distressed baseline, directly probing social-emotional processing of compassion statements.
Emotionally empathic comments are explicit signals of social support/compassion, relevant to affiliation and attachment processes when contrasted with baseline.
This contrast involves reception of affective verbal communication (compassion statements), fulfilling social communication inclusion criteria.
Emotionally empathic comments modulate recipients’ internal affect and subjective feelings (measured behaviorally), implicating self-perception processes.
Interpreting emotionally empathic comments requires inferring the speaker’s empathic stance and intentions, engaging representation of others’ mental states.
CE > baseline focuses on cognitively empathic (paraphrasing/understanding) comments versus baseline, indexing social cognitive processing of being understood.
Cognitive empathy (paraphrasing) signals social validation and connection, relevant to affiliation/attachment when compared with baseline.
This contrast examines response to communicative acts that state understanding (verbal paraphrase), a social communication manipulation.
Cognitive empathic comments influence participants’ felt state and appraisal (valence ratings), engaging self-awareness and self-perception.
Cognitive empathy entails mentalizing; recipients’ processing of such comments involves attributing understanding to the speaker, engaging perception of others’ mental states.
(EE+EN) > (CE+CN) contrasts emotional vs. cognitive interventions overall, addressing social processing differences between affective and mentalizing-oriented communications.
Emotional interventions (compassionate language) versus cognitive ones modulate signals of affiliation and attachment and thus tap this construct.
This contrast tests different types of verbal social communication (affective vs. cognitive empathy), directly within social communication domain.
Emotional vs. cognitive comments are likely to differentially affect recipients’ internal affective state and self-report, implicating self-perception.
Differentiating emotional and cognitive empathy involves representing the speaker’s affective vs. mentalizing stance, engaging understanding of others’ mental states.
EE > CE directly contrasts emotionally empathic with cognitively empathic comments, probing social processing differences between compassion and mentalizing statements.
Emotionally empathic (compassion) vs. cognitive empathic comments differentially signal affiliation/support versus understanding, engaging attachment-related processing.
This contrast involves reception of two types of social communicative acts (affective vs. cognitive empathy), squarely within social communication.
Comparing emotional and cognitive empathy examines their differential impact on participants’ feelings and self-reported valence, implicating self-perception.
Differentiating EE from CE requires inferring the speaker’s emotional vs. mentalizing intent, engaging representation and understanding of others’ mental states.
EN > CN contrasts emotional unempathic vs. cognitive unempathic comments, evaluating social processing of different forms of unempathic communication.
Unempathic emotional statements (indifference) vs. unempathic cognitive statements (lack of understanding) differentially signal rejection vs. lack of validation, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast examines reception of different unempathic verbal communications and their processing, meeting social communication criteria.
Different unempathic statements modulate participants’ affective state and valence ratings, implicating self-perception and emotional awareness.
Interpreting unempathic comments requires inferring speaker stance and intentions (e.g., indifference vs. lack of understanding), engaging perception of others.
CN > EN contrasts cognitive unempathic vs. emotional unempathic comments and probes social-cognitive processing of different forms of unempathic communications.
These unempathic contrasts alter perceived social support/rejection signals (lack of understanding vs. indifference), impacting affiliation-related processing.
This contrast examines processing of differing verbal unempathic communications (cognitive vs. emotional), i.e., social communicative content reception.
Unempathic comments of different types influence participants’ emotional state and self-reported feelings, tapping self-perception processes.
Distinguishing between types of unempathic comments requires attributing mental states and motives to the speaker, implicating perception of others’ mental states.

Task uses naturalistic social-evaluative videos (positive, negative, neutral) requiring processing of social cues, emotion, and interpersonal evaluation; the contrasts (e.g., negative>neutral) directly measure social processing networks (MPFC, rACC, amygdala, insula).

Positive videos express praise/appreciation (affiliative signals) and negative videos express social disapproval; the paradigm probes responses to social bonding/affiliation-relevant cues, so it measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Stimuli are audiovisual statements directed at the participant; task requires reception of facial, vocal and verbal social communication (affective content), matching inclusion criteria for Social Communication.

Participants were instructed to imagine the statements as directed to themselves, engaging self-referential and evaluative processes (supported by MPFC/rACC activation); contrasts therefore probe perception/understanding of self.
Task involves perceiving and interpreting posers' social-evaluative intent and mental states (mentalizing), and contrasts capture neural responses related to understanding others’ evaluations.
Same dataset/contrast set (positive>neutral) and naturalistic social-evaluative task that measures broad social processing (MPFC, rACC involvement); thus meets Social Processing inclusion.
Positive (praise/appreciation) condition probes affiliative signaling and participants' responses to affiliative social cues, meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
The positive videos require reception of affective verbal and non-verbal communication directed at the participant (receptive social communication).
Participants imagine the statements addressed to themselves; positive evaluations engage self-referential processing (consistent with MPFC activity), so Perception/Self applies.
Interpretation of the posers’ intentions and mental states (why they praise/criticize) involves understanding others and mentalizing, so Perception/Others applies.
This analysis (conjunction of positive>neutral & negative>neutral) isolates common social-evaluative processing; clearly measures broad social processing networks (MPFC/rACC, temporal regions).
Conjunction includes both praise and criticism; positive arm indexes affiliative signals and the conjunction captures shared affiliation/attachment-relevant processing across valences.
Conjunction reflects processing of communicative social signals (audiovisual statements) common to positive and negative evaluations—meets Social Communication inclusion.
Conjunction implicates MPFC/rACC associated with self-referential/mentalizing processes when statements are imagined as self-directed; thus Perception/Self applies.
Conjunction captures neural systems supporting understanding of the posers’ evaluative intent (mental state inference) common across valences, so Perception/Others applies.

The contrast examines neural responses to Black vs White faces related to racial trust disparity—a social cognition task involving perception and evaluation of social others, meeting criteria for Social Processing.

Trustworthiness judgments and racial trust disparity directly tap affiliation/approach-related evaluations and social bonding tendencies, so this analysis measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.
The task involves reception of facial signals (trustworthiness cues) and evaluation of faces—core aspects of social communication (receptive facial communication).
The contrast indexes perception and evaluation of others (faces) and later trustworthiness ratings—not self-related awareness or judgments, so it does not measure Perception/Self.
This analysis assesses representations and evaluations of others’ traits (trustworthiness) and intergroup differences—directly fitting Perception/Understanding of Others.
This contrast links neural activity (Black>White) to reduced racial trust disparity—an evaluative social-cognitive process, satisfying Social Processing criteria.
The finding concerns orbitofrontal activation predicting less trust disparity; OFC relates to approach/liking and affiliation, so the analysis measures affiliation/attachment-relevant evaluations.
OFC activation to faces and its relation to trustworthiness involves reception of facial affective signals—within Social Communication.
The analysis concerns perception/evaluation of other people (faces), not self-related processes, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The analysis examines neural representations and evaluations of others’ trustworthiness (Black vs White), directly fitting Perception/Understanding of Others.
This PPI contrast (OFC-fusiform connectivity predicting less trust disparity) probes social-evaluative neural mechanisms when perceiving faces—squarely Social Processing.

Connectivity between affective (OFC) and perceptual (fusiform) regions predicting reduced trust disparity implicates affiliation/approach evaluations (trust), so it measures affiliation/attachment processes.
The analysis involves processing of facial cues and their affective interpretation via connectivity—consistent with reception of facial communication.
This connectivity analysis concerns perception/evaluation of others (faces) and trust judgments, not self-referential processing, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
OFC–fusiform coupling predicting intergroup differences in trust reflects representations and evaluation of others’ traits, meeting Perception/Understanding of Others.

This contrast links neural responses to Black vs White faces with later racial differentiation disparity (how well participants differentiate others)—a social perception/cognition task, so Social Processing applies.
Racial differentiation disparity measures the granularity of perceiving others, not affiliation/attachment or relational bonding, so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Differentiation of face trustworthiness depends on reception and discrimination of facial signals—within Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
The analysis concerns perception of others (face differentiation), not self-related awareness or judgments, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
This analysis measures how participants represent and discriminate others’ traits (trustworthiness), directly fitting Perception/Understanding of Others.
This contrast identifies regions where greater activation to Black>White predicts less differentiation disparity—an aspect of social cognition and thus Social Processing.
Although differentiation may influence social interactions, this analysis measures perceptual/cognitive individuation rather than direct affiliation or attachment processes, so exclude.
Activation in prefrontal regions linked to differentiation involves processing and interpretation of facial information—consistent with Social Communication (receptive facial processing).
The focus is on perceiving and differentiating other people’s faces and trustworthiness, not on self-related cognition; thus Perception/Self is not included.
The analysis assesses individuation/differentiation of others’ traits and representations—directly fitting Perception/Understanding of Others.
This PPI (dlPFC–cingulate connectivity predicting less differentiation disparity) examines control-related neural mechanisms in perceiving others—part of social cognition, so include.
The dlPFC–cingulate connectivity relates to perceptual differentiation/control rather than direct measures of affiliation or attachment, so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Connectivity that supports differentiation of facial trustworthiness reflects reception and processing of facial information—within Social Communication.
The analysis indexes neural processes for representing others (face individuation), not self-related perception or introspection, so Perception/Self is excluded.
The PPI result predicts how well participants represent and discriminate others’ traits (trustworthiness), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

The Meaning > Physical contrast explicitly manipulates an interpretive attitude that elicits social-cognition networks (mPFC, TPJ, IFG). This contrasts a social/meaning-focused task vs a non-social/physical task, so it directly measures social processing.
The contrast probes semantic/social meaning broadly but does not measure affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment-specific processes.

The meaning-related task requires participants to read LEGO models as communicative symbols (semantic/expressive interpretation), engaging regions tied to social semantic processing—consistent with social communication measures.
Meaning > Physical manipulates mode of construal but does not specifically probe self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge.

The meaning-related task recruits mentalizing regions (mPFC, TPJ) associated with representing others' intentions/meanings; thus it measures processes involved in understanding others’ social meaning.

The Physical > Meaning contrast focuses participants on physical properties (fragility/robustness) and activates perceptual/motor regions (fusiform, precentral), not social-cognition networks; it does not measure social processing.
This contrast addresses physical/perceptual features and does not probe affiliation, bonding, or cooperation.
The task emphasizes object physical properties rather than communicative or expressive content, so it does not measure social communication.
No self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge processes are targeted by this physical-properties contrast.
The contrast does not require representation or inference about others’ states or intentions; it assesses perceptual/physical processing only.

The Own > Other (meaning-related) contrast directly probes self vs other models under a meaning/social judgment; it activated social-cognition regions (mPFC, ACC, TPJ), indicating measurement of social processing.

Although this contrast compares self-produced vs others' models, it does not specifically index affiliation/attachment or cooperation measures (no bond/cooperation manipulation reported for this contrast).

The contrast contrasts self vs other possessions and is more about self/episodic memory and agency than communicative exchange per se; it does not directly target reception/production of social communication.

Own > Other explicitly contrasts perception/understanding of stimuli produced by the participant (self) vs others, engaging self-related/autobiographical and agency regions (precuneus, mPFC, ACC). This meets the Perception/Self criterion.

Because this contrast is an explicit own > other comparison, it necessarily involves representation and contrast with others’ products; it probes processes relevant to perceiving/understanding others (by comparison).

The interaction (Own>Other × Collective>Individual) isolates responses to one’s own collective models and activated ACC, IFG, and insula—areas implicated in social/emotional and social-cognition processing—so it measures social processing.

This interaction specifically contrasts collective (cooperative) vs individual constructions in an own vs other framework, and the authors further linked the effect to self-reported relatedness. That directly indexes affiliation/attachment processes (social bonding/cooperation).

Own collective models were created and interpreted as vehicles of shared meaning (communicative artifacts), and the interaction engages regions tied to social/emotional signaling (IFG, insula), mapping onto social-communication constructs.

The interaction centers on responses to one’s own collective products (own vs other), engaging self-related/agency and autobiographical regions (ACC, precuneus), so it measures perception/self-related processes.

Because the interaction contrasts own versus other models (within collective/individual contexts), it necessarily involves representing others’ contributions and thus probes perception/understanding of others.

The contrast compares high-frequency social interaction in the ball-toss task vs. control (button-press) and isolates social interaction effects; the task is explicitly social and the activation (precuneus cluster) is discussed as reflecting self-image and representation of increased social interaction, fulfilling broad social processing.

The ball-toss high-frequency manipulation increases affiliative social interaction and enjoyment (experience effects); the precuneus activation is interpreted in relation to social relationships and reputation/self-image tied to forming/maintaining bonds, so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.

Although the task lacks spoken language, the ball-toss paradigm is an exchange-based social interaction that entails reciprocal, communicative behavior (who tosses to whom); the contrast targets social exchange dynamics and their neural correlates, meeting social communication criteria.

The precuneus is a canonical self-related region and the authors explicitly interpret activation as reflecting positive self-image/self-processing in response to increased social interaction; the contrast therefore indexes self-related processing.

The ball-toss task requires tracking other players’ actions and outcomes (who receives/tosses the ball), engaging representations of others’ behaviors and social status; the contrast thus implicates perception/understanding of others.

The right ventral striatum cluster emerges from the social (ball-toss) high-frequency > control contrast and is interpreted as representing social reward arising from increased social interaction, satisfying broad social processing.

The contrast manipulates frequency of social inclusion (more tosses to participant) which indexes affiliative reward and bonding; ventral striatum activation is discussed as coding social reward motivating affiliation/attachment.

The task involves reciprocal social exchange (ball passing) as a form of nonverbal social communication; the ventral striatal response reflects processing of this socially exchanged reward, meeting social communication inclusion.

Authors relate ventral striatal activation to experienced vs. expected social reward and link it to individual preferences and self-related valuation; thus the contrast taps self-related valuation processes.

The ventral striatal activation arises from observing/receiving social behavior from others (increased tosses), which requires representing others’ actions and social attention; therefore it implicates perception/understanding of others.

The contrast Social-Reg > Social-Look isolates socially-induced emotion regulation (a social task with a psychotherapist regulator). This directly addresses social processing (social cognition, interaction), meeting inclusion I1.

Although the study measured attachment separately, the contrast Social-Reg > Social-Look itself does not directly measure affiliation/attachment processes or contrasts (no attachment-specific condition); therefore it does not meet the requirement to be an affiliation/attachment task.

The Social-Reg condition involves explicit communicative instructions from a psychotherapist (videoed instructional communication) versus look; the contrast therefore captures effects of social communication (receptive processing of a regulator's communicative input), satisfying I1 and I2.

Social-Reg trials included self-report ratings of internal affect and involve implementation of reappraisal strategies (self-referential and self-monitoring aspects). The contrast thus indexes processes related to perception/understanding of the self (I1, I2).
Social-Reg uniquely recruits mentalizing regions (TPJ, dmPFC, precuneus) linked to representing others' intentions; the contrast isolates perception/understanding of others, meeting I1 and I2.

The conjunction (Reg>Look)_Social ∩ (Reg>Look)_Self identifies common regulatory network across Social- and Self-Reg. Because one of the tasks is socially-induced regulation, the analysis pertains to social processing broadly (I1).

This conjunction identifies common neural mechanisms of regulation but does not probe affiliation/attachment specifically (no attachment manipulation or contrast), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The conjunction isolates shared control regions (dorsolateral/dorsomedial PFC, inferior parietal) common to both tasks; it does not specifically index communicative exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals, so it does not meet the social_communication criteria.

The conjunction includes regions recruited during Self-Reg as well as Social-Reg; Self-Reg involves self-referential regulation and internal state monitoring (ratings), so this analysis indexes perception/understanding of the self (I1).

Although Social-Reg involves others, the conjunction shows regions common to both Social- and Self-Reg and does not selectively capture mentalizing/perception-of-others regions (these were found in the interaction/distinct Social-Reg contrast), so it does not fulfill the perception_others inclusion.
This contrast isolates areas more engaged in Social-Reg than Self-Reg (dmPFC, TPJ, precuneus) which are core social cognition regions; it therefore directly measures social processing (I1).

The contrast identifies neural regions specific to Social-Reg but does not itself manipulate or measure affiliation/attachment (no attachment-specific condition or contrast), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.

Social-Reg relies on communicative input from a psychotherapist and this contrast pinpoints regions (TPJ, dmPFC) engaged more during the socially communicated regulation; it therefore indexes social communication processes (I1 and I2).

Distinct Social-Reg activations include precuneus and medial PFC which are implicated in self-referential processing and perspective-taking; Social-Reg requires integrating the other's instruction with one's own experience, so this analysis taps aspects of self-perception/understanding (I1).

The Social-specific regions (left TPJ, dmPFC, precuneus) are canonical mentalizing/other-representation areas; this contrast therefore directly indexes perception and understanding of others (I1 and I2).
This contrast isolates regions more engaged during Self-Reg than Social-Reg. Self-Reg is an intrapersonal task (no social regulator), so this analysis does not reflect social processing per se.
The Self-Reg-specific contrast does not manipulate or measure affiliation/attachment processes; attachment measures were examined separately, not in this contrast.

Self-Reg uses internal, written cues rather than interpersonal communicative input; the distinct Self-Reg activations (e.g., left IFG) reflect cognitive control/language, not social communication, so this does not meet social_communication criteria.

This contrast identifies regions preferentially engaged during self-initiated regulation (Self-Reg) which involves self-monitoring and internal state regulation; thus it indexes perception/understanding of the self (I1, I2).
The Self-Reg-specific contrast does not target representation or understanding of others (no social regulator), so it does not satisfy perception_others criteria.

Contrast compares aggressive reaction to a provoking opponent vs non-aggressive reaction to a non-provoking opponent in the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social interactive task measuring responses to another agent’s behavior — therefore it indexes social processing.

The contrast arises from a competitive social interaction (TAP) which involves interpersonal dynamics (competition/provocation). Competition is listed as an example under affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria, so the task relates to social bonding/interaction constructs.

The task involves exchange of socially-relevant signals (chosen noise levels, outcomes, intercom) and behavior contingent on opponent actions; contrast indexes communicative/socially contingent interaction.

This contrast probes retaliatory behavior in response to provocation and does not specifically measure self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency judgments; the primary focus is on interactive aggressive behavior rather than explicit self-perception.
Participants must perceive and evaluate the opponent’s provocation level and adjust behavior accordingly, which reflects perception/understanding of others’ actions and intentions.

This contrast (non-aggressive reaction to non-provoking opponent > aggressive reaction to provoking opponent) involves social interaction and responses to another agent, thus indexing social processing.

The contrast concerns behavior in a competitive/social interaction (non-provoking vs provoking opponent). Although not measuring positive bonding, it taps competition/cooperation dimensions included under affiliation/attachment criteria.
The contrast captures communicative aspects of the interaction (choices of feedback/noise as social signals), so it relates to social communication processes.
The contrast reflects externally-directed behavioral differences in response to opponents and does not specifically probe self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
Differentiating responses to non-provoking vs provoking opponents requires representing and interpreting others’ behavior and intentions, matching perception of others.
Won > lost contrast occurs within the TAP social interaction and reflects social outcomes (interaction with opponent), thus indexing social processing.
Winning/losing are outcomes of a competitive social interaction; competition is encompassed by the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples, so the contrast is relevant to this construct.
Winning and losing convey social information between agents (including administered feedback); the contrast captures aspects of communicative social exchange and its neural correlates.
The contrast indexes reward-related responses to outcomes rather than explicit self-referential judgments or self-knowledge processes; no direct self-perception measure is present.
Interpreting win/loss outcomes requires assessing others’ actions and the social consequences of their choices (e.g., anticipating opponent feedback), therefore it engages perception of others.
Lost > won is a social outcome contrast within the interactive TAP, reflecting processing of socially-significant events and thus counts as social processing.
Losing vs winning occurs in a competitive social context; as competition is encompassed by the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples, this contrast is relevant to that construct.
Losing conveys socially-relevant signals (e.g., receiving aversive feedback) and involves interpretation of social cues, so it pertains to social communication.
This contrast emphasizes reactions to externally delivered outcomes (losing) rather than explicit self-awareness or self-evaluative processes.
Losing entails anticipating and interpreting the opponent’s chosen feedback and intentions; hence it engages perception of others’ actions and intentions.
Won against the provoking opponent > won against the non-provoking opponent compares socially-contextualized outcomes against different opponents — a social processing contrast.
This contrast differentiates outcomes depending on opponent type within a competitive social interaction; competition/opponent differences align with affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.
Distinguishing wins against different opponents involves decoding socially-relevant differences (provocation level) and thus relates to social communication between agents.
This contrast examines outcome differences by opponent provocation and does not measure self-related judgments or explicit self-awareness.
Comparing wins against provoking vs non-provoking opponents requires representing the opponent’s behavior and its social meaning, engaging perception of others.
Won against non-provoking > won against provoking is a social contrast within the TAP, reflecting processing of outcomes contingent on opponent behavior.
The contrast involves competition and interpersonal outcome differences across opponent types, which falls under the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples (competition/cooperation).
Winning against different opponents conveys different social signals; the contrast therefore indexes aspects of social communication and signaling between agents.
Focus is on outcome differences tied to the opponent rather than on measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
Discriminating outcomes by opponent provocation requires understanding others’ behavior and likely intentions, thus engaging perception of others.
Lost against provoking > lost against non-provoking examines social outcomes dependent on opponent type within the interactive TAP, hence social processing.
This contrast assesses differential responses within a competitive social context (provoking vs non-provoking opponent), aligning with the affiliation/attachment examples (competition).
Losing to different opponents involves processing socially-relevant cues about opponents’ behavior and anticipated feedback, implicating social communication.
The contrast emphasizes perception of outcome and opponent behavior rather than explicit self-reflection or self-knowledge.
Interpreting losses against a provoking vs non-provoking opponent requires attributing different states/intentions to the opponent, engaging perception of others.
Lost against non-provoking > lost against provoking contrasts social outcomes depending on opponent type within TAP — a social processing contrast.
As a competition-based outcome contrast across opponent types, it pertains to interpersonal dynamics and competition which are included under affiliation/attachment examples.
This contrast concerns processing socially-salient feedback and opponent behavior, reflecting social communication between agents.
This analysis focuses on responses to opponent behavior (outcome) rather than measures of self-awareness or self-evaluation.
Differentiating losses by opponent type requires representing opponents’ actions and intentions, consistent with perception of others.
Parametric modulations examine how brain activity scales with magnitude of retaliation in a social interactive task, thus indexing social processing.

Parametric modulation of retaliation occurs within a competitive interpersonal context (TAP). The gradient of aggressive responses in competition relates to affiliation/attachment inclusion examples (competition/cooperation).
Parametric effects reflect graded social signaling (amount of punishment chosen) and thus pertain to social communication processes (production of socially meaningful signals).

Although the parametric regressors index participants’ choices, the analyses aim to relate choice magnitude to brain activity in an interactive social context rather than to probe explicit self-awareness or self-knowledge processes.
Modulation of activity by chosen retaliation implies evaluation of the opponent and adjustment of behavior accordingly, engaging perception and understanding of others’ provocations and actions.
Retaliation independent of opponent examines aggressive behavior within an interpersonal context (TAP) and thus indexes social processing broadly.
This analysis captures aggression in a competitive social setting regardless of opponent type; competition-based interpersonal behavior falls under the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.
Retaliation levels represent socially communicative acts (punishment signals) directed at another agent, so this analysis maps onto social communication.
The focus is on retaliatory actions and their neural modulation rather than explicit measures of self-perception or self-reflection.
Even when collapsed across opponent types, retaliation reflects responses to perceived actions of others and requires representing others’ behavior, fitting perception of others.
Retaliation interacting with provoking opponent explicitly probes social behavior in response to another agent’s provocative actions — clearly a social processing analysis.

This analysis examines competitive/retaliatory responses specifically to a provoking opponent; such competition/provocation dynamics are within the affiliation/attachment domain per inclusion examples.
The analysis links graded punishment choices (social signals) to neural responses specifically when interacting with a provocative opponent, indexing production and interpretation of social signals.
The analysis targets neural correlates of behavior toward an opponent (retaliation magnitude) rather than assessing self-awareness or self-knowledge explicitly.
Because it isolates responses to a provoking opponent, this analysis requires representing the opponent’s provocations and intentions, engaging perception of others.
Retaliation interacting with non-provoking opponent examines social interactive responses (even if rare) and thus is a social processing measure.

This analysis assesses behavior in a competitive interpersonal context (interaction with non-provoking opponent); competition/cooperation scenarios fall under affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.
Choosing punishment levels toward a non-provoking opponent still constitutes production of socially informative signals and thus maps onto social communication.
Although participants did make choices, the contrast does not aim to probe self-referential processes or self-knowledge explicitly; it addresses social responding instead.
Interacting with the non-provoking opponent requires assessing the opponent’s behavior and intentions (even if behavior is non-provocative), thus engaging perception of others.
This 'Won' contrast examines outcome processing in a social competitive task (TAP) and therefore indexes social processing.
Winning is an interpersonal outcome in a competitive context; competition-related dynamics fit within the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.
Winning conveys socially-relevant information and involves response to opponent behavior/feedback, implicating social communication processes.

While outcomes could affect self-related states, the analysis focuses on reward/outcome processing rather than explicit self-evaluative or self-knowledge measures, so it does not meet Perception_Self criteria.
Interpreting a win involves anticipating and understanding opponents’ actions and their intended feedback, engaging perception of others.
Won against provoking opponent examines social outcomes contingent on opponent provocation within TAP and thus is social processing.
Winning specifically against a provoking opponent is an interpersonal competitive outcome; competition/provocation dynamics relate to affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.
This contrast distinguishes social outcomes based on opponent behavior (provocation), reflecting communicative/social signaling between agents.
The analysis focuses on differential outcomes relative to opponent type rather than explicit self-referential judgments, so does not meet Perception_Self criteria.
Winning against a provoking opponent requires understanding the opponent’s provocations and intentions, engaging perception of others.
Won against non-provoking opponent contrasts social outcomes by opponent type in the TAP social interaction and therefore indexes social processing.
Winning against a non-provoking opponent involves interpersonal competitive outcomes; the contrast falls under competition aspects included in the affiliation/attachment criteria.
This contrast reflects differential social signaling and feedback contingent on opponent type and thus concerns social communication processes.
Focus is on outcome differences and opponent type rather than explicit self-awareness or self-knowledge measures, so Perception_Self is not met.
Determining differences in wins against a non-provoking opponent requires representing opponent behavior and intentions, matching perception of others.

Contrast SocAdj > PhyConf directly compares social (mental-state) scenarios requiring contextual adjustment against physical baseline; this measures social processing (theory of mind).
The contrast probes general mentalizing/context integration, not affiliation/attachment (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation).
Task uses written scenarios to infer mental states rather than measuring exchange/communication (no reception/production of communicative signals).
Contrast focuses on inferring others' mental states and context integration, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
SocAdj involves representing and updating others' mental states; contrast isolates social (other-focused) inference processes vs physical.
Response-period SocAdj > PhyConf replicates classical ToM localizer and engages social/mentalizing processes at decision time.
No measures of affiliation/attachment, close relationships, or bonding are present in the response contrast.
Contrast indexes inference and contextual integration rather than communication dynamics (no reception/production of communicative acts).
Contrast targets understanding of others' mental states, not self-perception or self-judgments.
Response-phase contrast engages representation and integration of others' mental states (ToM), meeting understanding-others criteria.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 1 contrasts social vs physical scenarios (social inferences triggered by first sentence); measures social processing.
Time-point 1 contrast compares general social vs physical content but not affiliation/attachment constructs.
This early contrast examines spontaneous mental-state inferences rather than communicative signal reception/production.
Contrast indexes perception/representation of others (not self-related processing).
Soc > Phy isolates processes involved in representing others' intentions/mental states when reading the initial scenario.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 2 examines social vs physical when context is present; includes social processing and mentalizing.
The contrast concerns general social mentalizing rather than affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast taps mental-state representation and integration, not communicative exchange metrics.
Focus remains on others' mental states and contextual integration, not self-perception.
Time-point 2 Soc > Phy isolates processes for understanding others' mental states with context, matching this construct.
Soc > Phy during the Response period captures social inference processes engaged when making decisions about others' mental states.
Response contrast reflects general ToM/context integration rather than affiliation or bonding measures.
The decision-phase contrast concerns reasoning about mental states, not communicative production/reception.
Contrast pertains to others' mental-state reasoning, not self-related judgments or agency.
Response-period Soc > Phy engages representation and judgment about others' intentions and mental states, fitting this annotation.

Adj > Conf at Time-point 2 compares contextual adjustment vs confirmation across social and physical scenarios; because it includes social trials it partially measures social processing (contextualized social inferences are included).
This contrast targets contextual updating processes across domains, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Adj > Conf indexes updating/integration demands rather than communicative signal processing.
Contrast concerns contextual adjustment of inferences about events/agents, not self-perception or self-judgment.

Although pooled with physical trials, the Adj > Conf contrast includes social adjustment trials (SocAdj vs SocConf) and therefore taps aspects of understanding others' mental states when they must be updated by context.
Adj > Conf during the Response period captures contextual adjustment effects that include social trials (thus measuring social processing components during decision-making).
Contrast indexes general contextual updating and control processes rather than affiliation/attachment measures.
The contrast addresses integration/updating of contextual information, not communicative exchange per se.
This analysis concerns updating inferences about scenarios (including others) rather than self-related judgments.
Adj > Conf includes social adjustment trials at response time (SocAdj vs SocConf) so it engages understanding/updating of others' mental states and thus matches this construct.
SocAdj is a social condition (mental-state inference with contextual adjustment); this clearly measures social processing/ToM.
The SocAdj condition involves general mentalizing and context-updating, not affiliation/attachment-specific constructs.
While social, the trial asks inferential judgments about intentions rather than measuring communicative signal reception/production.
SocAdj focuses on others' mental states and contextual integration, not self-perception or agency judgments.
SocAdj explicitly requires representing and updating others' mental states; this matches Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.
SocConf is a social condition (mental-state inference without adjustment); it measures social processing (representing others' mental states).
SocConf involves inferring mental states but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs specifically.
This condition focuses on mentalizing rather than communicative exchange metrics (reception/production of signals).
Condition addresses others' mental states, not self-related processing.
SocConf requires representing others' intentions/mental states (without context-driven update), meeting the understanding-others construct.
PhyAdj is a physical (non-social) condition; it does not engage social processing/theory-of-mind per se.
PhyAdj is non-social and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
PhyAdj involves physical event inference and contextual updating, not social communication measures.
This physical condition pertains to event causes, not self-related judgments or agency.
PhyAdj contains no character-based mental-state inferences; thus it does not measure perception/understanding of others.

Contrast compares angry vs joyful sessions while participants view actors’ emotional actions; this directly probes social processing of others’ emotions and context.
Task manipulates emotional context (anger vs joy) and action perception but does not assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship/bonding constructs.
Participants view facial expressions and action contexts (reception of facial and non‑facial social cues); the contrast measures processing of communicative emotional signals.
No self-referential judgments, agency reports, or self-knowledge measures; task is passive observation of others.
Contrast examines how participants perceive others’ emotional states and actions (anger vs joy), directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Grasping vs faces contrasts different social stimuli (action observation vs facial displays), tapping social perceptual processes.
Contrast concerns perceptual differences between action and face stimuli, not measures of affiliation or attachment.
Contrast involves reception of non‑facial (action) and facial cues; it indexes aspects of social communicative signal processing (reception subconstructs).
No self-related processing or judgments are involved in this contrast.
contrasts perception of others’ actions versus faces, directly relating to action/animacy and inference about others.
Faces > grasping isolates processing of facial social cues and emotional expressions, a core social processing task.
The contrast targets facial/perceptual processing rather than affiliation, bonding, or attachment measures.
Faces involve receptive facial communication (emotion recognition); this contrast indexes social communication reception.
No self-focused tasks or self-evaluative judgments are present.
Contrast examines perception and interpretation of others’ facial emotional states, matching the perception-of-others construct.
Interaction tests how emotional context modulates processing of observed actions, a social-contextual perceptual process.
Interaction concerns contextual modulation of action perception rather than measures of affiliation/attachment.
The interaction assesses how context (anger vs joy) alters perception of actions, which affects reception of social/non‑verbal cues (social communication aspects).
No self-related judgments or agency measures are manipulated in this interaction analysis.
The interaction specifically addresses how observers interpret others’ actions depending on emotional context (action perception/understanding of others).
ROI/PPI analysis examines how angry vs joyful contexts modulate connectivity within regions (insula, STG) engaged in social perception—central social processing question.
Connectivity analyses probe emotion-context modulation of social perception, not affiliation or attachment constructs.
PPI shows modulation of right insula coupling with bilateral STG during angry grasping (processing of facial/action social cues), implicating reception of social communication.
Analyses focus on observers’ neural responses to others, not on self-awareness or self-evaluation.
Analyses directly probe neural mechanisms for perceiving others’ emotional actions (insula–STG connectivity during anger), aligning with perception-of-others.
Angry grasping > joyful grasping isolates how anger context alters processing of others’ actions—fits broad social processing construct.
Contrast differentiates emotional contexts of actions, not tests of affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related behavior.
This contrast examines reception of emotional/action cues (facial expression with grasping), which falls within social communication (reception) processes.
No measures of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge are involved in this contrast.
Directly assesses how observers perceive and process others’ emotional actions (action perception/understanding of others).
PPI seeding right insula examines connectivity changes during angry context while viewing social actions; addresses social processing mechanisms.
Functional connectivity analysis concerns emotion-modulated perception/processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Right insula coupling with STG during anger reflects processing of facial/action social signals (reception of social communication), so included.
No self-referential processing or self-reporting tasks tied to brain signals; analysis focuses on responses to others.
PPI investigates neural interactions underlying perception/understanding of others’ emotional actions, matching this construct.

PD and UG are social economic games; the contrast PD > UG compares social decision-making contexts and thus measures social processing broadly (perception, interpretation, and response to social information).

PD involves cooperation and group-based prosocial behavior (affiliation/attachment). The PD > UG contrast probes affiliation-related decisions (cooperation levels), so it measures affiliation/attachment.

Cooperation and competition tasks (PD vs UG) index exchange of socially relevant information and strategic interaction consistent with social communication constructs (reception/production in social exchanges).

Decisions in PD and UG require self-referential valuation (weighing self vs others), engaging processes related to understanding the self in a social decision context; thus the contrast likely involves self-related processing.
Both games require reasoning about others' actions/intentions (theory of mind, action perception). PD > UG contrast engages perception/understanding of others.
UG and PD are social decision tasks; the UG > PD contrast examines differences in social processing engaged by bargaining/unfairness versus collective-action decisions.
UG involves fairness and social bonding/norms; contrast UG > PD probes affiliation/attachment aspects (responses to offers, fairness norms).
UG entails socially relevant signaling (offers, accept/reject) and thus measures social communication processes; the contrast addresses these differences relative to PD.
Acceptance/rejection decisions in UG involve self-referential valuation and choices about outcomes for self versus other, engaging self-perception/assessment.
UG requires inferring proposer intentions and anticipating others' responses (mental state reasoning); UG > PD contrast taps perception/understanding of others.
High vs Low sociality directly manipulates social context (acquaintance vs random/computer) and examines neural differences in social processing; this contrast explicitly measures social processing.
The High Sociality > Low Sociality contrast probes effects of induced affiliation (socialization, acquaintance) on behavior and brain activity, directly indexing affiliation/attachment.
Socialization and interacting with acquaintances change interpersonal signaling and coordination; the contrast measures communication-related social processes involved in interaction and cooperation.
Interacting with acquaintances (vs strangers/computers) alters self-related valuation and social identity processing (self in relation to group), so self-perception processes are likely engaged.
High vs Low sociality requires greater consideration of others (their intentions, social identity), directly engaging perception and understanding of others; the contrast measures this construct.

Low Sociality > High Sociality contrasts neural activity when interacting with random individuals/computers vs acquaintances; this contrast still probes social processing differences and thus is within scope.
Low > High sociality contrast examines reduced affiliation/attachment effects (less social bonding), so it directly pertains to affiliation/attachment processes.
Interactions with low-sociality partners (computers/random individuals) alter communication demands and social signaling; this contrast measures social communication aspects of the task.
Decisions against low-sociality opponents may rely more on self-interested valuation and self-referential processes; thus perception/self-related processing is engaged and measured.
Even in low sociality conditions, participants form beliefs about opponents (agent vs computer); the contrast assesses perception/understanding of others or the lack thereof.
