The S-performance contrast stems from a task that manipulates cooperative versus competitive social interactions and measures how subjects form ability estimates about themselves within a social context. This directly indexes social processing (understanding and responding to social information about partners and relationships).

The task explicitly pits cooperation against competition and examines how interacting with high- or low-performing partners modifies self-evaluations, which is a canonical affiliation/attachment-related manipulation (cooperation/competition, social comparison).

Although there are no explicit communicative signals (e.g., faces, speech), the task involves exchange of socially relevant information (performance feedback, relational roles) and cooperative/competitive interactions—items listed as examples for this annotation—so the contrast is relevant to social communication constructs.

S-performance contrast indexes representations of one’s own recent performance and self-ability estimates (pgACC activity), directly measuring perception/understanding of self (self-evaluation, agency/self-knowledge).

This specific contrast isolates self-performance signals (pgACC) and the analysis focuses on self ability estimates; it does not primarily measure representations of others’ states or abilities (those are indexed in the O-performance contrast).

The O-performance contrast comes from the same social task (cooperation/competition) and tracks representations of the relevant other’s performance and how social context modulates those representations (area 9). This is central social processing (perceiving and integrating social information about others).

The analysis directly addresses cooperation versus competition and social comparison (how partner performance affects self/other estimates), which falls squarely within affiliation/attachment constructs per the inclusion examples.

The contrast measures processing of socially relevant information (partner performance, relational context) in cooperative/competitive interactions; cooperation/competition are listed as example tasks for this annotation, so inclusion is appropriate.

The O-performance contrast primarily indexes representations of the other’s expected performance (area 9). Although area 9 also carried some self-related/contextual signals, this contrast is focused on others and therefore does not primarily measure perception/understanding of self.
O-performance directly measures representations of others’ abilities and prediction errors about others (area 9), which maps onto perception and understanding of others (abilities, mental states).

Contrast CC-A (mutual cooperation vs other outcomes) derives from a one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma social interaction task; it directly measures social processing related to perceiving and responding to social outcomes (cooperation vs defection).

The CC-A contrast indexes mutual cooperation vs other outcomes in a cooperation/competition paradigm, directly assessing affiliation/attachment-related processes (positive social bond/reward for cooperation).
The task presents partner faces and measures responses to cooperative interactions; the CC-A contrast taps social communicative exchange (cooperation outcomes and inferred partner behavior).
CC-A contrasts participant-centered outcomes (their cooperation/defection and emotional ratings), indexing self-related evaluation and subjective affect (self-perception/monitoring).
CC-A involves representing partner choices and outcomes (inferring others’ behavior and intentions), thus measuring perception and understanding of others.
Contrast A-CC (average of other outcomes vs mutual cooperation) is derived from the same PD social interaction and measures social processing by comparing cooperative vs non-cooperative outcomes.
This contrast contrasts non-cooperative outcomes against mutual cooperation in a cooperation/competition task and therefore probes affiliation/attachment-related processes.
The contrast examines responses to social outcomes (partner cooperation/defection) with partner face presentation, reflecting social communicative processing.
The contrast contrasts participant-experienced outcomes (satisfaction, guilt, shame) and thus taps self-related evaluation and monitoring processes.
By comparing different partner-outcome combinations, this contrast implicates representation and understanding of others’ choices and intentions.
Gain-Loss contrast compares contextual modulation (gain vs loss) of responses during a social PD task; it reflects social processing differences across contexts.
Contextual (gain vs loss) effects on cooperation probe affiliation-related behavior (cooperation rates and reward value of mutual cooperation), satisfying affiliation/attachment criteria.
Gain-Loss explores how communicative/social outcome signaling (partner decisions and face cues) are processed differently across contexts, fitting social communication.
Contextual contrast affects participants’ self-related evaluations (happiness, trust) and decision-making, indexing perception/understanding of the self.
Gain vs Loss modulation reflects differences in how participants represent and evaluate others’ behavior under different outcome frames, addressing perception of others.
Loss-Gain (the reverse) is likewise a context contrast within a social cooperation task and indexes social processing under loss framing.
This contrast examines how loss framing affects affiliation-related responses to cooperation, directly relevant to attachment/affiliation processes in the PD task.
Loss-Gain addresses communicative/social outcome processing under loss context (partner choices and outcomes), meeting social communication inclusion.
Loss-Gain impacts self-related affect and decision outcomes (e.g., reduced happiness/cooperation in loss), indicating self-perception processes are measured.
This contrast tests how participants represent partners’ behaviors and intentions under loss framing, thus involving perception and understanding of others.
(CC-A) Gain - (CC-A) Loss examines context × cooperation interaction in a social cooperation task, directly measuring social processing modulations by context.
This interaction tests whether affiliation/attachment-related neural responses to mutual cooperation differ across gain vs loss contexts (explicitly a cooperation/attachment measure).
The interaction contrast probes how communicative signals of cooperation (partner behavior and faces) are differentially encoded across contexts, satisfying social communication criteria.
By testing context-by-outcome effects on neural responses tied to participants’ cooperative choices and subjective ratings, this contrast measures self-related perception/evaluation.
The interaction assesses whether representations of others’ cooperative behavior (and its reward value) change between gain and loss contexts, indexing perception of others.
(CC-A) Loss - (CC-A) Gain (reverse interaction) likewise probes social processing of cooperation under context change in the PD task.
The reverse interaction examines affiliation/attachment-related neural responses to cooperation when loss > gain effects are considered, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast evaluates social communicative encoding differences (partner signals and outcomes) under loss-over-gain interaction, meeting social communication inclusion.
The reverse interaction tests self-related neural responses (affective evaluation of outcomes) under loss vs gain, indexing perception of self.
By assessing whether representations of others’ cooperative behavior are stronger in loss than gain contexts, this contrast involves perception/understanding of others.

The contrast tests mentalizing (inferring others’ mental states) with Dissimilar > Similar targets — a core social cognition task engaging perception and interpretation of social information. This directly meets the Social Processing definition and measures social processing.

The study manipulated perceived similarity and explicitly assessed affiliation/connectedness and cooperativeness; the contrast probes neural processes when mentalizing about dissimilar vs similar others which is directly related to affiliation/attachment differences, meeting the inclusion criterion.

Although not a face-to-face communicative exchange, the task involves inferring and representing socially relevant information about others (receptive aspects of social information). The contrast is part of a social task assessing distinctions between partners, fitting the broad inclusion examples.

The paradigm includes self-related judgments (participants also selected statements for themselves) and the contrast contrasts mentalizing for dissimilar vs similar which depends on self-other comparisons and self-referential anchoring; thus it taps processes of self-perception/representation relevant to the task.

The mentalizing decision explicitly requires reasoning about others’ mental states (Understanding Mental States subconstruct). The Dissimilar > Similar contrast directly measures perception/understanding of others, satisfying the inclusion criterion.

This analysis models working memory maintenance across both competition and no-competition conditions and reports social-network regions (mPFC, PCC/precuneus) and correlations specific to the competition condition, so it assesses social-processing-related effects within the task.

The study involves a competition manipulation (social comparison/competition) and this analysis includes the competition condition and performance relationships, which taps affiliation/competition processes.
The task includes social-comparative feedback and the analysis includes conditions that require processing social feedback/other-performance, fitting the social communication criterion.

The analysis reports mPFC involvement and performance-related effects tied to self-referential/performance monitoring across conditions (and correlations with self-report competitiveness), indicating self-perception processes.

The working memory maintenance analysis includes the competition condition and shows precuneus/PCC effects that relate to social-referencing and distraction by others; thus it involves representing others in the social context.
This analysis specifically examines the performance parametric modulator within the no-competition (non-social) condition only, so it does not directly measure social processing.
The no-competition parametric modulator pertains to a non-social condition (no competitor), so it does not measure affiliation/attachment or competition processes.
This analysis is limited to the noncompetitive condition and does not involve exchange of social information about another person, so it does not meet the social-communication criterion.

Even in the no-competition condition participants receive feedback about their own performance and the analysis assesses performance-related effects, which taps self-perception and self-monitoring processes.
The no-competition condition does not involve processing information about another person, so it does not measure perception/understanding of others.
This analysis examines performance-related modulation within the competition condition, directly probing brain responses when a social competitor is present—i.e., social processing.
The competition condition is a social-competitive context (explicitly an affiliation/competition manipulation), so this analysis measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.
Performance parametric modulation during the competition condition necessarily involves processing social-comparative feedback about an opponent, consistent with social communication processes.
The competition condition involves self-monitoring and self-referential processes (mPFC engagement and correlations with self-report competitiveness), so this analysis measures perception of self.

The competition condition requires tracking another's (confederate's) performance and social-referencing, and the analysis links precuneus/PCC activity to these social effects—consistent with perception/understanding of others.

Event-related feedback analysis compares competition and no-competition feedback and finds increased activation in social/mentalizing regions (mPFC, PCC, STS) during competition, directly measuring social processing.
The feedback phase during competition conveys social-comparative information about an opponent and thus taps into affiliation/competition processes.

At feedback participants receive information about their competitor's performance (a form of social information exchange), and the analysis shows activation in regions linked to social perception/communication (STS), meeting the criterion.
Feedback processing involves evaluation of one's own performance (self-referential processing) and engages mPFC, indicating perception/self processes are measured.

Feedback includes information about the 'opponent' and the analysis shows PCC/precuneus and STS activation linked to social-referencing and other-related processing, so it measures perception of others.

The direct contrast Competition > No Competition isolates neural responses to the social competitive context and shows recruitment of mentalizing/default-mode regions, so it clearly measures social processing.
This contrast specifically targets the competitive (social) context versus noncompetitive, fulfilling the affiliation/competition task criterion.
Competition > No Competition contrast captures processing of social-comparative feedback and related communication about another's performance, meeting social-communication inclusion.
The contrast identifies increased mPFC activation during competition, an area implicated in self-referential processing and social comparison, indicating perception/self is measured.

Competition > No Competition reveals increased PCC/precuneus and STS activation associated with social-referencing and others' representation, indicating perception/understanding of others is measured.

The No Competition > Competition contrast is part of the social manipulation (the contrast reflects differences related to presence/absence of a social competitor) and thus addresses social processing, even if in the reverse direction.

Although this contrast highlights greater activation in the noncompetitive condition, it still directly compares social vs non-social contexts (competition), so it pertains to affiliation/attachment processes.
This contrast examines neural differences between competitive and noncompetitive feedback/context and therefore probes social-communication related neural processes (direction reversed).
No Competition > Competition examines self-related processing differences (feedback about one's own performance and mPFC/PCC involvement), so perception/self is relevant.

Although this contrast favors the noncompetitive condition, it still reflects processing differences tied to the presence/absence of another person and thus informs perception/understanding of others (by contrast), so include.

Table 1 reports ROI definitions and voxel counts for face-responsive regions used in analyses of attention to facial aspects and emotion — part of the study’s social-processing pipeline. Although the table is descriptive, it directly supports analyses measuring social processing (face/emotion), so it is included.

The table and related analyses do not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Task focuses on age and emotion judgments, not affiliation/attachment.
ROIs are defined for face-responsive regions used in analyses of facial emotion and age judgments (reception of facial communication). The table is directly related to social communication analyses.
No measures or contrasts probe self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. The table is about face-responsive ROIs for perceiving others, not self.
The ROI definitions support analyses that probe perception and understanding of others (emotion valence and age judgments of other people), so this analysis is relevant to perception_of_others.
This contrast decodes negative vs positive emotion (averaged over tasks) from face-responsive cortex — a direct measure of social processing (perception of social/emotional cues).
The contrast tests emotional valence (positive vs negative) and not affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons.
Decoding emotional valence of faces is reception of facial communication (affective signal processing), meeting the social_communication construct.
The contrast concerns perception of other people’s emotions, not self-related judgments or self-knowledge.
Decoding emotional valence of others’ faces is a direct measure of perception and understanding of others’ emotional states, matching this construct.
This contrast decodes negative vs positive emotion during the emotion-attend task, directly indexing social processing of emotional expressions.
The analysis targets emotion valence decoding while attending to emotion, not affiliation/attachment (no bonding or loved-one contrasts).
Emotion-attended valence decoding is reception of facial communication (affect recognition), fitting social_communication.
No self-related processes are probed; this is perception of others' emotions.
This contrast measures representation of others’ emotional valence when attended, directly addressing perception and understanding of others’ emotional states.

This contrast decodes negative vs positive emotion during the age-attend task, probing whether stimulus emotional valence is represented when attention is directed elsewhere — a social-processing measure.
The contrast examines emotional valence while attending to age; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
Even when attending to age, decoding emotional valence (or testing for absence thereof) pertains to reception of facial communication and thus fits social_communication.
The analysis concerns perception of others’ facial emotion when attention is on age; it does not involve self-perception or self-related judgments.
Testing representation of others’ emotional valence under an unattended condition directly probes perception/understanding of others, so include.

Contrast directly compares self- vs other-related outcomes during a social interaction task (joke-telling), clearly measuring social processing of actions and responses.

The contrast probes the effect of self-relevant social feedback on subjective pleasure and monitoring (action-outcome contingency), which relates to positive social interaction and bonding mechanisms (affiliation/attachment).
The task involves producing and receiving communicative vocalizations (joke utterance and listener laughter); the contrast isolates self-related processing in this communicative exchange.
The SELF minus OTHER contrast is explicitly designed to index self-related processing (mPFC activation), meeting criteria for perception/understanding of self (agency/self-monitoring).

This contrast targets self>other effects and is focused on self-related processing (mPFC); it does not primarily index representations of others' states or traits, so perception_of_others is not the main construct assessed.
Group vs No Laughter contrasts responses to social feedback (laughter) during an interactive social task, indexing social processing of others' responses.
The contrast isolates neural responses to group laughter, a positive social signal associated with reward/pleasure and social bonding, relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
Laughter is a non-facial communicative signal; the contrast captures reception of such social communication (auditory processing of others' laughter).
Group minus No Laughter primarily indexes perception of the listener's response (others' vocalizations) rather than self-related representations, so it does not meet the perception_self criterion.
The contrast measures neural responses to others' laughter (auditory social feedback), directly indexing perception and understanding of others' actions/responses.
Single laughter vs No Laughter contrasts neural responses to social auditory feedback within the interactive task, reflecting social processing.
Single laughter is a positive social signal likely related to social reward and bonding; the contrast probes affiliation-relevant responses.
This contrast indexes reception of non-facial communicative vocalizations (single-person laughter), fitting the social_communication construct (reception of non-facial communication).
Single vs No Laughter focuses on perception of others' responses rather than self-related processing, so perception_self is not the primary construct.
Contrast assesses neural processing of another's laughter (others' action/perception), meeting criteria for perception_others.
Group minus Single Laughter compares two types of social feedback, indexing sensitivity to social communicative cues and their processing in a social task.
Differential neural responses to more vs less potent social feedback (group vs single laughter) relate to gradations in social reward and bonding, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast isolates differences in reception of non-facial communicative signals (types of laughter), directly within social communication processing.
The contrast contrasts two types of others' responses and does not directly index self-related processes; thus perception_self is not the primary target.
Contrast examines neural sensitivity to variations in others' responses (group vs single laughter), directly reflecting perception/understanding of others' actions.
This interaction contrast explicitly assesses social action-outcome contingency (self vs other × listener response), a core social processing phenomenon measured in the task (VS activation reported).
Action-outcome contingency effects (greater pleasure when one's own actions elicit positive responses) are central to mechanisms of social bonding and affiliation; the contrast measures this process.

The contrast examines how communicative feedback (laughter) interacts with self/other agency to influence neural value signals, implicating social communication processes (reception of non-facial cues and integration).
The interaction specifically contrasts outcomes when the actor is self vs other and thus indexes self-related outcome monitoring and agency representations implicated in the mPFC and VS.
Because the interaction involves variability in others' responses (laughter levels) and their integration with actor identity, it also addresses perception/processing of others' actions as outcomes.

Although this contrast (single-laughter contingency interaction) yielded no significant activation, it nevertheless operationalizes social action-outcome contingency and thus measures social processing.
The contrast assesses contingency of social feedback (single laughter) for self vs other, a process tied to social reward and bonding mechanisms relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This interaction contrast concerns reception and evaluation of communicative feedback (single laughter) in a social exchange, fitting social_communication criteria.
The contrast measures how outcomes associated with the self (vs other) modulate neural responses to listener feedback, indexing self-related outcome perception and monitoring.
The contrast involves perception of others' responses (single laughter) as the outcome factor and thus addresses perception/understanding of others' actions.

PPI tests interaction of mPFC (self-related) and auditory cortex (others' response) signals on ventral striatum connectivity during the social contingency task, directly indexing social processing network dynamics.
The PPI connects self-related processing, sensory reception of social feedback, and reward circuitry tied to subjective pleasure—mechanistically relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.

The analysis examines how reception of communicative auditory signals (laughter) interacts with self-representation to influence reward-related connectivity, addressing social communication (reception/integration).
The PPI explicitly involves the mPFC seed (self-related region) and tests its modulatory role, thus indexing perception/monitoring of self-related signals.
Because the PPI also uses auditory cortex seeds representing others' laughter, it directly probes how perception of others' responses contributes to network interactions (perception_others).
Analogous to analysis_6 but with left auditory cortex seed; examines network interactions underpinning social action-outcome contingency, so it measures social processing.
Left-AC–mPFC PPI that links auditory social feedback, self-related processing, and reward circuitry relates to mechanisms of social reward and affiliation/attachment.
The analysis probes reception/integration of non-facial communicative cues (laughter) with self-related signals, fitting the social_communication construct.
The PPI involves the mPFC (self-related region) as a seed and therefore indexes self-related perception/monitoring in network modulation.
The left auditory cortex seed represents perception of others' responses; the PPI tests how these representations interact with self-related signals, aligning with perception_others.

Select > content contrast engaged social-cognition ROIs (VMPFC, MMPFC, DMPFC, TPJ, PC, rSTS) and the study explicitly interprets social processing during selection. The task involves social-related considerations even when selecting for oneself, satisfying social processing inclusion (I1, I2).

Select > content primarily probes personal selection (reading for self). Although some social-cognition regions were engaged, the task/contrast is not primarily measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, close-relationship constructs) as required by the affiliation inclusion criteria. Thus I1 is not met for this contrast.

Select > content concerns deciding to read for oneself rather than exchanging information; although social-cognition ROIs are engaged, the contrast does not index communication (sending/receiving messages) per the social_communication inclusion (I1).
Select > content was explicitly designed to probe self-related processing and activated MPFC and PCC meta-analytic ROIs for self-relevance; this meets the Perception/Self inclusion (I1).

Select > content also elicited activity in social-cognition regions implicated in understanding others (TPJ, DMPFC), and the authors interpret that people consider others’ perspectives even when selecting, meeting Perception/Others inclusion (I1).
Share > content contrast directly probes social processes (deciding to share with others) and engaged social-cognition and self-related ROIs; it clearly measures Social Processing (I1, I2).

Sharing (including narrowcast to a friend and broadcast) indexes affiliative behavior and social bonding motives (self-presentation, reputation), so the share contrast measures affiliation/attachment constructs consistent with I1.

Sharing news is an explicit form of social communication (exchange of information). The Share > content contrast directly measures propensity to communicate information to others, satisfying the social_communication inclusion (I1).
Share > content engaged self-related ROIs (MPFC, PCC) and the authors report self-relevance/self-presentation as a motive for sharing; this meets Perception/Self inclusion (I1).

Share > content robustly engaged regions involved in understanding others (DMPFC, TPJ, etc.), and sharing inherently involves reasoning about others’ perspectives, meeting Perception/Others inclusion (I1).

Share > select contrast shows greater activation in social-processing, self, and valuation ROIs when sharing vs selecting, directly indexing social processes; meets Social Processing criteria (I1, I2).
Share > select emphasizes the social/affiliative aspects of sharing over personal selection (e.g., reputation, bonding), consistent with affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).
This contrast isolates sharing (communication) relative to selecting for self, so it directly measures social communication processes (I1).
Although comparing share to select, the contrast still showed elevated self-related processing (MPFC/PCC) during sharing; thus it relates to Perception/Self processes (I1).
Share > select showed greater recruitment of mentalizing regions (DMPFC, TPJ) associated with understanding others, meeting Perception/Others inclusion (I1).

The Select (parametric modulation by preference) analysis examined how neural activity during selecting scaled with preference and included social- and self-related ROIs; it measures social processing related to selection decisions (I1, I2).

The parametric Select analysis indexes preference to read for oneself, which is primarily self-oriented; it does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., bonding, close-relationship scales), so I1 is not met for affiliation.

The Select parametric modulation concerns personal selection preference rather than communication/exchange of information; it does not directly measure social communication per the specified inclusion (I1).
The Select parametric analysis showed activity in self-related ROIs scaling with preference to select, directly measuring Perception/Self processes (I1).

Although focused on selection, the parametric Select analysis also found effects in social-cognition regions and the authors interpret that social considerations influenced selection; this meets Perception/Others inclusion (I1).

The Share (parametric modulation by preference) analysis directly probes social processing underlying willingness to share and showed scaling in social and self ROIs, satisfying Social Processing inclusion (I1, I2).

Preference to share (including narrowcast/broadcast) maps onto affiliative motives (reputation, bonding); the parametric Share analysis measures affiliation/attachment-related tendencies and meets I1.
Preference to share directly measures tendencies to communicate information to others; the Share parametric analysis therefore meets social_communication inclusion (I1).

The Share parametric modulation showed scaling in self-related regions (MPFC/PCC), indicating self-relevance/self-presentation processes during sharing decisions, meeting Perception/Self inclusion (I1).

The Share parametric analysis showed that activity in mentalizing regions scaled with preference to share, reflecting consideration of others’ mental states and meeting Perception/Others inclusion (I1).

The Trust Game is a social task probing reciprocity and prosocial behavior; the contrast 'Gave $0' indexes social decision-making about reciprocation, meeting the Social Processing definition.
The contrast involves cooperation/reciprocity decisions (affiliation-related behavior); Trust Game measures affiliation/attachment dynamics (cooperation), so it meets the criterion.
Although not a facial-communication task, the contrast probes cooperative/competitive social exchange (Trust Game), which is listed as an example under Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Deciding whether to give back engages self-related decision-making, agency and self-monitoring (perception/understanding of self) within a social context; meets inclusion.
Reciprocity decisions are influenced by representations of others' intentions and past behavior (understanding others' mental states); the contrast indexes perception/understanding of others.
'Gave $1.5 After Receiving' is a reciprocity choice in a social exchange; it directly probes social processing.
This contrast indexes reciprocal/cooperative behavior after being reciprocated, tapping affiliation/attachment processes (cooperation).
The contrast reflects cooperative social exchange (Trust Game), fitting the Social Communication inclusion examples (cooperation/competition).
Choosing to reciprocate after receiving engages self-related evaluation and agency in a social decision context.
This behavior depends on perceiving and evaluating the other player's prior reciprocation — understanding others' actions and intentions.
'Gave $1.5X After Not Receiving' probes reciprocity/altruism following non-reciprocation — a social decision-making process.
This contrast measures altruistic/affiliative responses despite being treated unfairly, directly relating to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition).
The contrast captures social exchange behavior (cooperation/altruism) which falls under the Social Communication inclusion examples.
Altruistic choices after not receiving require self-evaluation and agency (deciding against self-interest), meeting Perception_Self inclusion.
Choosing to give after not receiving implies attribution or representation of the other's state or motives (understanding others), so include.

The contrast 'Altruistic choices (Gave $1.5X After Not Receiving - Gave $0 After Not Receiving)' directly isolates pro-social vs selfish responses in a social exchange, a core social processing measure.
This contrast compares affiliative/altruistic versus non-affiliative responses after non-reciprocation, addressing affiliation/attachment mechanisms.
The contrast isolates communicative/cooperative behavioral outcomes in the Trust Game (cooperation vs non-cooperation), aligning with Social Communication inclusion.
Comparing altruistic to selfish choices after non-reciprocation examines self-related choice processes (agency, self-monitoring).
This contrast reflects how representations of others' prior (non-)reciprocation modulate subsequent decisions, implicating perception/understanding of others.

Task explicitly involves observing others' social integrity threats and judging interpersonal emotions (fremdscham) — a canonical social-processing paradigm engaging mentalizing and empathy networks (ACC, AI, mPFC). This meets the social processing inclusion criteria.

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment per se (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation, or direct attachment measures). Although social comparison is discussed theoretically, the experimental manipulation does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs.

Stimuli and contrasts probe observers' affective responses and mentalizing about targets rather than communicative behavior or reception/production of facial/non‑facial communicative signals. It therefore does not meet the social communication inclusion example tasks.

Participants explicitly rate their own affective state (vicarious embarrassment), which indexes perception and understanding of one’s current internal emotional state (self‑report of affect). This matches the self-perception inclusion criterion.

The paradigm requires representing and evaluating the social target's integrity and inferred embarrassment (mentalizing). Results and analyses explicitly examine regions (mPFC, ACC, AI) associated with understanding others’ states, satisfying the perception-of-others criterion.

Task explicitly involves observing others' social integrity threats and judging interpersonal emotions (schadenfreude) — a canonical social-processing paradigm engaging mentalizing and reward networks. This meets the social processing inclusion criteria.

The schadenfreude condition does not manipulate affiliation/attachment (no kinship, bonding, or cooperation manipulation). While social comparison processes are discussed conceptually, the experimental contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment measures.

The contrast measures internal affective responses and reward-related processing to observed events, not communicative exchange or reception/production of facial/non‑facial signals; thus it does not meet the social communication inclusion examples.
Participants provide trial-by-trial self-reports of their schadenfreude (their own internal affect), indexing perception/understanding of self-relevant emotional states.

Interpreting others' social integrity threats and mental states is central to the task; analyses focus on mentalizing regions (mPFC) and shared-circuit regions (ACC/AI), supporting inclusion for perception of others.

The contrast (Fremdscham > Schadenfreude) directly compares two social-emotion conditions and isolates differences in social-cognitive/empathic processing (e.g., left AI). This is squarely within social processing.

This between-condition contrast targets differential empathic vs. reward-related processing rather than affiliation/attachment constructs; no measures of bonding or attachment are present in the contrast.
The contrast examines neural differences in affective and mentalizing responses, not communicative signal reception/production. It therefore does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.

Differences reflect how participants’ self-focused affective reports and associated self-perception processes (degree of vicarious affect) are modulated by instruction; the contrast isolates self-referential affective processing differences.

The Fremdscham > Schadenfreude contrast highlights greater engagement of regions implicated in representing others' affective states (left AI, ACC, mentalizing network), thus indexing perception/understanding of others.

The contrast (romantic > neutral) uses images of couples in romantic interactions; this is a social task involving perception and interpretation of social cues and bonding-related responses, so it measures social processing.

Romantic images explicitly probe affiliation/attachment-related processing (romance/pair-bonding) and the contrast tests responses to affiliative stimuli (romantic vs neutral), matching the exemplar 'Loved one vs Stranger' type contrasts.

Viewing images of couples engaging in romantic behaviors engages reception of social/affective cues (facial/body expressions and interpersonal interaction), so the contrast indexes social communication-related processing.
The task contrasts romantic versus neutral images of other people and does not require self-referential judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Romantic images require representing and assessing others' emotional states and intentions (understanding others), so the contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
The romantic > sexual contrast compares responses to social (romantic) interactions versus sexual images; it probes social processing related to relationship cues and social cognition.
Romantic stimuli probe affiliation/attachment processes; the contrast (romantic > sexual) isolates affiliation-related activation, consistent with measures of attachment/affiliation.

The contrast involves perceiving interpersonal romantic behaviors and affective signals, engaging reception of facial/body communicative cues and social interpretation, so it indexes social communication.
The contrast compares responses to images of others (romantic vs sexual) and does not involve self-reflection or judgments about the self; it does not measure perception/understanding of self.

Romantic and sexual images require assessment of others' emotional states, intentions, and social interactions; the contrast reflects differences in processing others, matching the perception-of-others construct.

The IAT contrasts (incongruent vs. congruent) use social stimuli (pictures implying monogamy or adultery and valenced words) and measure implicit attitudes toward extra-pair relationships, which is a social cognition task about relationship behavior. This meets the inclusion criterion for Social Processing (I1).

The IAT specifically probes implicit evaluations of monogamy versus adultery and the study is explicitly about relationship maintenance and attachment-related behavior, so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).

The IAT paradigm here measures implicit evaluative attitudes about relationship behaviors rather than receptive or expressive social communication (facial expression recognition, gaze, or communicative exchange). It does not target the social communication subconstructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion for Social Communication.

The contrast indexes implicit attitudes toward adultery/monogamy (evaluative social attitudes) rather than self-focused processes (agency, self-knowledge, self-monitoring). Thus it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.

The task uses images depicting interpersonal/romantic scenarios (monogamy vs adultery) and probes participants' evaluations of those social others/behaviors, which aligns with perception and understanding of others (I1).

Even though the congruent vs. incongruent contrast did not produce significant activations in the reported results, the analysis itself is based on the same IAT social task (monogamy vs. adultery) and therefore measures social processing (I1).
The contrast pertains to the same affiliation/attachment-related IAT (implicit evaluations of monogamy and adultery), so it measures affiliation and attachment constructs (I1).

The congruent vs. incongruent contrast does not probe communicative behaviors or face/gaze/expressive reception/production; it assesses evaluative associations, so Social Communication is not applicable.
The analysis addresses implicit social attitudes rather than self-referential processing or agency/self-knowledge, so Perception/Self is not applicable.

The contrast involves judgments about interpersonal/romantic scenarios (monogamy/adultery) and thus taps into representation and evaluation of others' behaviors/traits, meeting the Perception/Others inclusion criterion (I1).

Analysis contrasts ISC when subjects believed sisters were genetic vs non-genetic while viewing a moral-dilemma movie. This directly interrogates social cognition (moral evaluation, mentalizing, perspective-taking) across subjects and thus measures broad social processing.

The contrast specifically manipulates perceived kinship (genetic vs adopted sisters), i.e. affiliation/attachment information, and examines its effect on brain synchrony — a canonical kinship/affiliation manipulation.

The stimulus is a movie of interpersonal interaction with dialogue and social exchange; the contrast probes how social information (kinship) modulates shared neural responses, relevant to receptive social communication processes.

Participants were instructed in runs to take different perspectives (donor vs recipient) and the ISC differences reflect perspective-taking/self-referential processing during moral evaluation, implicating perception/understanding of self-related perspective.

The contrast implicates mentalizing and understanding of the movie characters’ intentions and emotional states (perception of others) which the authors explicitly link to regions showing greater ISC in the genetic condition.

The reverse contrast (non-genetic>genetic) is part of the same social manipulation (perceived kinship) and therefore still indexes social processing differences, even if effects localized primarily to visual cortex in this contrast.

Although this contrast shows stronger ISC in occipital areas when sisters were believed non-genetic, the comparison itself is driven by the affiliation/kinship manipulation, so it is relevant to affiliation/attachment processing.

The analysis contrasts responses to the same interpersonal movie under different kinship context; even if activity shifts to perceptual regions, the task remains a social-communication stimulus and manipulation.

Perspective instructions and the kinship manipulation can change self-related perspective taking and internal evaluation; thus the contrast is relevant to self-perception processes engaged during viewing.

The comparison assesses how perceived relatedness alters processing of other characters (mentalizing/understanding others); even if non-genetic>genetic effects appear in visual cortex, the underlying manipulation targets perception of others.
This GLM contrasts decision vs non-decision periods in a moral-dilemma task about saving sister, friend, and strangers — a canonical social cognition task probing moral/social processing broadly.

The moral decision task explicitly contrasts choices involving the subject’s sister and best friend vs strangers, directly indexing affiliation/attachment and kin-preference behavior and its neural correlates.

The decision task presents socially relevant identities and requires processing of social relationships and cues (who to save), engaging receptive social-communication processes and social information exchange representations.

Deciding whom to save involves self-related evaluative processes and perspective-taking (making choices from one’s own viewpoint about personal priorities), indexing perception/understanding of self-related decision processes.

The moral decision GLM requires reasoning about others’ outcomes, intentions, and value (sister, friend, strangers) — core perception/understanding of others (mentalizing) processes are engaged and localized in the reported areas.

Contrast FT>FA measures processing of social cues (approach vs avoidance) using PLD/HL stimuli and examines mirror and mentalizing systems; thus it targets broad social processing.
Task requires judging orientation (facing toward/away) and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation).
The task involves reception of non-facial social signals (biological motion, body orientation) which are a form of non-facial social communication.
Analyses concern perception of external agents (others' body motion and orientation), not self-related processing (agency or self-knowledge).
Contrasts assess action perception, animacy and inference about others' potential for social involvement, mapping directly onto perception and understanding of others.
FA>FT contrasts brain responses to social-directional cues (facing away vs toward) in PLD/HL, reflecting social processing.
Contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation manipulations).
FA>FT involves perceiving non-facial social signals (body motion/orientation), constituting reception of non-facial communication.
Contrast pertains to perception of others, not self-related judgments or agency.
FA>FT measures action perception and interpretation of others' social orientation, fitting perception and understanding of others.
HL>PLD compares responses to human-like vs point-light displays in a social perception task, reflecting social processing.
This contrast contrasts stimulus type but does not probe affiliation/attachment (no relational or bonding measures).
Comparing HL and PLD addresses reception of non-facial communicative cues from body motion, i.e., social communication reception.
Contrast targets perception of external agents rather than self-related processes.
HL>PLD taps perception and interpretation of others' actions and social meaning, aligning with perception of others.
PLD>HL examines processing of point-light biological motion versus human-like stimuli in a social context, thus social processing.
No measures of attachment or affiliation; task is perceptual (orientation) rather than relational.
PLD>HL relates to decoding non-facial body cues and intentions from motion, a form of social communication reception.
Contrast concerns perception of other agents' motion, not self-perception or self-knowledge.
This analysis probes observers' perception and interpretation of others' actions (animacy/action perception), meeting the construct.
STIMULUS*DIRECTION interaction tests how stimulus type and movement direction jointly affect social-cognitive systems (MNS/MS), directly addressing social processing.
Interaction analysis does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation comparisons).
Interaction examines how different social cues (body type and orientation) modulate reception of non-facial communicative signals; thus it fits social communication.
Focus is on perception of others' motion and social meaning, not self-related processing.
Interaction assesses how observers represent others' actions and social intent across stimulus types and directions, directly mapping to perception of others.
POST-HOC ANALYSIS further characterizes social-cognitive effects (e.g., mPFC, IFG, IPL differences) across social conditions; clearly social processing.
Post-hoc contrasts refine neural differences but do not test affiliation/attachment constructs.
Post-hoc contrasts involve regions implicated in decoding communicative body cues and intentions (reception of non-facial communication), matching the construct.
Analyses focus on neural responses to others' actions/stimuli rather than self-related judgments or traits.
Post-hoc tests examine neural correlates of perceiving others' actions and inferring social meaning, consistent with perception of others.
FT_PLD>HL compares facing-toward PLD vs HL—assesses social-cue processing and potential for social involvement; thus social processing.
Contrast does not target attachment/affiliation (no bonding or relationship condition).
Comparing FT PLD vs HL examines reception of body-orientation cues relevant to non-facial social communication.
Contrast concerns perception of others (orientation of walker) rather than self-related processes.
This contrast probes how observers perceive others' action orientation and social meaning in the FT condition—fits perception of others.
FT_HL>PLD contrasts facing-toward human-like versus point-light displays, assessing social processing of motion cues.
No measures of affiliation or attachment in this contrast.
This contrast involves reception of communicative body cues (human-like motion facing observer) which falls under social communication reception.
Focus is on perception of other agents, not self-related constructs.
Examines perception and inferred social meaning of others' actions (HL facing observer), consistent with perception of others.
FA_PLD>HL examines facing-away PLD versus HL, probing how social cues conveyed by motion away from observer are processed.
Contrast concerns perceptual decoding of orientation; it does not target affiliation/attachment measures.
FA_PLD>HL involves decoding non-facial motion cues and inferred social involvement from body orientation—relevant to social communication reception.
Analysis focuses on perception of external agents' motion, not self-related processes.
This contrast evaluates perception and interpretation of others' actions (walking away) and related social meaning, mapping to perception of others.
FA_HL>PLD compares facing-away HL vs PLD, assessing social cognitive processing of these stimuli and directionality.
No affiliation/attachment constructs are being measured in this contrast.
Contrast taps reception of non-facial communicative cues (HL vs PLD body motion away), relevant to social communication.
Contrast concerns perception of others' motion; self-related constructs are not targeted.
Assessing HL vs PLD in FA condition addresses perception and interpretation of others' social orientation/actions, aligning with perception of others.
PLD_FT>FA examines direction effects for point-light displays (facing toward vs away), which index social cue processing.
This within-PLD direction contrast does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs.
Comparing FT vs FA for PLD addresses reception of body-orientation social cues (non-facial communication).
Analysis targets perception of other agents' motion, not self-related processing.
This contrast investigates action perception of others (directionality of PLD) and inferred social involvement, fitting perception of others.
PLD_FA>FT tests how point-light displays moving away vs toward engage social-cognitive networks, reflecting social processing.
Contrast does not involve measures of affiliation/attachment or relational bonding.
This contrast concerns decoding non-facial body motion cues indicating orientation/intent, i.e., reception of non-facial communication.
Focus remains on perception of others (PLD), not on self-perception or self-knowledge.
PLD_FA>FT probes action perception and inferred social meaning of others walking away, mapping to perception of others.
HL_FT>FA examines direction effects for human-like stimuli (facing toward vs away), implicating social processing (potential for social involvement).
No direct measures of affiliation or attachment are present in this contrast.
HL_FT>FA contrasts reception of non-facial communicative body cues in human-like stimuli, matching social communication reception.
Analysis concerns perception of other agents' motion/orientation rather than self-related constructs.
This contrast probes perception and inferred social meaning of others (HL facing observer vs away), consistent with perception of others.
HL_FA>FT assesses neural responses to human-like walkers moving away vs toward, relating to social cue processing and involvement.

Contrast compares retrieval of collaboratively learned labels to arbitrary labels; task and reported activations (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus) explicitly index social cognition/mentalizing and collaborative/communicative processes, so this measures social processing.

Contrast targets collaboratively encoded labels produced in a cooperative communicative task (collaboration/cooperation is an example of affiliation-related paradigms). The contrast reflects processes tied to social bonding/interaction during encoding and retrieval.

The paradigm is explicitly a referential communicative task (directors retrieving labels in a communicative setting). The contrast isolates retrieval of collaboratively established communicative labels, meeting the Social Communication construct.

Authors report engagement of autobiographical memory and medial prefrontal cortex (self-projection/self-related processing) for collaboratively learned labels; thus the contrast likely involves processes related to perception/understanding of self (autobiographical/self-projection).
Contrast shows recruitment of theory-of-mind regions (right TPJ, precuneus) and is interpreted as mentalizing about the matcher — directly indexing perception/understanding of others' mental states.

This contrast (Individual > Arbitrary) isolates retrieval of self-generated (individual) versus arbitrary labels and primarily engages semantic memory regions (left angular gyrus, temporal poles). The task and reported activations do not reflect social processing or social interaction.

The individual condition does not involve cooperation/attachment-related processes; contrast contrasts individual self-generated learning with arbitrary pairs and therefore does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Although the overarching experiment has communicative elements, this specific contrast isolates individual (non-collaborative) encoding effects and semantic retrieval, not social communication processes.

The contrast reflects semantic retrieval of self-generated labels rather than explicit self-reflection or agency/self-knowledge judgments; reported activations are semantic (angular gyrus/temporal poles) rather than classic self-specific regions.

The contrast does not engage theory-of-mind or other-related processing; it contrasts individual encoding with arbitrary labels and shows semantic network activity, not perceptions of others' mental states.

Collaborative > Individual directly contrasts collaboratively encoded (social) vs individually encoded labels and shows activation in classic social/mentalizing regions (mPFC, right TPJ, precuneus), indicating social processing.

The contrast isolates effects of collaborative (cooperative) encoding relative to individual encoding; because cooperation is directly involved, this reflects affiliation/attachment-related social processes tied to interacting partners.

The difference reflects retrieval of labels established through communicative interaction; activity in social/communication-related regions and the communicative nature of the task meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Authors report medial prefrontal and autobiographical-memory involvement (self-projection) for collaboratively encoded labels; thus perception/understanding of self (autobiographical/self-related processing) is plausibly engaged by this contrast.
Contrast produces right TPJ and precuneus activation and is interpreted as mentalizing about the conversational partner; this directly indexes perception/understanding of others' mental states.

Arbitrary > Individual highlights hippocampal and other memory-related activity for arbitrary associations versus self-generated labels; there is no evidence this contrast indexes social processing or interaction.
This contrast concerns arbitrary associative memory and hippocampal involvement, not cooperation, bonding, or affiliation measures.
The contrast contrasts non-social arbitrary learning with individual learning and identifies memory/hippocampal networks rather than communicative processes.
Reported activations relate to hippocampal/medial and subcortical memory systems for arbitrary associations, not explicit self-related judgments or agency/ self-knowledge processing.
No evidence that this contrast engages processes of understanding others (theory of mind); it highlights hippocampal and memory-related activations for arbitrary associations.

Individual > Collaborative contrasts individually encoded labels relative to collaboratively encoded ones; this contrast does not index social processing and instead reflects differences in semantic/memory processing or lesser social involvement.
This contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment; it contrasts individual encoding against collaborative encoding and is not designed to probe bonding/affiliation constructs.

This contrast isolates individual over collaborative retrieval and does not target communicative or social-exchange processes (no evidence of social-communication network engagement reported for this contrast).

Although individual encoding involves self-generated labels, the contrast does not target self-reflection, agency, or self-knowledge processes specifically; reported effects are semantic/memory-related rather than classic self-processing signatures.
This contrast reflects individual > collaborative retrieval and does not demonstrate engagement of processes for understanding others; thus perception_others is not measured here.
Arbitrary > Collaborative emphasizes hippocampal and general memory systems for arbitrary pairs compared to collaboratively learned labels; it does not index social interaction or social cognition.

This contrast focuses on arbitrary associative memory versus collaborative encoding and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/ bonding manipulation in the contrast direction).

The contrast isolates memory systems for arbitrary associations and does not reflect production/reception of social communicative signals; thus it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Reported activations reflect hippocampal and other memory-related regions for arbitrary retrieval, not explicit self-related processing or judgments, so perception_self is not measured here.
No evidence that this contrast engages Theory-of-Mind or other-related processing; activations relate to memory and associative retrieval rather than understanding others' mental states.

Analysis ‘Observation of social interactions’ directly measures perception and processing of social interactions (both cooperative and affective). This meets the Social Processing definition and I1.

The task includes cooperative interactions (affiliation/cooperation) as part of the stimuli set; even though the contrast is general observation, affiliation-related content is present and measured. Matches I1 (cooperation example).
The stimuli and contrasts probe exchange of socially relevant information (affective and cooperative interactions, affect recognition and interaction cues), fitting Social Communication. Meets I1.
The analyses probe perception and inference about others’ interactions and intentions, not self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge. Does not meet inclusion criteria for Perception/Self.
The analysis examines understanding of others’ intentions, affectivity and cooperativity—directly targeting perception and understanding of others. Meets I1.
Contrast Cooperativity>Afffectivity explicitly probes social interaction processing focused on cooperation; clearly within Social Processing. Meets I1.
This contrast specifically isolates cooperativity (cooperation) versus affectivity—direct measure of affiliation/attachment-related behavior (cooperation). Meets I1.
Cooperative interactions involve exchange of social information and joint action cues (receptive aspects); contrast measures social communicative content. Meets I1.
Contrast focuses on perceiving others’ cooperative behavior, not self-related processing or judgments. Does not meet inclusion criteria for Perception/Self.
Cooperativity contrast targets understanding others’ action goals and intentions (action perception/mental state inference). Matches Perception/Others I1.
Contrast Affectivity>Cooperativity probes social-affective interaction processing; clearly within Social Processing. Meets I1.

Although this contrast emphasizes affectivity rather than cooperation, affective social interactions relate to affiliation/attachment processes (positive social bonds), and the stimuli/ratings assess these properties. Meets I1.
Affectivity>Cooperativity taps affect recognition and communicative cues in interactions (receptive social communication), fitting the construct. Meets I1.
This contrast addresses perception of others’ affective states and interactions, not self-related processing. Does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.
Affectivity>Cooperativity directly measures inference about others’ affective states and mentalizing (understanding others), matching Perception/Others. Meets I1.
Analysis 3 (unnamed table entry) is part of the same study and therefore pertains to the same task probing social interactions; thus it involves Social Processing. Meets I1.
Given this study’s stimuli and contrasts include cooperative interactions and affiliation-related content, Analysis 3 (study-related) likely measures affiliation/attachment aspects as well. Meets I1.
As with other analyses in this study, Analysis 3 concerns perception of social interactions and communicative cues (affective/cooperative), fitting Social Communication. Meets I1.
No evidence that Analysis 3 assesses self-related processes; study focuses on perception of others’ interactions. Does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.
All analyses probe understanding of others’ intentions, goals and affect—Analysis 3, as part of the study, addresses perception/understanding of others. Meets I1.

The Partnering contrast (Leading + Following + Mutual > Solo + Alone) directly probes brain activity during dyadic, haptic joint action and reports recruitment of social/interaction areas (pSTS, TPJ, mPFC) and somatosensory/proprioceptive networks. This is a social task assessing perception, interpretation, and response to social (partner) cues.

The partnered conditions are cooperative and the Mutual condition specifically engages reward/affiliative circuitry (nucleus accumbens, amygdala). The contrast assesses interaction/cooperation versus solo action, fitting affiliation/attachment (cooperation) constructs.

Partnering requires exchange of haptic cues (signalling and reception) and the paper emphasizes interpersonal information transfer via touch; neural results include areas for dynamic social perception (pSTS, MT+) consistent with social communication (receptive and productive haptic signalling).
Partnered interactions evoke self-related processing and monitoring (mPFC, MCC, insula) and involve self-other integration; the contrast probes self-oriented aspects during social interaction.

Partnering engages mentalizing and action-perception systems (TPJ, pSTS) involved in representing others’ actions and intentions; the contrast explicitly measures perception/understanding of a partner’s movements.

The Leading-specific contrast isolates the leader’s neural profile within a dyadic task. Although motoric, it is embedded in a social joint-action context and engages areas related to self-other integration and interpersonal coordination, so it qualifies as social processing.

Leading occurs within a cooperative dyad; while the contrast emphasizes motor-planning and self-orientation, it is nevertheless part of a cooperative interaction and thus taps cooperative/affiliative behavior (even if not the primary focus).

Leading involves generating signals (haptic cues) to be perceived by a partner; the study frames leaders as conveying intentions via force cues. Even though the contrast is motor-focused, it indexes a communicative function (production of non-facial/haptic communication).

Leading specifically engages self-oriented, self-initiated action systems (SMA, PMC, CMA, IFG) and is explicitly interpreted in terms of agency and self-initiation, matching perception/self constructs (agency, self-monitoring).

Although Leading is more self-oriented, it nonetheless requires integrating partner information and predicting partner responses (self–other integration areas are discussed), so it contributes to representations of others in the context of joint action.

Following-specific contrast isolates neural responses when participants attend/respond to a partner’s haptic cues; this is a prototypical social interactive process involving perception and response to another agent.

Following is embedded in a cooperative dyadic context; the paper links mutuality and partnering to reward/affiliative processes, and following supports coordinated cooperative behavior, satisfying the cooperation aspect of affiliation/attachment.

Following is characterized as heightened receptivity to partner signals (haptic communication). Neural findings include sensory and motion-tracking regions (S2, MT+/pSTS) consistent with reception of non-facial social communication.

Following involves monitoring one’s actions in response to another (ventral ACC/mPFC implicated in monitoring externally-triggered actions), which maps onto self-monitoring and aspects of agency/perception of self in social contexts.
Following explicitly requires perception and tracking of another’s movements and intentions; activations in pSTS and aIPL are directly relevant to action perception and understanding others’ actions.
The Mutual-specific contrast examines symmetric, cooperative dyadic interaction and reports engagement of core social networks (mPFC, TPJ, PCC), so it is squarely a social-processing analysis.

Mutual interaction elicited reward-related activity (nucleus accumbens, amygdala) and is described as the most cooperative/reciprocal condition; this directly maps onto affiliation/attachment (cooperation, social reward).
Mutuality requires continuous exchange and alignment of actions (haptic communication); mentalizing and pSTS involvement indicate ongoing communicative processing between partners.
Mutual recruited mPFC and PCC, areas implicated in self-related processing and balancing internal/external attention, consistent with perception/understanding of self during reciprocal interaction.
Mutual strongly engaged mentalizing regions (TPJ, mPFC, PCC) used for representing others’ intentions and ambiguous agency, matching perception/understanding of others.

The Improvisation contrast (Leading + Solo > Mutual + Alone) includes a social component (Leading) and examines improvisation both in social and solo contexts; the analysis discusses how improvisation operates within joint action, so it taps social processing to an extent.

Improvisation contrasts are primarily concerned with motor-planning and working-memory processes (SMA, DLPFC, PMC) and sequence generation/variability, not with affiliation/cooperative bonding per se. The contrast mixes solo and partnered improvised performance and does not target attachment/cooperation measures specifically.

The improvisation contrast isolates generative motor processes and differentiates them from movement variability; it is not primarily measuring the exchange of social information or communicative reception/production, especially since Solo and Alone are included.

Improvisation engages self-initiated generation and agency-related networks (SMA, DLPFC, CMA) and is interpreted with respect to willed action and self-monitoring, matching perception/self constructs (agency, self-generation).

The core focus of the improvisation contrast is on internal generation and sequence complexity rather than on representing others’ mental states or actions; Following and Mutual (which target perception_of_others) were excluded/handled separately to disambiguate effects.

The Self-initiation contrast ([Leading + Solo + Mutual + Alone] > Following) isolates self- versus externally-triggered action within the experimental context that includes partnered conditions; it therefore probes social processing insofar as self-initiated actions occur within social interactions as well as alone.
This contrast is specifically about agency/self-initiation versus external triggering and is not designed to measure affiliation or bonding/cooperation per se.
Self-initiation analysis addresses endogenous vs. exogenous motor initiation (agency) rather than communicative exchange; it is not primarily testing reception/production of social signals.
The contrast directly targets self-initiated action and associated neural correlates (SPL, DLPFC) and is therefore squarely about agency and self-monitoring processes.
The primary contrast compares self-initiated to externally-driven movement; it is not designed to probe representations or understanding of others’ mental states or actions.

The Joint improvisation/Leading>Solo contrasts examine improvisation within a dyadic context and tests whether leading entails additional partner-related signalling; this is embedded in social interaction and examines social neural correlates.

These joint-improvisation contrasts focus on signalling and combination of improvisation + partnering (motor and somatosensory areas) rather than on cooperative bonding or attachment measures specifically.

Joint improvisation and Leading>Solo are directly concerned with whether leaders signal intentions to partners via haptic cues; the analyses engage/interpret production of non-facial social communication (haptic signalling), so this matches the social_communication construct.
Joint improvisation contrasts evaluate self-initiated generative processes (agency) in a social context (role of leader), implicating self-perception and self-monitoring networks.

These analyses probe leader–partner interactions and whether signals to a partner are present; they therefore relate to representing and anticipating others’ actions/responses (action perception/understanding), consistent with perception_others.

Viewing erotic pictures of male vs female individuals or couples is a social-related task: participants perceive, interpret, and respond to social stimuli (other people). The contrast measures differential neural responses to social stimuli (male vs female persons), meeting I1.
Stimuli are erotic pictures intended to evoke sexual arousal, not tasks or contrasts assessing affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger); thus do not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.

Pictures contain faces, bodies and social cues (face/body perception, potential affective expressions). The contrasts index processing of receptive social signals (facial/body cues), satisfying I1 for social communication (receptive aspects).
Task does not involve self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge. The contrasts compare perception of others, not perception of self, so I1 is not met.

Contrasts explicitly measure responses to other people (male vs female erotic pictures) and involve representations about others’ bodies, actions, and likely mental states (e.g., mentalizing activations reported). This meets I1 for perception/understanding of others.
Viewing erotic pictures (male>female contrast) is a social-related perceptual and evaluative task involving others; the analysis measures social processing (I1).
Contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no loved-one/attachment manipulation); I1 not met.
Images include faces/bodies and social cues; analysis reflects reception of social signals (facial/body perception), meeting I1 for social communication.
No self-related judgments or self-perception measures—contrast concerns perception of others, so I1 not met for self.
Male>female picture contrast indexes differential processing of other people’s characteristics and likely action/animacy perception, meeting I1 for perception of others.
Bisexual women viewing female>male erotic pictures involves social perception of other people; the analysis measures social processing (I1).
Stimuli do not operationalize affiliation or attachment constructs; the task is sexual/erotic perception rather than attachment assessment (I1 not met).
Visual social cues (faces/bodies) are present and the contrast indexes reception of these cues (face/body perception), consistent with social communication reception (I1).
No measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge are included; contrast assesses others, so perception_self I1 is not met.
Contrast evaluates neural responses to other people (female vs male images) and involves processing of others’ appearance/actions, meeting I1 for perception of others.
Bisexual women viewing male>female erotic pictures is a social perceptual task (processing other people); analysis measures social processing (I1).
Task does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/attachment manipulation), so I1 for this annotation is not met.
Male vs female pictures elicit processing of faces/bodies and possibly mentalizing; this reflects receptive social communication processes (I1).
Contrast involves perception of others rather than self-referential processing; thus perception_self I1 is not met.
The contrast measures representations of other people (their bodies, actions, possibly emotions), satisfying I1 for perception of others.
Homosexual women viewing female>male erotic pictures engages perception and evaluation of other people (social stimuli); the analysis measures social processing (I1).
Stimuli do not measure affiliation or attachment (no close-relationship contrasts); I1 not satisfied for affiliation/attachment.
Pictures include faces, bodies, and contextual social cues; contrasts probe reception of social signals (face/body perception), meeting I1 for social communication.

Contrast does not involve measures of affiliation/attachment (no relationship or bonding tasks), so affiliation/attachment I1 not met.

Video contrasts show robust superior temporal (auditory) and face/body processing; presence of vocalizations and communicative social signals means the analysis captures receptive social communication (I1).
No self-related judgments or self-awareness tasks; the analysis concerns perception of others, so perception_self I1 not met.

Heterosexual women viewing male>female erotic videos is a social-related audiovisual perception task; the contrast measures social processing (I1).

The task required participants to perceive and judge emotional valence of vocalisations (human, chimpanzee, macaque) and the fMRI contrast tested neural responses to socially relevant affective signals. This directly measures social processing of affective cues.

The task involved affect recognition from vocalisations but did not assess affiliation, attachment, close relationships, or related constructs (no kinship/loved-one vs stranger or cooperation/competition manipulations).

Participants processed non-facial social communication (auditory affective vocalisations). The contrast probes neural responses to communicative vocal signals across species, meeting the Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication) criteria.
The analysis measured perception of others' vocal affect, not self-related awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not probe Perception/Understanding of Self.

The study measured participants' representations and judgments about others' emotional states from vocal cues (ability to discriminate valence across species) and the fMRI contrast reflects neural correlates of perceiving others' affective states.
