Contrast compares self- vs. celebrity-judgments in a social role task; it directly assesses social processing (self/other evaluation).
Contrast focuses on self versus a distant other (celebrity) and does not probe close relationships, bonding, or attachment processes (no kinship/close-other contrast).
Task involves trait judgments rather than exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals; it does not target facial/expressive communication or communicative interaction.
Self vs. celebrity contrast is a canonical measure of self-referential processing and self-knowledge access.
Because the contrast explicitly involves a non-self person (celebrity), it indexes representation/assessment of others as well (self vs. other comparison).
Friend- vs. celebrity-judgments are a social role evaluation contrast involving interpersonal processes and social cognition.
Contrast pits a close other (friend) against a distant other (celebrity), directly engaging affiliation/close-relationship representation (kinship/close-other processing).
The friend vs. celebrity contrast involves social comparison and evaluation of others, which fits the Social Communication inclusion examples (social comparison/kinship scenarios).
This contrast compares two others (friend and celebrity) and does not directly probe self-referential processing.
Friend vs. celebrity judgments directly assess representations and evaluations of other people (close vs. distant), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis tests moderation (interdependence) of the self- vs. celebrity neural contrast from a social-role task, so it is a social processing analysis.
Although it examines moderation effects, the underlying contrast is self vs. celebrity which does not probe close-affiliation processes.
The analysis concerns self-referential vs. distant-other judgments and the moderation by self-construal, not communicative signal reception/production.
The interaction/moderation analysis is applied to the self- vs. celebrity contrast and therefore indexes self-referential processing moderated by interdependence.
Because the contrast includes a celebrity (other), the moderation analysis also speaks to representation of others (self vs. other).
This analysis examines moderation (interdependence) of friend- vs. celebrity neural responses — clearly a social cognition contrast.
Friend vs. celebrity directly involves a close-other (friend) and thus probes affiliation/attachment-related representations; the moderation analysis targets these affiliation processes.
Friend vs. celebrity comparisons engage social-evaluative/comparative processes consistent with Social Communication inclusion examples (social comparison/kinship scenarios).
The contrast concerns two others (friend and celebrity) and therefore does not index self-referential processing.
This moderation analysis targets neural representations of others (friend vs. celebrity) and functional connectivity during other-processing, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Functional connectivity during self- vs. celebrity-judgments (gPPI with MPFC seed) is derived from a social-role evaluation task and therefore counts as social processing.
The reported functional connectivity analysis concerns self vs. celebrity and does not probe close-affiliation/attachment processes (no close-other contrast).
The PPI examines task-modulated connectivity for self vs. celebrity judgments rather than communicative signal reception/production; it is not a social-communication task per se.
gPPI connectivity using MPFC during self- vs. celebrity-judgments indexes networks supporting self-referential processing.
Because the contrast contrasts self with a non-self (celebrity), the connectivity analysis also informs representations of others (self vs. other).
Functional connectivity during friend- vs. celebrity-judgments (gPPI with MPFC/precuneus seeds) is part of the social-role evaluation paradigm and indexes social processing.
The friend vs. celebrity connectivity contrast specifically targets close-other (friend) processing and thus affiliation/attachment-related neural coupling.
Connectivity differences for friend vs. celebrity reflect social-evaluative/comparative processing (akin to social comparison/kinship scenarios) relevant to social communication constructs.
The contrast concerns two others (friend and celebrity) and does not index self-referential processing.
gPPI results for friend vs. celebrity capture neural representations and interactions supporting understanding of others (close vs. distant).
This is another modulation analysis of self- vs. celebrity processing by interdependence; it derives from the social-role task and reflects social processing.
Underlying contrast is self vs. celebrity, which does not specifically index affiliation or close-relationship processes.
The analysis focuses on self-referential vs. distant-other judgments moderated by self-construal, not on communicative signal reception/production.
The moderation analysis is applied to the self- vs. celebrity contrast, indexing self-knowledge and self-referential processing.
Because the contrast involves a non-self (celebrity), the moderation analysis also informs representation of others (self vs. other).

Study uses a social decision-making task (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing mentalizing and social interaction processes; analysis pertains to social processing across conditions.
Task explicitly contrasts cooperative and competitive partners (cooperation/competition), which directly probes affiliation/attachment-related processes and social bonding/interaction tendencies.
Participants view faces and make decisions in interpersonal exchanges (cooperation/competition), involving reception and use of social cues to guide behavior—fits social communication measures.
Analyses involve participants' decisions, strategy adaptation and self-referential behavior (monitoring/adapting own choices), thus engaging perception/understanding of self.
Core aim is inferring others' intentions (Theory of Mind, rTPJ activity) and distinguishing cooperative vs. competitive partners—directly measures perception/understanding of others.
Contrast Competitive > Cooperative isolates neural responses during social interactions with a noncooperative partner, a social processing measure.
Direct comparison of competitive versus cooperative partners probes affiliation/attachment dynamics (cooperation vs competition).
Contrast examines processing of socially relevant cues and exchange behavior (response to partner behavior), fitting social communication constructs.
Contrast reflects how participants adjust their own decisions and monitor their behavior when faced with a competitive partner, engaging self-perception processes.
Competitive>Cooperative specifically targets brain responses to others' noncooperative intentions (ToM), directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Cooperative > Competitive contrast examines neural activity when interacting with cooperative partners versus competitive ones; a social processing measure.
This contrast emphasizes affiliative/cooperative interactions and associated neural correlates, directly relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Contrast reflects processing of socially cooperative cues and outcome communication between partners, consistent with social communication.
Examines participants' own behavioral responses (choices) in cooperative contexts, implicating self-monitoring and self-related decision processes.
Targets how participants perceive and respond to others' cooperative intentions (ToM/reasoning about others), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
This analysis (Competitive>Cooperative repetition) isolates social cognitive processing related to interacting with a noncooperative partner in the game.
Contrast targets competition versus cooperation, probing affiliation and bonding related processes as participants adapt behavior.
Addresses exchange of socially relevant information (partner behavior) used to guide decisions—fits social communication inclusion.
Reflects changes in participants' own choices and strategy adaptation when facing a competitive partner, implicating self-perception/monitoring.
Directly measures inference about others' intentions (noncooperation) and associated neural markers (rTPJ), matching perception-of-others construct.
Early phase Competitive>Cooperative focuses on time-dependent social processing (initial interactions), directly measuring social cognition dynamics.
Examines early-stage responses to a competitive versus cooperative partner, relevant to affiliation/attachment and early bond/strategy formation.
Early-phase contrast captures reception of social cues and updating of information about partners—fits social communication processes.
Early-phase analysis probes participants' initial self-referential decision-making and monitoring in response to partner behavior, engaging self-related processing.
Specifically targets early inference of others' intentions (ToM) when behavioral evidence is first encountered—clear perception-of-others measure.
Dynamic ToM‐Value Competitive>Cooperative links individual differences in adapting to partners to neural connectivity—addresses social processing and learning about others.
Dynamic ToM captures behavioral adaptation to cooperative vs competitive partners (affiliation/attachment dynamics), so the contrast measures affiliation-related processes.
This analysis uses a behavioral covariate of adaptation (dynamic ToM) tied to exchange behavior and inference about partners, involving social communication mechanisms.
Dynamic ToM value quantifies participants' own differential behavior across partners (self-adaptation), implicating self-perception and monitoring.
Dynamic ToM explicitly indexes understanding and representation of others’ differing intentions and correlates this with neural connectivity—directly perception-of-others.

The study directly contrasts social vs. non-social images and uses both a NeuroSynth meta-analysis of ‘social’ studies and an independent fMRI contrast isolating socialness. This explicitly measures broad social processing. The decision is based on inclusion criteria I1 (social-related task) and I2 (analysis/contrast measures Social Processing).

The paradigm involved valence appraisal of social vs. non-social images but did not specifically assess affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, bonding, cooperation vs. stranger comparisons). The task and contrasts do not correspond to measures of affiliation/attachment (I1 not met).

Although some stimuli included faces and social scenes, the task was a general valence appraisal rather than measures of social communicative exchange (reception/production of facial or non-facial communication). The analysis does not target social communication per the inclusion criteria (I1 not met).

The task required judgments about image valence and did not involve self-referential processing, agency, or self-knowledge judgments. Thus it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria (I1 not met).

The contrast isolates processing of images containing humans and social interactions versus non-social scenes, which engages perception and understanding of others (animacy/action perception and representations of others). The social vs. non-social contrast is a measure of Perception/Understanding of Others. Decision based on inclusion criteria I1 (task/stimuli involve perception of others) and I2 (contrast measures Perception of Others).

This analysis tests the main effect of modality on valence judgments of facial, vocal, and bimodal emotional expressions — a social-related emotion perception task involving recognition and interpretation of others' emotional cues, directly measuring social processing.

The main effect of modality concerns emotion perception (face vs voice) and does not measure affiliation or attachment processes (no tasks or contrasts involving kinship, bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons).
The task involves reception of facial and vocal emotional signals (affect recognition), fitting the Social Communication construct (receptive aspects: facial and non-facial communication).
Analyses reflect judgments about others' emotional expressions (perception of external stimuli), not self-related judgments, self-awareness, or agency.
The main effect of modality evaluates how participants perceive and interpret others' emotional states from faces and voices, directly measuring Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis tests the main effect of emotion (anger, happiness, neutral) during valence judgments — a core social task involving emotion recognition and interpretation of others' expressions.
The main effect of emotion concerns recognition of emotional valence and intensity, not affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding, kinship, or cooperative behavior.
Emotion category effects reflect reception of socially relevant signals (facial and vocal affect), which falls squarely within Social Communication (receptive facial and non-facial communication).
The analysis addresses perception of external emotional stimuli (others), not self-related judgments or self-knowledge processes.
Main effect of emotion captures how participants perceive and differentiate others' emotional states (anger vs happiness vs neutral), directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

The Emotion × Modality interaction examines how modality (face, voice, bimodal) modulates emotion perception — a social cognitive process involving interpretation of others' affective signals, thus measuring social processing broadly.
The interaction concerns perceptual/emotional differences across modalities and emotions, not affiliation/attachment measures or contrasts (no bonding, kinship, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons).
The interaction reflects differential reception of facial vs vocal emotional communication (reception subconstructs), directly relevant to Social Communication.
The interaction pertains to perception of others' affect across modalities, not to self-perception or self-referential judgments.
The Emotion × Modality interaction documents how participants perceive others' emotional states differently depending on modality, directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast compares agentic vs. communal trait ratings during self-evaluation — a social-related task about processing social trait information and self-related evaluation. Meets criterion I1 (social-related task).
Task is self-evaluation of traits (agency vs. communion) and does not measure affiliation/attachment, kinship, cooperation, or bonding per se. I1 was considered but not met.

Contrast involves internal self-judgment rather than exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals (faces, gestures, conversation). Not a social-communication task. I1 considered but not met.
Directly measures judgments about the self (agentic vs. communal self-evaluation), meeting the Perception/Self inclusion criterion I1.
Contrast concerns self-evaluation (SA vs SC) rather than representations of others' traits or mental states. I1 considered but not met.
SC vs SA contrasts communal vs. agentic trait judgments during self-evaluation — a social-related self-processing task. Meets I1.
This contrast contrasts trait domains within self-evaluation and does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (kinship, bonding, cooperation). I1 considered but not met.
Contrast reflects internal trait judgments rather than communicative reception/production; does not meet social communication examples. I1 considered but not met.
Direct self-referential trait evaluation (communal vs agentic) — fits Perception/Self (I1).
No processing of others' states/traits in this contrast; focused on self-knowledge. I1 considered but not met.
OA vs OC contrasts endorsement of others' agentic vs communal evaluations of the participant — clearly social-processing involving social feedback and evaluation. Meets I1.
Although social feedback is involved, the task does not directly measure attachment or affiliation/bonding (no kinship, cooperation, or attachment scales). I1 considered but not met.
Participants process and respond to social feedback (others' evaluations) — an exchange of socially relevant information consistent with Social Communication I1.
Endorsing others' evaluations of the self requires making judgments about oneself (agreement with others' ratings), so it engages Perception/Self processes (I1).
Task requires considering others' evaluations (representations of others' judgments about the participant) — involves Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).
OC vs OA contrasts endorsement of others' communal vs agentic evaluations — a social-feedback/social-processing contrast. Meets I1.
Contrast involves social feedback but not direct measures of affiliation or attachment constructs; I1 considered but not met.
Engages processing of socially exchanged information (others' evaluations) and participants' responses, consistent with Social Communication I1.
Participants judge their agreement with others' communal vs agentic evaluations of themselves — engages self-perception and self-knowledge (I1).
Requires representing and evaluating others' judgments about the participant (understanding others' evaluations), matching Perception/Others I1.
SA vs Fixation (with regression on self-esteem) examines neural responses during agentic self-evaluation — a social/self-processing task. Meets I1.
This analysis focuses on agentic self-evaluation and its correlation with trait self-esteem; it does not target attachment/affiliation measures. I1 considered but not met.
The contrast compares self-evaluation to fixation and analyzes relationships with self-esteem; it does not involve communicative reception/production of social signals. I1 considered but not met.
Directly probes agentic self-evaluation processes and their neural correlates with self-esteem — meets Perception/Self I1.
Contrast is self-focused (agentic self-evaluation) and does not measure representations of others' states or traits. I1 considered but not met.
PPI with dlPFC seed during SA vs Fixation examines connectivity during agentic self-evaluation — part of social/self-processing. Meets I1.
Connectivity analysis during agentic self-evaluation does not target affiliation/attachment constructs. I1 considered but not met.

Although connectivity involves regions linked to emotion and control, the analysis is about internal self-evaluation connectivity rather than communicative signal processing; not a Social Communication task per se. I1 considered but not met.
Seed-based connectivity during agentic self-evaluation addresses neural substrates of self-related processing, fitting Perception/Self I1.
PPI during SA examines self-evaluation networks and does not directly probe representations of others. I1 considered but not met.
PPI with thalamus seed during SA vs Fixation investigates connectivity during agentic self-evaluation — falls under social/self-processing. Meets I1.
Analysis focuses on thalamic connectivity during agentic self-evaluation and does not assess affiliation/attachment measures. I1 considered but not met.

Thalamic PPI during self-evaluation probes network integration for self-related processing rather than communicative reception/production; not a Social Communication contrast. I1 considered but not met.
Connectivity patterns during agentic self-evaluation relate to self-perception and retrieval of autobiographical information — meets Perception/Self I1.
This PPI analysis centers on self-evaluation networks and does not directly measure understanding of others' mental states or traits. I1 considered but not met.

The emotional > neutral contrast examines empathy and mentalising using naturalistic videos and continuous ratings; this directly probes social processing (perception, interpretation and response to others' emotions).
The contrast does not probe affiliation, attachment, bonding, or related constructs (no tasks comparing loved ones/kin or cooperation/attachment measures).
Participants view and interpret dynamic social signals (facial/expressive and verbal cues) to judge others' emotional intensity, meeting social communication (reception) criteria.
The contrast targets perception of others' emotions rather than self-awareness or self-judgments; self-related processing is not the focus of this contrast.
The task explicitly measures understanding and tracking of others' emotional states (empathic accuracy), which directly indexes perception/understanding of others.
The neutral > emotional contrast still concerns processing of social video stimuli and mind-wandering differences, and thus pertains to social processing in the task context.
This contrast compares engagement/mind-wandering between neutral and emotional social stimuli but does not assess attachment or affiliation constructs.

Even when neutral > emotional, the stimuli are videos of people and participants make judgments; the paradigm involves reception of social communicative cues, so this contrast relates to social communication.

Although neutral clips may evoke self-referential processes (e.g., mind-wandering), the primary contrast examines response to others' video descriptions rather than measuring self-perception explicitly.
The comparison concerns responses to videos of other people (their descriptions of events), and thus involves perception and understanding of others, even if activity is higher for neutral clips.
Modulation of BOLD by intra-individual Z-EA (empathic accuracy) directly indexes social cognitive processing related to perceiving and understanding others' emotions, fitting broad social processing.
Empathic accuracy measures tracking others' emotions and mentalising, not affiliation/attachment or bonding per se.
Z-EA reflects how well participants interpret dynamic social cues from targets (receptive social communication), so the analysis maps onto social communication.
This analysis examines accuracy in perceiving others' states rather than self-related judgments or self-monitoring, so it does not meet perception-self criteria.
Empathic accuracy is a direct measure of representing and reasoning about others' emotional states (mentalising), matching perception_others inclusion criteria.
Negative modulation by Z-EA still concerns variance in social cognitive performance (how brain activity relates to differences in empathic accuracy), so it is within social processing.
Negative relationships with EA do not address affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding measures.

Regions negatively related to EA reflect aspects of processing social communicative cues or regulatory control during social judgments; the task is about interpreting others' signals (social communication).

Although some negatively related regions (e.g., frontal pole) can be involved in self-referential processing, the analysis targets relationships with empathic accuracy (others), not explicit self-perception measures.
This contrast examines how brain activity covaries (negatively) with accuracy in understanding others' emotional states, directly addressing perception/understanding of others.
Positive correlations between BOLD and participants' continuous ratings of targets' emotional intensity track dynamic social perception and emotion understanding, central to social processing.
This analysis measures moment-to-moment perception of others' emotions, not affiliation/attachment or bonding.
Continuous rating of others' emotional intensity requires reception and interpretation of facial/verbal/nonverbal communicative signals, fitting social communication reception.
The focus is on time-locked perception of others' emotional intensity; any self-report is secondary and the contrast does not target self-awareness explicitly.
This analysis directly measures neural correlates of perceiving and tracking others' emotional states over time, meeting perception_others criteria.

Negative correlations with emotional intensity ratings (regions more active when perceived intensity is low) still reflect processing of social/emotional stimuli and thus are within social processing.
This analysis does not probe attachment/affiliation constructs; it examines inverse relationships with perceived emotional intensity.

Regions negatively correlated with intensity relate to processing of communicative signals (e.g., visual areas, default mode) and the task involves reception of social cues, so it maps to social communication.
Although negative correlations point to increased self-referential/default-mode activity, the analysis is defined by participants' ratings of others and is not an explicit self-perception contrast.
The contrast examines how neural activity relates inversely to perceived emotional intensity of others, which is directly about understanding others' emotional states.

This entry lists peak coordinates from the general semantics literature (not a social-related task or contrast). It does not represent an analysis of social stimuli or contrasts between social and non-social conditions.
The general semantics peaks do not originate from tasks measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger), so the inclusion criteria are not met.
This analysis/table summarizes general semantic peaks and is not a task measuring social communication (facial/non-facial reception/production).
The general semantics peak table does not reflect tasks probing self-perception or self-knowledge.
The general semantics peaks are not from tasks explicitly measuring perception or understanding of others' mental states/traits/actions.
This entry contains peak coordinates from the face-selective ATL literature (face recognition studies). These are social stimuli/analyses and thus fall under broad social processing.
Face-selective ATL studies focus on face recognition/person identity rather than affiliation/attachment tasks (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation measures).
Face-selective ATL studies directly measure reception of facial communication/face recognition, which maps onto social communication (receptive facial communication).
Face-selective ATL literature addresses perception of others' faces/identity rather than self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge.
Face-processing studies concern perception and recognition of other people (identity, facial features), fitting perception/understanding of others.

This contrast (social: faces + spoken names of famous people > non-social: landmarks) explicitly tests social semantic processing (person knowledge) and therefore meets the broad social processing criterion.
The task is an identity/occupation (nationality) judgement about famous people vs landmarks, not an affiliation/attachment measure (no kinship, loved-one comparisons, cooperation).
The contrast includes face perception and spoken name recognition (reception of facial/non-facial cues), which fall under social communication (receptive aspects).
The task requires recognition and semantic knowledge about others (people) rather than self-related judgments or self-perception.
The contrast probes representation and recognition of other people (famous individuals), aligning with perception and understanding of others (identity/traits).
Although this contrast is non-social > social, the experimental design includes social stimuli (faces and spoken names of people) and thus addresses social processing in the dataset.
The contrast compares landmarks and people; it does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship or attachment measures).

The comparison involves face and spoken name stimuli, which are receptive social communication tasks (facial/name recognition), so this analysis is relevant to social communication even if the contrast highlights non-social activations.
The task concerns recognition of other entities (people/landmarks) rather than self-related processing.

The dataset includes tasks probing knowledge about other people (famous faces/names), mapping onto perception and understanding of others even if this particular contrast emphasizes non-social responses.
This contrast (social: faces + written names > non-social: Camel and Cactus) specifically tests person-related semantic processing and thus is squarely within social processing.
The tasks involve occupation/association matching for famous people and objects, not measures of affiliation or attachment.
Face perception and name-based person recognition are receptive social communication processes and are directly assessed in this contrast.
The task assesses semantic knowledge about other people and objects rather than self-related processes.
The contrast probes recognition/knowledge of other people (famous persons), consistent with perception and understanding of others.
This is the reverse contrast of Study 2 (non-social > social) but the experiment includes social person stimuli; therefore it pertains to social processing in the dataset.
The contrast does not test affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship or relationship-bond measures).
The underlying tasks include face and name recognition (receptive social communication), so the analysis is relevant to social communication despite the contrast direction.
The task is about other people/objects, not self-perception or self-knowledge.
The experiment includes recognition and semantic knowledge of other people (famous faces/names), mapping onto perception/understanding of others.
This contrast (social concept words > non-social abstract words) directly probes socially relevant conceptual knowledge (social trait/behavior words) and thus meets broad social processing criteria.
The synonym judgment task for social concept words assesses social semantics (e.g., polite) rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/attachment measures).

This task involves conceptual/semantic judgments about social words rather than reception or production of facial or communicative signals; it does not directly map onto social communication subconstructs.
The synonym judgment of social concept words is not a task about the participant's own traits, agency, or self-knowledge but about word meanings.
Social concept words concern social traits/behavior and understanding of socially relevant attributes, which map onto perception/understanding of others' traits and social knowledge.

Although this contrast highlights non-social > social, the conditions include socially relevant concept words versus non-social abstract words, so the dataset and analysis address social semantic processing.
The contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs; it compares social concept semantics to non-social abstract words.
The analysis concerns conceptual word meaning (social vs non-social), not reception/production of communicative signals (faces/affect), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The task involves synonym judgments about word meanings, not self-referential judgments or self-knowledge tasks.

The analysis includes social concept words that reflect attributes/traits relevant to understanding others; thus it relates to perception/understanding of others even if the contrast emphasizes non-social activations.

The mind-rating parametric analysis examines mind perception (attributing internal states) using faces and relates neural activity to social-cognitive judgments — clearly a social-processing task measuring social cognition.
The analysis does not measure affiliation or attachment (no tasks or contrasts probing bonding, close relationships, cooperation, or kinship); it focuses on mind perception rather than attachment.

The task uses face stimuli and judgments about internal states and eyes/gaze — constructs directly related to reception of facial/nonverbal communication (eye gaze, facial cues); thus it measures social communication.
The analysis targets perception and inference about others' minds, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge, so it does not measure perception of the self.

Mind-rating parametric analysis explicitly targets perceiving and reasoning about others' internal states (animacy/mental state attribution), matching the perception_others construct (animacy, action perception, understanding mental states).
The gaze-cuing parametric analysis links neural activity to gaze-cueing behavior, a low-level social attention measure; this is a social-processing analysis of how observers respond to social cues.
The analysis measures gaze-cueing and attention to gaze, not affiliation/attachment or bonding/cooperation; no contrasts or tasks probe attachment-related constructs.
Gaze-cueing directly involves production/reception of nonverbal communication (eye gaze/following) and the analysis relates neural responses to gaze-following behavior — fitting social_communication.
The analysis concerns perception of others' gaze/intentions and behavior, not self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge); thus it does not meet perception_self.
Gaze-cueing measures attention to others' gaze and relates behavior to inferring others' intentions/animacy; this matches perception_others (animacy/action perception/understanding mental states).

Task is an emotional face-recognition paradigm using the mother’s own child’s facial emotions — a canonical social processing task (perception, interpretation, and response to social/emotional cues). This contrast (happy-own > neutral-own) measures social processing of child affect across participants.

Stimuli are the mother’s own child (a primary attachment figure) and the contrast targets positive affiliative cues (happy faces). Although not a direct own vs stranger contrast, the task probes attachment-relevant processing and bonding-related responsiveness to the child’s positive affect.

The task requires reception and classification of facial affect (receptive facial communication). The contrast isolates neural responses to emotional facial signals (happy vs neutral) and therefore indexes social communication processes (affect recognition).
Contrast involves perception of another’s (child’s) facial emotions and does not probe self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

Contrast measures mothers’ representations and interpretation of their child’s emotional state (understanding others’ emotions), directly matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

This is the ELM-specific contrast of happy-own > neutral-own (ELM>CON masked), directly assessing altered social/emotional processing of the mother’s own child in the maltreatment group. It therefore indexes social processing.

The contrast examines group differences in neural responses to positive (affiliative) cues from the mother’s own child, which is relevant to attachment/affiliation processes (how mothers respond to their child as an attachment figure).
The analysis isolates group-specific differences in receptive facial communication (recognition/processing of the child’s happy expression), so it meets social communication inclusion criteria.
This group-specific contrast concerns perception of the child’s emotions and does not probe self-related cognition or self-monitoring, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The contrast reflects altered representation and understanding of the child’s emotional state in ELM mothers versus controls, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast involves recalling interpersonal relationship episodes (self-relevant) — a clearly social task engaging social cognition, memory, and affect; thus it measures broad Social Processing relevant to affiliation, self- and other-referencing.

The task specifically elicits formative relationship episodes and internal working models / recurrent interpersonal behavior, which map onto affiliation and attachment constructs; the contrast (self-relevant > control) directly measures recall of attachment-relevant relationship episodes.

The contrast is an autobiographical recall task focused on self-referential relationship episodes rather than measuring reception or production of communicative behavior (facial/gestural/verbal exchange); it does not operationalize social communication per the annotation definition.

The contrast contrasts self-relevant episodic recall vs control, directly probing self-reflection and self-related processing (self-knowledge/agency), satisfying the Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

This specific contrast (self-relevant > control) does not measure perception or understanding of others; although the study includes an other condition, this particular analysis isolates self-referential recall and thus does not meet the annotation criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

Impression-formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status is a social task assessing how participants perceive and respond to social information; fits Social Processing inclusion (I1).
Task involves forming impressions of faces but does not measure affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment-related processes (I1 for this construct not met).
Task requires perception of faces and forming impressions (receptive facial communication / facial recognition), matching Social Communication inclusion (I1).
Analyses probe perception of others (impression formation) rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge; Perception/Self inclusion (I1) not met.
Primary task is forming impressions and evaluating others’ race and status, directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).
Same impression-formation context (faces varying by race and status); broadly assesses social processing and network-level social cognition (I1).
No measures of affiliation/attachment, bonding, cooperation, or relationship formation are present; does not meet Affiliation/Attachment inclusion (I1).
Impression formation from facial stimuli entails reception of facial communication and face-based social information (meets Social Communication I1).
Analyses concern perception of others and neural coactivation related to impression formation rather than self-reflection or self-knowledge (Perception/Self I1 not met).
Directly measures representations and evaluations of other people (race and status), satisfying Perception/Others inclusion (I1).
Control task involves explicit evaluations of faces (actors/models), a social task assessing face-based evaluations and thus falls under Social Processing (I1).
Control task requires attractiveness/likeability ratings of faces but does not probe affiliation, attachment, or relationship processes (Affiliation/Attachment I1 not met).
Task entails reception of facial information and making judgments based on faces (receptive facial communication), meeting Social Communication inclusion (I1).
Control analyses focus on evaluating others (actors/models) rather than self-related processing; Perception/Self inclusion (I1) not met.
Explicit evaluations of other individuals’ attractiveness/likeability directly index Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).
As above, control-task PLS results concern face evaluation, a social processing domain (I1).
No measures of affiliation, bonding, or attachment in the control task; Affiliation/Attachment inclusion (I1) not met.
Evaluative ratings of facial stimuli involve reception of facial cues and social communicative information, satisfying Social Communication inclusion (I1).
Analyses target evaluations of external faces rather than self-referential processes; Perception/Self inclusion (I1) not met.
Control-task contrasts index perception and evaluation of other people (actors/models), meeting Perception/Others inclusion (I1).

The analysis is part of the study on face and voice emotion integration—clearly a social-related task measuring social processing (emotion perception/integration).
The tasks contrast emotional faces/voices and their integration; they do not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation, etc.).
The analysis assesses reception and integration of facial and vocal emotional signals (receptive aspects of social communication), matching the construct.
The contrasts probe perception of others' facial and vocal emotion, not self-related awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
The analyses evaluate representation and understanding of others' emotional states from faces and voices (animacy/action/emotion perception), fitting this construct.
Bimodal > unimodal contrasts probe multisensory integration of emotional face/voice signals—a social processing task measuring social perception and integration.
This contrast tests multisensory emotion integration, not affiliation/attachment (no relationship/attachment manipulations).
Contrast measures reception and integration of facial and vocal emotional communication (receptive social communication).
Contrast involves perception of others' faces/voices; it does not assess self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge).
Bimodal > unimodal contrasts index processing and integration of others' emotional signals—directly assessing perception/understanding of others.
The incongruent > congruent contrast examines how conflicting facial and vocal emotional information is processed—clearly a social processing measure.
The congruency manipulation addresses emotional signal conflict, not affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific processing.
This contrast probes reception and interpretation of conflicting facial and vocal communicative signals (receptive social communication).
The contrast concerns perception of others' emotions and conflict resolution, not self-related cognition or self-assessment.
Incongruency effects reflect how observers represent and reason about others' emotional states from multimodal cues, matching perception_of_others.

The task is a face-based trustworthiness judgment with feedback about others' cooperative vs selfish behavior — a prototypical social processing task involving perception, interpretation, and learning about social information.

The contrast concerns judgments and feedback about cooperative versus selfish individuals (cooperation/noncooperation), directly indexing affiliation/attachment-related processes (cooperation behavior).
Participants evaluate facial cues to infer trustworthiness and update impressions based on feedback — this involves reception of facial communication and social information exchange.
The analyses target judgments about others' trustworthiness and neural responses to feedback about others, not self-referential judgments or explicit measures of self-knowledge/agency.
The contrasts probe representations and learning about other persons' traits (cooperative vs selfish) and involve mentalizing and trait inference about others.
Contrast of congruent > incongruent feedback during a social (trustworthiness) task measures social processing of feedback about others.
The congruent vs incongruent contrast concerns feedback about cooperative vs selfish persons, directly relating to affiliation/cooperation processes.
This contrast examines processing of facially derived social information and feedback, implicating reception of facial communication and updating.
The contrast addresses processing of feedback about others' traits rather than self-related judgments or self-knowledge.
Congruent > incongruent feedback reflects differential representation and learning about others' traits, matching perception/understanding of others.
Age × feedback interaction in reward-related regions during a social trustworthiness task is still social processing (how social feedback is neurally processed across ages).
The interaction examines neural responses to cooperative vs selfish feedback (impression congruency) across age groups, which is directly relevant to affiliation/attachment (cooperation) processing.
The analysis concerns processing of facially-derived social feedback and updating across ages, implicating reception and interpretation of facial/social signals.
The focus is on neural responses to feedback about others' trustworthiness and age differences therein, not on self-referential processing per se.
Age × feedback effects specifically index how participants represent and update knowledge about others' cooperative vs selfish traits, fitting perception/understanding of others.
Younger > older contrast in reward-related regions during social feedback processing concerns social cognitive differences and thus qualifies as social processing.
This contrast reflects age differences in processing feedback about cooperative vs selfish others, relating to affiliation/cooperation processes.
The contrast captures differences in neural responses to socially communicated information (faces and feedback) between age groups.
Although feedback can carry information about participants' performance, the analyses target responses to others' trait feedback rather than explicit self-related evaluation.
This contrast indexes age differences in brain activity when processing information about others' trustworthiness, aligning with perception/understanding of others.
Congruent > incongruent in reward-related regions during a trustworthiness task is social processing of feedback about others.
This contrast contrasts feedback relating to cooperative versus selfish people and thus maps onto affiliation/attachment (cooperation) processes.
The contrast examines processing of facially-derived social feedback and implication for social communication (reception of facial cues and feedback).
The analysis concerns processing of feedback about others' traits rather than explicit self-awareness or self-judgments.
Congruent > incongruent feedback indexes differential representation/learning about others' traits (cooperative vs selfish), consistent with perception/understanding of others.

Conjunction of Leading and Following vs Rest involves an interactive joint-action task (participant physically interacting with experimenter). The task probes social interaction and processing of partner cues during movement, satisfying the social processing criterion.
The task is a cooperative joint-action movement but does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no loved one vs stranger, no bonding or attachment scales).
Leading/following requires the exchange of haptic and movement cues between partners (transmission/reception of signals); the conjunction captures this interactive communication element.

The task involves self-generated action and agency (leading entails initiation and self-monitoring); the conjunction includes motor and self-related regions (SMA, MCC), relevant to perception/understanding of self.

Joint interaction requires representing and responding to the partner's actions (action perception); conjunction includes areas involved in action observation and somatosensation relevant to perceiving others.
Followers-only conjunction still reflects the interactive joint-action task with an experimenter; social processing of partner cues is intrinsic to the task.
The analysis does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding measures; it focuses on sensorimotor and role-specific expertise, not attachment.
Follower participants rely on reception of partner cues (haptic/movement signaling) constituting non-facial social communication; the conjunction captures interaction-related communication processes.
Even in followers-only conjunction, participants perform self-generated movements and monitoring; motor/self-related areas are engaged, relevant to perception of one's own actions and agency.

Followers specifically track partner signals and engage regions implicated in perceiving others (e.g., pSTS, TPJ reported elsewhere), so the conjunction reflects perception/understanding of others' actions.
Contrast Leading > Following targets role-specific processes within an interactive social task; leading is a social coordinative behavior implicating social processing networks.
This contrast examines role-specific motor/agency differences rather than affiliation or attachment-related constructs.
Leading requires transmitting signals to the partner (non-verbal/haptic communication); the contrast isolates neural correlates of that communicative exchange.
Leading engages self-related processes (action initiation, agency, self-monitoring; e.g., SMA, CMA, PMC), consistent with perception/understanding of self.
Although leading is more self-oriented, it still involves representing partner actions to coordinate movements; neural systems for action perception and partner monitoring are relevant.
Contrast Following > Leading focuses on externally-oriented, mentalizing and partner-tracking processes during an interactive social task, fitting social processing.
The contrast isolates follower-related perceptual/mentalizing processes rather than measuring affiliation or attachment between partners.
Following depends on reception of partner-generated cues (haptic and movement information), comprising non-facial social communication/reception processes captured by this contrast.

Following is primarily externally-oriented (tracking partner cues, mentalizing) rather than focusing on self-awareness or agency; the contrast emphasizes perception of others rather than self-related processes.
Following engages mentalizing and action-perception regions (TPJ, PCC, pSTS) implicated in understanding others' actions and mental states, matching perception/understanding of others.
Regression of Leading>Following with leader skill examines how social/interactive role expertise modulates neural responses during joint action, so it targets social processing.
This regression targets expertise effects on role-specific motor/social processing, not affiliation/attachment measures.
Leader-skill correlations highlight regions supporting the transmission of signals and interactional communication (e.g., dPMC, STG, insula), fitting social communication processes.
Leader-skill correlates include premotor and SMA regions tied to agency and self-initiated action; the regression probes self-related processing differences with expertise.
Even leader-skill effects involve coordination with a partner and processing partner-related signals (STG/insular involvement), implicating aspects of perceiving others' actions.
Deactivations/negative correlations in the leader-skill regression still relate to social role processing during joint interaction and are part of the study's social-processing focus.
These deactivations are related to expertise-modulated role processing, not measures of affiliation/attachment.
Negative correlations with leader skill likely reflect reduced or altered communicative/interactional processing in certain regions with expertise, which is relevant to social communication.
Deactivations tied to leader skill may reflect changes in self-related processing (automation or reduced self-monitoring) with expertise, thus relating to perception of self.
Even deactivations in leader-skill regressions occur within the context of partner interaction and could relate to altered processing of others' actions or signals with increasing expertise.
Regression of Leading vs Following with follower skill probes how social/interactive expertise modulates neural responses during joint action, matching social processing.
This analysis examines follower-expertise effects on mentalizing and perceptual networks, not affiliation/attachment measures.
Follower-skill correlations highlight reception and interpretation of partner cues (TPJ, pSTS, mPFC), reflecting social communication/reception processes.
Follower-skill effects are primarily externally-oriented (mentalizing, action perception of partner) rather than probing self-awareness or agency, so perception_self is not central here.
Follower-skill correlations involve TPJ, PCC, pSTS and mPFC—regions classically tied to understanding others' actions and mental states, directly matching perception/understanding of others.

The analysis examines neural responses during an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma social interaction task (reciprocated cooperation CC in males). This directly measures broad social processing (perceiving, interpreting and responding to social information).
The contrast is CC (reciprocated cooperation), a cooperation outcome probing affiliation/attachment-related processes (positive social bonding and reward), matching the inclusion examples.
The PD task involves exchange of socially relevant information (cooperate/defect choices and feedback). The CC contrast captures social communicative signals and their neural processing.

Responses to CC outcomes reflect self-relevant evaluations (reward, agency, self-monitoring of cooperation decisions and outcomes), consistent with Perception/Self inclusion examples (cooperation/competition).
CC outcomes require assessing the partner's behavior (reciprocation), engaging theory-of-mind and understanding others' intentions, directly matching Perception/Others criteria.
The analysis examines neural responses during the iterated Prisoner's Dilemma to CC outcomes in females, which is a prototypical social interaction task measuring social processing.
CC (reciprocated cooperation) probes affiliation and bonding processes (positive social interaction/reward) in females, meeting the affiliation/attachment criteria.
The PD task involves exchange of social decisions and feedback; CC trials capture communicative content (cooperative signal) and its neural processing in females.
Female participants' neural responses to CC reflect self-referential processing and evaluation of outcomes of their own cooperative choices, aligning with Perception/Self criteria.
CC trials require representing and evaluating the partner's reciprocation (others' intentions/mental states), meeting the Perception/Others inclusion criteria.
This analysis assesses neural responses to CD (unreciprocated cooperation) in males during the PD social interaction task, a direct measure of social processing of negative social feedback.
CD (partner defects after subject cooperates) probes affiliation/attachment dynamics (breach of cooperation, social bonding consequences) and is an affiliation/attachment-relevant contrast.
CD outcomes convey social signals (non-reciprocation) and thus involve social communication processes (exchange and interpretation of partner behavior) measured neurally.
The CD contrast elicits self-relevant processing (assessment of one's decision consequences, emotional response), consistent with Perception/Self inclusion (cooperation/competition).
Unreciprocated cooperation requires understanding the partner's choice and intentions (mentalizing), directly fitting Perception/Others criteria.
This analysis examines neural responses to CD (unreciprocated cooperation) in females during the PD social interaction task, which is a social processing measure of negative social interactions.
CD trials probe affiliation dynamics and the consequences of non-reciprocation on social bonds, matching affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The PD CD contrast captures socially communicative information (partner's defect after subject's cooperation) and its neural encoding in females.
Female responses to CD reflect self-evaluative processing and emotional appraisal of outcomes of one's cooperative choice, aligning with Perception/Self criteria.
CD outcomes require assessing partner intent and behavior (mentalizing and understanding others), directly meeting Perception/Others criteria.

The H> L feedback contrast indexes responses to an opponent's provocation (monetary reduction) in the Taylor Aggression Paradigm — a social interaction task. This directly measures social processing (perceiving and responding to socially relevant cues).

The feedback phase occurs in a competitive/cooperative context (competitive punishment vs. opponent) and thus taps affiliation/attachment related processes (competition, social bonding/antagonism). The contrast compares high vs low provocation in that social-competitive context.

The feedback contrast captures exchange of socially relevant information (opponent's punitive actions) and communication-like social signals (provocation), so it meets criteria for social communication.

Although a feedback contrast primarily reflects perception of the opponent, it also indexes internal appraisal and state changes (anger) that relate to self-perception and self-related processing following social feedback; thus it qualifies under self-related perception.
The high vs low provocation feedback directly involves assessing another person’s action/intention (opponent taking money), i.e. perception and understanding of others’ behavior and intent.
The L>H feedback contrast is also derived from the TAP social interaction and measures differential processing of social feedback (low vs high provocation), thus indexing social processing.

Contrasting low over high provocation within the competitive interaction reflects processes related to social affiliation/competition and responding to different social valences in relationships with an opponent.
Low vs high provocation comparisons capture variations in socially communicated intent/behavior between players, fitting the social communication construct.
Responses to low versus high provocation involve internal appraisal and emotional state (anger) differences, implicating self-related perception and monitoring.
The contrast measures how participants perceive and evaluate the opponent’s actions (others’ behavior) under differing provocation levels, meeting the perception-of-others criterion.

The decision-phase H> L contrast captures how participants decide to respond to high vs low provocation — a social decision-making process engaging social cognition and processing of social information (DMN involvement reported).
Decisions about punishing an opponent in a competitive context directly index affiliation/attachment dynamics (competition, social bonding/antagonism) and thus meet this construct.
The decision to retaliate represents a form of social exchange/communication (sending a punitive signal); the contrast measures these communicative social behaviors.

The decision period engages self-referential processing (introspection, evaluation of how to respond, state anger), with the paper specifically noting DMN engagement related to self/social cognition — satisfying self-perception criteria.
Deciding how much to punish the opponent necessarily involves representing the opponent’s prior action/intentions (mental state inference), so it indexes perception and understanding of others.
The L>H decision contrast still reflects social decision-making in the TAP (responses after low vs high provocation), capturing social processing.
Choosing how to respond after low provocation occurs within the competitive social context and relates to affiliation/attachment processes (decisions about social behavior toward another).
Decisions to act (or not) after low vs high provocation convey social communicative intent; the contrast therefore measures social communication processes.
The decision period involves self-monitoring and internal decision processes (self-related cognition), so perception_self is relevant even when contrasting low over high provocation.
Even when contrasting low>high during decision, participants must represent the opponent and their actions — matching perception-of-others criteria.

The reported 2-way interaction (treatment × genotype) relates to neural responses during the decision period to social provocation (cuneus effect) and to behavioral/anger differences in a social task; this is a social-processing effect.
The interaction modulated responses in a competitive social context (reactive aggression/retaliation), which pertains to affiliation/attachment (competition/cooperation) constructs.
The gene×hormone interaction influenced neural correlates of retaliatory decision-making — a social communicative behavior — thus fitting the social_communication construct.
The interaction affected task-related anger and decision-related brain activity (self-referential/attentional processes during decisions), implicating self-perception mechanisms.
The interaction modulated processing of an opponent’s provocation and subsequent responses (understanding others’ behavior), so perception_of_others applies.

Contrast compares cooperative vs competitive social exchanges in a dyadic interactive task and models brain responses to a partner's behavior (iBBD). This directly assesses social processing broadly (interaction, intention inference, reward, monitoring).

Cooperation vs competition contrast probes affiliation/attachment-relevant processes (cooperation as affiliative, reward-related activity in ventral striatum and related circuits reported), matching the affiliation/attachment construct.
The task requires real-time exchange of behavior and mutual adaptation (communicative exchange of intentions/actions). Modeling responses to partner moves indexes social communicative interaction.

Contrasting cooperation and competition measured brain regions implicated in self-related processes (e.g., precuneus, mPFC) and self-other distinction; Builders and Others recruit self-related monitoring when reacting to partner behavior.
The contrast assesses neural reactions to another’s actions and mentalizing (STS, TPJ, mPFC), directly indexing perception and understanding of others’ intentions and actions.

Competition > cooperation contrast isolates social interaction processes under competitive goal structure; still a social task modeling responses to partner behavior (iBBD), so broad social processing applies.
Although focusing on competition, the contrast directly compares affiliation-relevant states (competition versus cooperation) and thus probes affiliation/attachment dimensions of social behavior.
Competitive exchanges still require exchange of action-related information and adaptation; the analysis models communicative/interactive behavior between players, fitting social communication.
Competition engages self-monitoring, response inhibition and planning (pre-SMA, IFG) and self-other distinction processes while reacting to partner moves, so self-perception processes are implicated.

Competition requires predicting and reacting to an opponent’s actions; the contrast assesses neural correlates of perceiving and understanding others’ behaviors and intentions (mentalizing/action perception).
CN > TB contrast compares concurrent vs turn-based interaction structure during social exchange; this manipulation directly targets social processing dynamics (real-time mutual adaptation, iBBDs).

Interaction structure (CN vs TB) modulates cooperative and competitive behavior and affiliative dynamics (e.g., greater success and different reward/mentalizing engagement in CN), so it probes affiliation/attachment-related processes.

Concurrent vs turn-based interaction changes the nature and timing of communicative exchange and mutual information transfer; the contrast indexes social communication demands (real-time signaling and adaptation).
CN requires heightened attention, movement planning and possibly altered self-other distinction, engaging self-related processes when reacting to partner moves; thus perception_self applies.
Difference between CN and TB modulated mentalizing regions (STS, TPJ) reflecting perception and understanding of others’ intentions in real time; therefore perception_others applies.

This three-way style contrast (goal-by-interaction: TB (COO>COM) > CN (COO>COM)) probes how goal (cooperation vs competition) effects differ by interaction structure, a core social processing question measured with iBBDs.
Contrast directly examines how affiliative (cooperative) vs competitive dynamics vary with interaction structure (TB vs CN), thus measuring affiliation/attachment-related neural responses.

By assessing differences in cooperation>competition effects across interaction structures, the contrast targets how communicative demands and mutual signaling differ between TB and CN, fitting social communication.

The contrast examines how self-related reactive processes (planning, monitoring, self-other distinction) change as a function of goal and interaction structure; Builders vs Others show role-dependent self-processing differences.
This contrast captures modulation of neural responses to others’ behavior (iBBDs) across goal and interaction contexts, indexing understanding of others’ intentions and actions.
Builder (COO>COM) > Other (COO>COM) isolates role-by-goal differences in interpersonal brain-behavior coupling, a direct measure of social processing across roles.
This role-specific cooperation>competition contrast addresses how affiliative processes differ between Builders and Others (helpers vs hinderers), relevant to attachment/affiliation constructs.
Roles change communicative demands; modeling differential iBBDs for Builders vs Others during cooperation vs competition captures role-dependent social communication processes.
Builders showed greater engagement of self-referential/precuneus regions in cooperative exchanges; this contrast specifically interrogates self-related processing in role-dependent contexts.
Differences between Builders and Others in neural responses to partner behavior index distinct forms of perceiving and reasoning about the other’s intentions (mentalizing/action perception).
Other (COO>COM) > Builder (COO>COM) is the complementary role-by-goal contrast examining how Others’ (helpers/hinderers) neural reactions differ, directly within social processing domain.
This contrast measures affiliative processes when playing the Other role (helping vs hindering) and how these differ from Builders, thus indexing attachment/affiliation-related neural activity.
Others’ communicative/interactive behavior (help/hinder) and the brain responses they evoke are central to social communication; the contrast explicitly targets this.

Others engaged mPFC/ACC and other socio-cognitive regions during cooperation; this contrast probes self-related evaluative processes in the Other role (e.g., monitoring one's contributions), so perception_self applies.
By modeling Others’ neural reactions to Builders’ moves, the contrast directly assesses perception and understanding of the partner's actions and intentions, i.e., perception_others.

The contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) examines mutual eye contact, interpersonal behavioral coupling (eye-blink NCR), and brain activations/connectivity related to social interaction (ACC, AIC, cerebellum) — clearly measuring social processing at behavioral and neural levels.

The task probes real-time mutual gaze and shared attention between unfamiliar participants but does not assess affiliation, attachment, bonding, or relationship-specific measures (no loved-one vs stranger, no attachment scales).

Eye contact and reciprocal gaze (production and reception of facial/eye signals) are core social-communication behaviors; the analyses explicitly quantify gaze/eye-blink coupling and related neural substrates and thus measure social communication.

The study interprets ACC–AIC engagement as related to self-awareness and reports enhanced self-related processing during live eye contact; thus the contrast probes perception/understanding of self-related processes (agency/self-awareness) in the social context.

Analyses quantify how a participant’s attention/eye-blinks are influenced by the partner (NCR causality), and probe neural substrates supporting perception/understanding of another’s actions (interbrain synchronization in occipital/LOTC); this matches perception and understanding of others.

gPPI shows LIVE-specific enhancement of effective connectivity from ACC to AIC during mutual eye contact, reflecting social-interaction related modulations of network function — a direct measure of social processing.
Effective connectivity analyses reflect on-line interaction and self/other processing but do not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding, relationship or attachment measures).

Enhanced ACC→AIC connectivity during LIVE reflects neural mechanisms supporting reciprocal social signaling (eye contact) and processing of socially relevant facial cues — directly tied to social communication.
ACC→AIC connectivity is interpreted by authors as supporting self-awareness (AIC input, ACC output) during live interaction, so this analysis probes self-related perception/processing.
Modulation of effective connectivity during live interaction indicates altered processing of partner-derived signals (perception/understanding of others’ behavior) and thus matches this construct.
Interbrain synchronization (LIVE > REPLAY) in bilateral MOG/LOTC during mutual gaze demonstrates cross-brain coupling in a social task, directly indexing social processing.
Interbrain synchronization reflects temporal alignment of attention and action perception but does not assess affiliation or attachment/bonding between participants.
Interbrain coupling in visual/LOTC regions during live eye contact reflects reciprocal signaling and shared perceptual processing of facial communication (gaze/blink), fitting social communication.

Authors link shared attention and self-other alignment to self-awareness mechanisms; interbrain synchronization in regions receiving efference copies suggests involvement of self-related representations (e.g., efference), so this analysis touches perception of self.

Interbrain synchronization indexes alignment to the partner’s behavior (eye-blinks/gaze), directly reflecting perception and representation of another’s actions and temporal attention — thus meets perception of others.

Face Processing Task (fearful vs neutral faces) targets socioemotional processing, mentalizing, empathy, and anxiety-related processes; clearly measures social processing.
Task/stimuli and contrasts do not assess affiliation or attachment (no loved-one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation/competition manipulations).
Task involves reception of facial communication (emotion recognition, face evaluation, mentalizing) and the regressions highlight TPJ and STS regions tied to facial/social communication.
Participants rate their own negative feeling to faces and analyses implicate mPFC and self-referential/rumination processes, indicating self-perception/self-reflection measures.
Analyses focus on understanding others’ emotional states and mentalizing (TPJ, STS involvement) when processing faces, matching perception/understanding of others.
Questionnaire regressions on task data probe socioemotional processing and trait modulation of social processing (empathy/worry/anxiety effects).
Questionnaire regressions do not index affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts (no measures of bonding/attachment).
Regressions highlight facial/emotion reception regions (TPJ, insula) and modulation by empathy, indicating social communication reception processes.
Regressions link trait measures to mPFC and rumination-related activity, reflecting self-reflection/self-perception processes.
Findings show modulation of regions (TPJ) involved in understanding others’ mental states by empathy, indicating perception of others.
STAI regressions relate trait anxiety to socioemotional face processing and interoceptive/mentalizing networks, meeting social processing criteria.
Trait anxiety analyses do not probe affiliation/attachment-specific constructs or contrasts.
Face-processing task and STAI regressions implicate insula and TPJ in processing social-affective facial cues, consistent with social communication reception.
Anxiety-related increases in insula and mPFC for neutral>fear reflect interoception and self-referential processing (self-perception).
Analyses involve understanding/responding to others’ facial emotions and mental states (TPJ/STS involvement), thus perception of others is relevant.
PSWQ (worry) regressions probe modulation of socioemotional face processing, including mPFC and sustained processing—fits social processing.
Worry regressions do not examine affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation contrasts).
Worry relates to processing of faces and engagement of regions tied to facial/emotional communication and mentalizing (TPJ/mPFC/insula involvement).
Worry-related mPFC activation for neutral>fear indicates internal mentation/self-referential processing (perception of self).
Worry and its relation to amygdala–TPJ/insula connectivity suggest altered processing of others’ emotional states, matching perception of others.
RRS (rumination) regressions show widespread modulation across socioemotional network (TPJ, insula, mPFC), indicating broad social processing involvement.
Rumination analyses do not target affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts (no relationship/attachment tasks).
RRS-related activations in bilateral TPJ and insula during face processing pertain to reception of facial communication and mentalizing.
Rumination linked to mPFC activity and self-referential processing (reflection/brooding subscales), indicating perception of self.
RRS associations with TPJ and amygdala–TPJ connectivity reflect processing of others’ mental states and emotions (perception of others).

The cyberball exclusion task is a social task examining responses to social exclusion and how social support modulates that response (behavioral ratings and neural activity in right anterior insula). The contrast (exclusion run1>run2) directly measures changes in social processing following emotional support.

Cyberball exclusion targets affiliation/attachment-related processes (belonging, social bonds). The contrast assesses how emotional support (gentle touch) alters affiliation-related distress, so it measures affiliation/attachment.

The task involves interpersonal interaction (ball-tossing) and exchange/representation of social behavior; the contrast measures changes in social communicative context after support, thus relevant to social communication.

Participants provided self-reported emotional ratings and neural activity reflects self-experience of social pain (AI). The contrast measures changes in self-perception/affective state following support.

The task requires tracking other players’ behavior and intentions (who throws to whom). Emotional support modulates neural responses to others’ exclusionary behavior; thus the contrast engages perception/understanding of others.

The contrast examines neural changes during social exclusion (reduced TPJ activity) after appraisal support; this is a social-processing manipulation of how information alters social exclusion experience.

Appraisal support provided information about the social ties of the other players, altering affiliation-related interpretations and increasing reported unpleasantness; the contrast probes affiliation/attachment processes.

Appraisal support consisted of text messages conveying social information; the contrast measures effects of that communicative input on neural processing (TPJ/ToM), so it maps onto social communication.

Behavioral unpleasantness ratings (self-reported) changed after appraisal support and were related to subgenual ACC activity in related contrasts; this contrast therefore affects self-perception/affective state.
Findings include TPJ (a ToM region) modulation after appraisal support, directly implicating perception and understanding of others’ mental states; the contrast measures this process.
This contrast (exclusion run2>run1) shows increased subgenual ACC after appraisal support during social exclusion, indexing altered social-affective processing; thus it measures social processing.

Appraisal support increased negative affect and subACC activity, reflecting changes in affiliation/attachment-related affective responses to exclusion; the contrast targets affiliation-related processing.

The appraisal manipulation was delivered via communicative text and the contrast captures the neural consequences of that communicated information on social exclusion responses, relevant to social communication.
The contrast indexes changes in self-reported unpleasantness correlated with subACC activity after appraisal support, indicating modulation of self-perception/affective state.

Appraisal support altered regions implicated in understanding others (TPJ in related contrasts) and the contrast shows affective consequences (subACC) tied to reinterpretation of others’ intentions, thus engaging perception of others.
