Contrast compares dynamic facial expressions (social/emotional stimuli) vs nonsocial mosaics, directly probing social processing (perception of emotion, social cues). Whole-brain FWE results identify social brain regions (amygdala, STS, IFG), confirming measurement of social processing.
Stimuli are emotional facial expressions but the task does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts).

The contrast assesses reception of facial communication (dynamic facial expressions), engaging receptive facial communication processes (STS, FG, amygdala), matching the social_communication construct.
Task is passive observation of others' facial expressions and does not assess self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; thus it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
The contrast directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states via dynamic facial expressions (engages neural substrates for action/animacy/mental state perception).
This interaction examines the stimulus-type effect (expression>mosaic) across emotions, still assessing social processing of dynamic facial expressions; the primary contrast remains social.
Although emotion is a factor, the analysis does not probe affiliation/attachment (no bonding/cooperation/loved-one contrasts).
Examines how social-communication-related activation (expression>mosaic) varies with emotion; still targets reception of facial communication processes.
Analysis concerns perception of others' expressions across emotion conditions, not self-related processing.
Tests whether perception/understanding of others (response to dynamic expressions) differs by emotion, directly relevant to perception_others.
This analysis examines stimulus-type effects across participant sex; it still assesses social processing of dynamic expressions versus mosaics.
Participant sex factor does not transform the task into an affiliation/attachment measure; no bonding/cooperation contrasts are present.
Assesses whether reception of facial communication (expression>mosaic) differs by sex; remains squarely within social_communication.
The contrast and sex factor do not probe self-perception or self-knowledge processes.
Evaluates perception/understanding of others' expressions and possible sex differences, meeting perception_others criteria.
Three-way interaction includes stimulus-type, emotion, and sex but still centers on social processing of dynamic facial expressions vs mosaics.
No measures or contrasts targeting affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, loved-one vs stranger) are present.
This interaction tests modulation of reception of facial communication by emotion and sex; remains within social_communication.
No self-related judgments or self-awareness measures are involved in this analysis.
Directly relevant to perception and understanding of others' emotional states across emotion and sex factors.
Laterality comparison of expression>mosaic directly tests lateralized social processing of facial expressions, still a social task probing perception and processing of social cues.
Laterality analysis addresses hemispheric dominance for facial expression processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Tests lateralization of reception of facial communication (dynamic expressions), directly relevant to social_communication (receptive facial communication).
Analysis concerns perception of others and hemispheric dominance, not self-perception processes.
Laterality contrast assesses hemispheric dominance in perceiving others' expressions (mental state/action/animacy perception), meeting perception_others criteria.
This analysis examines whether lateralized expression>mosaic effects vary by emotion; it remains a social processing measure of dynamic facial expressions.
Inclusion of emotion and laterality does not convert the task into an affiliation/attachment measure; no relevant contrasts for bonding or attachment are present.
Assesses modulation of lateralized reception of facial communication by emotion; directly relevant to receptive facial communication processes.
Focus is on perception of others' expressions and hemispheric effects across emotions, not self-related processing.
Direct test of whether perception/understanding of others' emotional expressions shows emotion-dependent laterality; meets perception_others criteria.
Tests whether lateralized expression>mosaic effects vary by participant sex; still a social-processing measure of dynamic facial expressions.
Participant sex factor does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs; no bonding/cooperation contrasts are included.
Analyzes sex-related modulation of lateralized reception of facial communication, relevant to social_communication.
Analysis focuses on others' expressions and hemispheric effects by sex, not self-related perception or agency.
Directly probes perception/understanding of others' expressions and sex differences in laterality; fits perception_others inclusion criteria.
Four-way interaction includes stimulus-type, emotion, sex, and laterality but remains centered on social processing of dynamic facial expressions versus mosaics.
Despite multiple factors, the analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/kinship/cooperation contrasts).
Tests complex modulators of reception of facial communication (emotion, sex, laterality) and therefore falls within social_communication.
No measures of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge are included in this analysis.
Four-way analysis pertains to perception and understanding of others' emotional expressions and their lateralization/modulation by emotion and sex, satisfying perception_others criteria.

The contrast (increased responses to faces before treatment) involves viewing human faces with social stigma and implicit bias; the task engages social perception and social-cognitive processing (implicit dehumanization, empathy suppression). This directly measures social processing.

The experiment does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts); it uses a gender-judgement cover task and contrasts disfigured vs treated faces, which is not an affiliation/attachment paradigm.

Participants view faces and make gender judgements; the contrast examines neural responses to facial features relevant to reception of facial communication (face perception, social cues, stigma). This fits the reception of facial communication subconstruct of social communication.
No task or contrast probes self-related processing, agency, or self-knowledge. The paradigm focuses on perception of others, not judgments about the self.

The contrast reflects perception and evaluation of others (disfigured vs post-treatment faces) and is explicitly interpreted in the paper as relating to empathy, mentalizing, and dehumanization — core aspects of perception/understanding of others.

The contrast (decreased responses to faces before treatment) examines neural responses tied to social-cognitive processes (reduced anterior cingulate/MPFC activation interpreted as reduced empathy/mentalizing). It therefore measures social processing.

This contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons); it measures neural responses to stigmatized others rather than affiliation.

Although the primary finding is decreased activation in medial ACC/MPFC, the task still involves viewing faces and inferring social information; perception of facial cues and related social communication processes are engaged, meeting the reception of facial communication criterion.
No measures of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge are present in this contrast; interpretations focus on perception of others and empathy rather than self-related processing.

The decreased ACC/MPFC response is interpreted as suppressed empathy/mentalizing toward disfigured individuals, which directly indexes perception and understanding of others’ mental states and traits.

Decision-making contrast from the prisoners' dilemma (choices to cooperate vs defect) is a social task assessing social behaviour and decision-making; it directly measures social processing (cooperation, trust, reciprocity).
The decision phase operationalizes cooperation/competition in a PDG, which directly probes affiliation/attachment-related behaviour (formation/maintenance of cooperative ties).

The task involves interaction with opponents represented by faces and requires exchange of socially relevant information (decisions contingent on perceived partner behavior), tapping social communication processes (receptive and decision components).

Choice behaviour in the decision phase reflects self-referential decision-making and agency (evaluating own options and strategies), meeting criteria for perception/understanding of self in social contexts.
Decisions depend on inferences about the other players’ likely choices (mentalizing, trust), directly engaging perception and understanding of others' mental states.
Result-phase contrast (perception of outcomes following partner behaviour) is part of the social interaction task and measures social processing (feedback from others, reciprocity effects).
Outcome perception in PDG (reciprocation or betrayal) directly bears on affiliation/attachment dynamics (maintenance or breakdown of cooperative relationships).
Result perception requires interpretation of partner behavior and social feedback, engaging receptive aspects of social communication (interpreting partner's action).
Watching outcomes involves self-evaluation of one’s choice consequences and monitoring performance/strategy, implicating self-related processing (agency, self-monitoring).
Outcome perception requires assessing the other player's action and intentions (mental state attribution), thus measuring perception and understanding of others.
Group-specific summary (patients) derives from the PDG social interaction task and therefore measures social processing within the patient group.
Patient group analyses of cooperation rates and associated activations reflect affiliation/attachment processes (cooperation tendencies and relationship-building).
Patient-specific activations relate to face processing, mentalizing and responses to partner behaviour, implicating social communication functions.
Analyses in patients include decision-related signals (choice formation and monitoring) that reflect self-related processes (agency, strategy evaluation).
Patient analyses examine mentalizing-related regions and responses to partner actions, directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Group-specific summary (controls) is derived from the same PDG social task and measures social processing within healthy participants.
Control group analyses of cooperative behaviour and activations reflect affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation dynamics with partners).
Control-specific activations include temporal and face-processing regions and responses to partner behaviour, implicating social communication (facial reception and interpretation).
Control analyses include decision-making signals and outcome evaluation reflecting self-related processing (agency, self-monitoring).
Control analyses show engagement of regions supporting mentalizing and interpretation of others’ actions, indexing perception of others.
Main effect of group (patients vs controls) on activation (e.g., MPFC differences) arises from a social interaction contrast and therefore reflects differences in social processing between groups.
Group differences in cooperation-related neural activity (MPFC and frontal regions) map onto affiliation/attachment processes influencing cooperative relationships.
Between-group effects in regions implicated in social cognition and face/temporal processing indicate alterations in social communication mechanisms between groups.
Group differences in medial prefrontal activation relate to self-referential and decision processes (self-monitoring, agency) during social decisions, satisfying self-perception inclusion.
MPFC and other reported group-difference regions are involved in mentalizing and understanding others, so the main effect captures perception/understanding of others.
Main effect of condition (decision vs result) tests different social-cognitive stages in the PDG and thus measures social processing across task phases.
Condition differences (decision vs result) reflect dynamics of affiliation (deciding to cooperate vs processing reciprocation/betrayal), directly tied to attachment-related processes.
Different conditions engage distinct communication-related processes (choice formation vs interpreting partner feedback), meeting social communication criteria.
Decision and result conditions differentially engage self-related evaluation (agency during choice, self-monitoring after outcomes), addressing perception of self.
Decision vs result contrasts probe how participants represent and update beliefs about others across phases (mental state inference), measuring perception of others.
ROI main effect of group focuses on frontal, medial prefrontal and other social-network ROIs derived from the PDG; these ROIs index social processing differences between groups.
ROI effects in superior frontal and medial prefrontal ROIs correlate with trust and cooperation measures, indicating affiliation/attachment processes are measured in this analysis.
ROI analysis includes areas implicated in face/mentalizing processing and correlations with trustworthiness ratings, capturing social communication functions.
ROI %BOLD changes correlated with trust and adherence and reflect self-related decision processes (choice-related activation and self-monitoring), satisfying perception_self.
ROI activations correlate with trustworthiness ratings and mentalizing measures, directly indexing perception and understanding of others in the social task.

The ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast assesses observation of goal-directed hand actions of others, a social-related task involving perceiving others’ actions. This fits Social Processing (broad social perception/understanding).
The task does not measure affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related processes (no kinship, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons).
The contrast probes action perception (kinematics), not communicative signals or facial/expressive communication; it does not measure social communication constructs.
The task measures perception of others’ actions, not self-related awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
The contrast specifically measures Action Perception (perception and understanding of others’ actions/kinematics), directly matching this annotation’s subconstruct (Action Perception).
The ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast evaluates observation of others’ goal-directed hand actions; this is a social-related perceptual task falling under Social Processing.
No measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger) are present in this contrast.
The task focuses on kinematic action perception rather than communicative exchange or facial/non-facial communicative behaviors.
This analysis concerns perception of others’ actions, not self-related constructs (agency or self-knowledge).
Directly targets Action Perception—the perception and understanding of others’ actions/kinematics—meeting this annotation’s criteria.
The ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast tests observation of others’ hand actions, a social perceptual task encompassed by Social Processing.
The contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/kinship/cooperation comparisons).
The experiment probes action kinematics perception, not communicative signaling or exchange, so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
Measures perception of others’ actions (action observation), not self-related awareness or judgments; thus Perception_Self is not applicable.
The contrast specifically indexes Action Perception (perception/understanding of others’ actions and kinematics), matching this annotation.
